prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
TRUTH'S WHISPER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But your voice is often buried beneath convenient lies.
You hide in shadows while falsehoods dance in daylight,
Patient as mountains, waiting for willing ears.

I have trained myself to hear your whisper
Beneath the cacophony of comfortable deceptions.
You demand courage from those who would voice you—
A price many find too steep to pay.

Sometimes I press my ear to the ground,
Feeling for your vibrations in the soil of experience.
You come not as thunderclap but as persistent stream,
Wearing channels through the bedrock of certainty.

If I listen closely enough, will my tongue
Become the conduit for your unvarnished essence?
Or will I, too, dilute you with my fears,
Mixing you with honey to ease your bitter taste?

Truth! I shall speak you—but only if I've earned
The right through faithful listening in the silence.

LISTENING FOR TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how seldom do I quiet my mind enough to hear.
Your voice competes with sirens of desire,
With comfortable illusions I've collected through the years.

You wait in patient silence while I fill the void
With endless chatter, opinions, half-formed thoughts.
You cannot force your way into unwilling ears
Or hearts that have built fortresses against your light.

Sometimes I catch glimpses of you in unexpected places—
In the eyes of a child, unfiltered and pure,
In moments of crisis when pretense falls away,
In the space between heartbeats when time seems to pause.

To speak you truly requires a lifetime of listening,
Of shedding layers of self-deception like old skin,
Of standing naked before your unforgiving mirror
And loving what remains despite its imperfections.

So I practice silence, cultivate attention,
Hoping one day my words might ring with your clear tone.

THE LISTENER'S VOW

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If my ears have grown accustomed to your voice,
If I've learned to distinguish your steady rhythm
From the seductive cadence of what I wish to hear.

How easy to mistake echoes of my own desires
For your authoritative proclamation.
How simple to believe I've found you
When I've only discovered a comfortable reflection.

Yet you persist, patient beyond measure,
Whispering beneath the surface of things,
Neither cruel nor kind, simply present,
Waiting for those brave enough to receive.

I pledge to create silence within myself,
To clear away the clutter of assumption,
To sit in the discomfort of uncertainty
Until your voice emerges clear and unmistakable.

Only then, when I've truly heard you,
When your essence has taken root in my being,
Will my tongue be worthy of your weight,
And my words carry the resonance of what is real.

TRUTH'S BARGAIN

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But we both know how rarely I've kept still.
My ears are filled with noise of my own making—
The static of justifications, the hum of pride.

You offer no compromise, demand complete surrender.
You care nothing for my comfort or reputation.
You stand unmoved by tears or clever arguments,
A mountain that will not shift to ease my passage.

What strange bargain we have struck, you and I—
That I might voice your essence only if
I first become an empty vessel, hollow and waiting,
Stripped of pretense and expectation.

So I practice this discipline of listening,
Of quieting the clamor of my own certainty,
Of sitting with discomfort as you reveal
What I have hidden even from myself.

And when at last my lips form your shape,
The words will not be mine but ours together—
A collaboration between seeker and sought,
The listener finally worthy of becoming speaker.

THE HABIT OF TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I have trained my inner ear to recognize
The subtle frequency on which you broadcast,
Cutting through the static of convenient fiction.

How strange that you require such discipline—
A daily practice of attentiveness and doubt,
Of questioning what comes too easily,
Of suspecting what fits too perfectly.

You hide in plain sight, neither obscure nor obvious,
But requiring a particular quality of attention
That must be cultivated like a rare and delicate plant,
Watered with humility, pruned with discernment.

I confess I have often claimed your name
While speaking only my own limited perception.
I have mistaken certainty for clarity,
Conviction for communion with your essence.

So I begin again the practice of listening—
Not for what confirms but what transforms,
Not for what comforts but what awakens,
Knowing that only then can I truly speak you into being.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
TRUTH'S ECHO

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how often do I close my ears to your whispers?
You arrive uninvited at midnight hours,
Tapping at windows of consciousness I've shuttered tight.

You are the mirror I avoid in morning light,
The letter I leave unopened on the table.
Yet still you wait, patient as stone,
Outlasting my elaborate distractions.

If I listened more closely to your cadence,
Would my own voice grow stronger in its telling?
Perhaps the habit of hearing precedes the courage of speaking—

So I shall practice sitting in your presence,
Learning the contours of your face,
Until my tongue no longer stumbles
Over the weight of what must be said.

LISTENING PRACTICE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears are filled with the noise of convenience,
The comfortable static of half-beliefs,
The lullabies of what I wish to hear.

How does one cultivate such a habit?
Perhaps in silence, when the mind grows still
And the heart beats loud enough to hear itself.
Perhaps in pain, when illusions fall away like autumn leaves.

I have been a stranger to you, Truth,
Though you have lived beside me all along,
Patient as the mountains, persistent as the tide.

Today I begin again—cupping hands around my ears,
Turning toward your voice like a flower to the sun,
Knowing that to speak you truly
I must first become the vessel that receives.

THE LISTENER'S VOW

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I can train my soul to recognize your face
Amid the carnival of masks that dance before me,
Each one claiming your name with borrowed authority.

You speak in languages I've yet to master—
In the space between heartbeats,
In the silence after thunder,
In the questions children ask before they learn not to.

I've mistaken echoes for your voice before,
Repeated them with zealot's certainty,
Only to find myself speaking to empty rooms.

So now I vow to listen first—
To cup my palms against the earth,
To press my ear to the wall of the universe,
To become the apprentice of your subtle tongue.

TRUTHSPEAKER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But habits form slowly, like water carving stone,
And I have spent years blocking my ears
With cotton comforts and convenient noise.

You do not shout to be heard above the din.
You wait, still as meditation,
For the moment when I grow tired
Of my own exhausting narratives.

What discipline this requires—
To sit before you empty-handed,
To abandon the scriptures I've written about myself,
To let my certainties dissolve like sugar in rain.

Perhaps today I'll practice for an hour,
Tomorrow for two, until listening becomes
As natural as breathing, and speaking you
As inevitable as the tide returning to shore.

THE HABIT OF TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
This is the bargain we make at the crossroads,
Where intention meets action,
Where promises crystallize into practice.

How strange that I must learn to hear
What has always been speaking—
In the trembling leaves, the midnight doubts,
The unexpected tears that arrive without explanation.

I have been deaf by choice, by fear,
By the comfort of constructed realities
That fit like well-worn shoes around my feet.

But now I kneel before you, Truth,
Ears pressed to your chest like a physician,
Learning the rhythm of your heartbeat
So that someday my voice might become its echo.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:

When your whispers fade beneath the noise of time?

While I clothe myself in comfortable lies, well-worn.

Would my foundations crumble, disappear?

Truth, you are the mirror I both seek and shun,
Reflecting light on shadows I would rather run.

So I promise to listen, to cultivate the art
Of hearing you completely, with an open heart.
For truth unheard remains a distant star,

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears are stuffed with cotton dreams and wishful thinking.
The symphony of reality plays on despite my muffled hearing,
As I dance to tunes of my own creation, stumbling, sinking.

When did I first turn away from your clear-eyed gaze?
Perhaps when childhood faded into responsibility's haze.
Or was it when first love shattered on expectation's floor,
Leaving me to gather fragments I'd rather ignore?

To speak truth requires first we learn to hear it call—
Through propaganda's noise, through comfort's siren song.
It demands we strip ourselves of armor long maintained,
To stand vulnerable before what cannot be explained.

So let me cup my hands around my willing ears,
And train my tongue to echo what sincerely appears.
For in this habit of listening, I might finally find
The courage to speak truth, leaving falsehoods behind.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But habits form like rivers carving stone—
Slow persistence through resistant matter,
Until the path becomes the only one we've known.

I've listened to the voices that bring comfort,
To echoes that return what I have sent,
To stories that paint me as the hero,
To lullabies that help me to relent.

But truth, you sing a different kind of music,
Discordant sometimes, jarring to the ear,
You don't conform to melodies I've written,
You play the notes I've trained myself to fear.

So how do I form this habit of attention?
How do I tune my ears to your strange sound?
Perhaps by sitting longer in the silence,
By letting my defenses tumble down.

Truth! I shall speak you—this I promise now—
But first, I'll learn to listen, somehow.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But listening requires stillness I have yet to master.
In a world of constant noise and endless chatter,
Your voice becomes a whisper, growing fainter, faster.

You hide in plain sight, between heartbeats and breaths,
In the spaces where certainty meets doubt.
You reside in questions that have no simple answers,
In the courage to face what we'd rather live without.

Sometimes I catch glimpses of your form,
Reflected in tears or unexpected laughter,
In moments when pretense falls away
And I stand naked before what truly matters.

Perhaps the habit starts with small surrenders—
Admitting when I'm wrong, embracing mystery,
Allowing contradiction to exist unchallenged,
Accepting that you're rarely what I wish you'd be.

So Truth, I vow to cultivate this practice,
To quiet my mind and open up my ears.
For only when I truly learn to listen,
Can I speak the truth that silences my fears.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A habit hard to form in days of crafted narratives,
When algorithms feed me what I wish to hear,
And echo chambers comfort with alternatives.

You stand before me, Truth, in simple garments,
No flourish or embellishment to catch the eye,
While Falsehood dances by in sequined splendor,
With honeyed words and never-ending supply.

What discipline it takes to tune my senses
To hear your steady rhythm, soft and clear,
To train my tongue to shape itself around you,
When easier words are always hovering near.

Perhaps I'll start by listening to silence,
By questioning the thoughts I hold most dear,
By seeking out the voices that discomfort,
By facing what I've long refused to hear.

Truth! I shall speak you—this becomes my practice,
A daily meditation, conscious choice.
First listening with humility and patience,
Then lending you my fragile, human voice.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
TRUTH'S WHISPER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how seldom do I quiet my mind enough to hear.
Your voice is not thunder but the gentle rustle of leaves,
Not proclamation but question mark curling at day's end.

I have stuffed my ears with cotton comforts,
Packed them tight with excuses and distractions.
Yet still you find the cracks in my defenses,
Slipping through like water, persistent and clear.

If I am to be your vessel, I must first be empty.
If I am to echo your wisdom, I must first absorb it.
The habit of listening requires the courage of silence,
The discipline of doubt, the humility of not-knowing.

So I shall practice this art of receptive waiting,
This patient cultivation of truth-ready soil.
And perhaps one day, what grows from my lips
Will be as honest as the earth that nourished it.

LISTENING FOR TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But the listening itself is a craft I've yet to master.
Your voice competes with sirens of convenience,
With lullabies of what I wish to hear instead.

Truth, you are not always welcome at my table.
You upset the careful arrangements I've made,
Turn over furniture I've positioned just so,
And leave me to reckon with the aftermath.

Sometimes I pretend not to hear your knocking,
Or I answer the door but leave you on the threshold.
I nod as if in understanding while planning my escape—
A coward before your unflinching gaze.

Yet what freedom might come from surrender!
What strength from admitting weakness!
What voice might emerge from my throat
If I let your wild current carry me beyond pretense.

So I practice: ears open, defenses down.
I am learning to listen before I speak.

THE HABIT OF TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But habits form slowly, like rivers carving canyons,
And I have been deaf for so long, comfortable
In the cushioned silence of my own making.

What does it mean to listen to truth?
To cup my hands around the flickering flame
Of what is, not what I wish would be?
To stand naked before the mirror, unflinching?

Perhaps it begins with small truths—
The acknowledgment of morning light,
The acceptance of my own reflection,
The recognition of pain I've caused.

Truth requires practice, like any discipline.
It demands daily attendance, regular communion.
It asks that I kneel before it, not in worship
But in the humility of a student before a master.

So I will listen. I will make of my body
An instrument tuned to your frequency.
And when my mouth opens, may what emerges
Be worthy of the name I dare to give it: Truth.

TRUTH'S BARGAIN

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A bargain struck between my tongue and ear.
But how rarely they collaborate, these parts of me—
One racing ahead while the other lags behind.

I have been a ventriloquist of falsehoods,
My mouth moving to scripts written by fear.
I have been an architect of convenient narratives,
Building shelters against the storm of what is real.

Truth, you are not cruel, though you cut deeply.
You are not unkind, though you spare no illusion.
You are simply what remains when all else falls away—
The skeleton beneath flesh, the stone beneath soil.

If I am to invite you into my speech,
I must first invite you into my listening.
I must create within myself a chamber of echoes
Where your voice can reverberate, uncensored.

So I practice this alchemy: silence into speech,
Reception into expression, listening into truth-telling.
And in this transformation, perhaps I too am changed—
A vessel both emptied and filled by what passes through.

THE LISTENER'S VOW

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But listening is an art I've neglected for too long.
I've filled my days with noise to drown your whispers,
Turned up the volume when your murmurs disturbed me.

You do not shout to be heard above the din.
You do not compete with the carnival barkers of falsehood.
You simply wait, patient as stone, enduring as stars,
For the moment when I finally exhaust myself into silence.

What would happen if I made a sanctuary of my attention?
If I cleared a space within, swept clean of expectation?
If I approached you not as conqueror but as supplicant,
Not demanding answers but offering openness?

Perhaps then my words would carry your weight,
My voice would resonate with your clarity.
Perhaps then what flows from me to others
Would nourish rather than deplete, illuminate rather than obscure.

So I vow to practice the discipline of receptivity,
To cultivate the habit of deep listening.
And in that fertile soil, may truth take root and flourish,
Speaking itself through the imperfect instrument of my voice.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:

The whispers of reality knock at stubborn doors,
While I, the reluctant host, feign sleep.

You come dressed in simple garments,
No ornate lies to make you palatable.
Yet I've grown accustomed to sweet deceptions,
The honey-coating that makes bitter pills slide down.

If I train my ears to your frequency,
Will my tongue remember how to form your shape?
Or have the muscles of honesty atrophied
From years of convenient silence?

I commit now to this practice of listening,
To cup my hands around your voice,
To let your echoes reverberate within me
Until speaking you becomes as natural as breath.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But silence has been my trusted companion for years.
I've watched your shadow dance across my threshold,
Too frightened to invite you fully in.

How strange that I would promise to proclaim
What I have diligently avoided hearing.
Like promising to translate a language
I've never bothered learning.

The habit of listening requires discipline,
A willingness to sit with discomfort,
To let your sharp edges cut away
The comfortable illusions I've built.

Perhaps today I'll crack open a window,
Let your whispers find their way to me.
And tomorrow, perhaps a door,
Until my home becomes a place where you reside freely.

For truth cannot be spoken
By those who cover their ears with pride.
I shall learn to listen first,
Then my voice will follow, clear and unafraid.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

But my ears are filled with the noise of convenience,
The static of self-deception humming constantly.
I've constructed elaborate systems
To filter you out, Truth, to keep you at bay.

What audacity I have—
To claim I'll voice what I cannot hear,
To promise utterance without reception,
To be your messenger without receiving your message.

The habit of listening requires surrender,
A laying down of weapons forged in fear.
It demands I create space within myself
Where your voice can resonate, undistorted.

So I begin this practice today:
Cupping hands behind my ears,
Turning toward your direction,
Letting your vibrations touch my drums.

Only then, when I've learned to receive you fully,
Will my tongue be worthy of shaping your name.
Only then will I speak you, Truth,
As clear and pure as you deserve to be spoken.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

But how rarely do I pause to hear your voice,
Preferring instead the lullabies of comforting lies,
The bedtime stories that help me sleep at night.

You are a patient teacher, Truth,
Waiting in corners of consciousness,
Neither forcing your way in
Nor abandoning me to my delusions.

The habit of listening—what a curious phrase.
As if attentiveness were a garment
I could don each morning,
Rather than a lifelong apprenticeship.

Perhaps I shall begin with small truths,
The ones that whisper rather than shout,
Training my inner ear to recognize
Your particular timbre among the noise.

And maybe then, when listening becomes
As natural as breathing, as constant as heartbeat,
My speaking voice will find itself transformed—
A clear channel through which you flow, unobstructed.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

But habits form slowly, deliberately,
Like water carving canyons through resistant stone.
I have been deaf by choice, by fear, by convenience,
Selective in my hearing, protective of my peace.

The irony does not escape me—
How can these lips form words
My ears refuse to welcome?
How can I be vessel for what I will not hold?

So this becomes my practice:

I shall make a ritual of listening,

Only then, when truth has made a home in me,

Will I dare to open my mouth and let you flow—
A river that has always known its proper course.

I am learning to listen with more than ears,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

responses.text:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would my heart ever truly beat.
In the silence of night's embrace,
I trace the contours of your face
In memory's tender gallery.

The world offers treasures and gold,
Promises of riches untold,
But what value have gems or crowns
When compared to the love that drowns
My soul in warmth that won't grow cold?

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I cross oceans, climb mountains steep.
Time may weather stone to dust,
Steel may surrender to rust,
But my devotion stands firm, complete.

In this universe vast and wide,
You're the star by which I abide.
My compass, my anchor, my light—
Guiding me through darkest night,
The tide to which my heart's waves ride.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I surrender my wild heart;
The freedom I once cherished so,
Now seems a lonely path to go—
A journey incomplete, apart.

The mountains whisper your sweet name,
The rivers carry your refrain.
I find you in the morning dew,
In sunset's gold and midnight blue,
In gentle rain and raging flame.

What alchemy transformed my soul?
What magic made my spirit whole?
I who once wandered far and wide,
Now find my home where you reside,
In your embrace, I've found my goal.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned what it means
To see beyond my selfish needs,
To plant in barren soil the seeds
Of what love truly, deeply means.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could ever satisfy this soul of mine.
Not diamonds plucked from deepest caves,
Nor pearls rescued from ocean waves,
Nor fame that makes the brightest shine.

The universe conspired, it seems,
To weave you through my waking dreams.
Your laughter—music to my ears,
Your presence calms my deepest fears,
Our love outshines all mortal schemes.

When shadows lengthen, day grows old,
And stories of our lives are told,
I'll cherish every moment spent
In love's sweet, sacred testament
More precious far than any gold.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have known this joy complete.
In you, I found my missing part,
The rhythm syncing with my heart,
The dance that makes my life replete.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned to truly see
The beauty in life's fleeting hours,
The wisdom in the wilting flowers,
The grace in all that comes to be.

Before you, I was half-asleep,
Walking paths neither wide nor deep.
You woke me with a gentle touch,
A whispered word that meant so much,
A promise I shall always keep.

The cosmos shifts when our eyes meet,
Time pauses, then resumes its beat
But different somehow, rearranged,
The very fabric of space changed
By love that makes my world complete.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have found my courage true.
To face the mirror of my soul,
To break, then heal, becoming whole—
This gift of self, returned by you.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would stars abandon midnight skies,
Would oceans forsake ancient shores,
Would time unlock its rigid doors,
Would truth relinquish all its lies.

In hands that tremble when we touch,
In breath that catches, speaks too much,
In silent glances, volumes said,
In thoughts that dance inside my head,
I find the love I've missed so much.

What strange alchemy is this?
That transforms pain to perfect bliss,
That makes the ordinary shine,
That turns mere water into wine,
That heals all wounds with just one kiss.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I have learned what matters most.
Not wealth or fame or fleeting youth,
But this enduring, simple truth:
In loving you, I've found my ghost.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:
'Twas noontide of summer,
When heat shimmered gold,

The cicadas sang loudly,

Wildflowers nodded,

The creek barely whispered,

As I paused to ponder
How swift days go by.

The dust motes were dancing
In beams thick as gold,
Time ceased its advancing,
As moments unrolled.

The bees hummed their secrets

While I watched, contented,
Life's gentle, sweet flow.

'Twas noontide of summer,
A pause in time's flight,
When day's brightest number
Revealed life's delight.

'Twas noontide of summer,

And heat pressed upon us
Like weight on our skin.

The world held its breathing,

No leaf dared a quiver,
No bird made a sound.

The horizon wavered
In vaporous haze,
As though reality
Had entered a phase

Where dreams and the waking
World seamlessly blend,
Where beginnings dissolve
And endings suspend.

I stood at the crossroads
Of memory and time,
Where childhood summers
Still perfectly rhyme

With this present moment
Of sunlight and heat—
'Twas noontide of summer,
When past and now meet.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When light ruled supreme,
The sun's blazing fervor
A tangible beam.

The meadows lay silent
Save crickets' soft song,
As nature grew pliant
In day's hours long.

I wandered barefooted
Through grass parched and dry,
My thoughts deeply rooted
In questions of why—

Why time seems eternal
Yet passes so fast,
Like summer infernal,
Too brilliant to last.

The lake in the distance
Gleamed silver and still,
Offering resistance
To noon's fiery will.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When truth comes to light,
And we, the newcomers,
Glimpse wisdom's true height.

'Twas noontide of summer,

Reveal second sight.

The stones of the pathway
Released ancient heat,
As I walked the halfway
Point where seasons meet.

Cicadas were singing

While memories bringing
Sweet joy mixed with pain.

The old willow weeping
Its tears to the pond,
Its branches sweeping
Creates shadows beyond

The realm of the living,
Where ancestors dwell,
Forever forgiving
The tales that we tell.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When visions appear,
And we, the wayfarer,
Find what we hold dear.

Of fae and magic old,
Where time remained unplanted,
And stories yet untold.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When I crossed the threshold there,
Becoming both lost wanderer,
And found beyond compare.

'Twas noontide of summer,
In the garden of my youth,
Where memories yet slumber,
Preserving simple truth.

The porch swing gently creaking,
Grandmother's lemonade,
Cousins laughing, seeking
Refuge in dappled shade.

The scent of fresh-cut clover,
Sweet peaches ripe with sun,
Dog days not yet over,
Adventures just begun.

No phones to cause distraction,
No screens to dim our sight,
Just genuine interaction,
And fireflies at night.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When time moved honey-slow,
Before becoming runner
In life's relentless flow.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

responses.text:

Beneath ancient oak trees,

How strange to remember
Ice crystals and snow
When the mercury climbs
And the hot breezes blow.

The cicadas' fierce drumming
Measured time's steady march,
As shadows grew shorter
Beneath heaven's arch.

I thought of cool waters

Yet beauty still lingers
In this merciless glare,
In the stillness of noon
And the sun-saturated air.

'Twas noontide of summer,
A moment suspended,
Between morning's promise
And day nearly ended.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When dreams turned to dust,
And the old wooden swing set
Surrendered to rust.

I returned to the homestead,
Abandoned for years,
Where childhood's bright laughter
Now echoes through tears.

The garden once tended
By grandmother's hands,
Now choked with tall grasses
And time's harsh demands.

The porch where we gathered
For stories at dusk,
Stands silent and empty,
Its memories hushed.

I walk through the rooms
Where our lives were entwined,
Searching for echoes
Of the past left behind.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When I finally knew,
That places may crumble,
But memories stay true.

Though time marches forward

Love's essence still lingers
Like summer's soft rains.

'Twas noontide of summer,

Between worlds of wonder

I glimpsed ancient spirits

They whispered of secrets
From epochs long past,

Too beautiful to last.

The stones of the hillside
Began softly to sing,
Of glaciers and fire
And earth's violent beginning.

A fox paused to watch me,
With eyes wise and old,
As if we shared knowledge
Too vast to be told.

The wind carried voices
From futures unborn,
Prophecies and warnings
Like thunder before storm.

'Twas noontide of summer,
A moment between,
When reality faltered
And magic was seen.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When lovers first met,
Beneath an old willow
Their destinies set.

Her eyes like the ocean,
His smile like the sun,
Two souls intertwining,
Two hearts beat as one.

The world around faded,
As hands gently touched,
Time slowed to a whisper,
Reality clutched.

Words softly were spoken,
Like prayers to the sky,
Promises and wishes,
Too deep to deny.

The universe witnessed
This moment divine,
When paths long divergent
At last did align.

The bees hummed approval,
The birds sang in tune,
As love bloomed like flowers
In the heat of high noon.

'Twas noontide of summer,
When destiny smiled,
And love's ancient magic
Two hearts reconciled.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

responses.text:
This anger burns deep within,
A flame that consumes my soul.
It feeds on memories bitter and thin,
On wounds that refuse to grow old.

Like magma beneath mountain stone,
It churns and bubbles unseen.
A force of nature I've never known
To be so ruthless, so keen.

I carry this heat through winter days,
Through nights that stretch endlessly on.
It colors my world in crimson haze,
Turns twilight to blood-red dawn.

Perhaps one day I'll learn to release
This furnace that scorches my heart,
Transform this rage into something like peace,
And let my healing finally start.

Until then, I burn silently bright,
A star consuming itself from within,
Holding tight to this terrible light—
This anger burns deep within.

This anger burns deep within,
Like ancient coal seams underground,
Inherited from ancestors' sins,
A legacy I never found.

It smolders quietly most days,
Beneath the mask of pleasant smiles.
But catch me in certain ways,
And witness how the fire reviles.

Not rage that flashes quick and hot,
But something darker, slow and sure.
A patient beast that I have caught,
Or has it caught me? I'm not sure.

Sometimes I wonder whose voice speaks
When fury rises to my tongue.
Is it mine or echoes from peaks
Of battles fought when I was young?

This anger burns deep within,
A companion I never chose.
Both punishment and medicine,
A thorny, necessary rose.

This anger burns deep within,
Like embers nestled in fallen leaves.
Not a sudden flash, but a slow begin—
A patient fire that silently breathes.

It doesn't demand immediate voice,
Nor does it seek swift vengeance now.
It waits, knowing it has the choice
Of when to emerge, and how.

I've carried this heat for many years,
Hidden beneath layers of forgiveness and doubt.
Sometimes cooled by merciful tears,
But never fully extinguished out.

Perhaps this burning is part of me,
A necessary flame that keeps me alive.
A beacon of truth that helps me see
The injustices I've learned to survive.

So I'll honor this anger, deep within,
Not as weakness but as strength reborn.
A sacred fire under my skin,
Illuminating paths previously unworn.

This anger burns deep within,
A molten core beneath fragile crust.
Not born today, but where did it begin?
In childhood slights or broken trust?

It flares at unexpected times,
When I thought its fuel long spent.
Triggered by innocuous chimes,
Or words I'm sure were never meant.

I've tried to douse it with forgiveness,
To smother it with rational thought.
Yet still it persists with stubbornness,
This battle endlessly fought.

Sometimes I wonder if it protects me,
This guardian of boundaries crossed.
Perhaps without it, who would I be?
What essential part would be lost?

So this anger burns deep within,
Neither friend nor foe, but something between.
A complicated, necessary sin,
A shadow and light, unseen yet seen.

This anger burns deep within,
Not as destruction but as light.
A lantern through the darkness thin,
Illuminating wrongs to right.

Society says swallow it down,
That rage is poison, best suppressed.
But buried feelings surely drown
The truth that needs to be expressed.

I've learned to channel this bright flame,
To forge it into purpose clear.
Not shame but power I reclaim,
Transmuting what was once just fear.

For anger shows us where the lines
Of justice have been crossed too far.
It's wisdom wrapped in warning signs,
A compass pointing to the star.

So let this anger burn within,
Not as a curse but as a gift.
A sacred fire to begin
The changes that will cause a shift.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'For the first time in my life'

responses.text:
For the first time in my life
I felt the universe exhale
As if it had been holding its breath
Waiting for me to notice.

The stars aligned in patterns
I'd never bothered to decode,
And the moon, that ancient witness,
Nodded knowingly from above.

For the first time in my life
I understood that beginnings
Don't arrive with fanfare or warning—
They slip in through unlocked doors.

My hands, once clenched in certainty,
Unfurled like spring's first blooms.
The weight I'd carried lightened,
Not because it vanished,
But because I learned to carry it differently.

For the first time in my life
I am both compass and traveler,
Both question and answer,
Both the seeker and what is sought.

FOR THE FIRST TIME IN MY LIFE

For the first time in my life
I saw myself without mirrors,
Without the reflections of others' eyes
Or expectations carved in familial stone.

For the first time in my life
Silence wasn't something to be filled,
But a canvas stretching endlessly,
Inviting colors I never knew I owned.

The clock stopped its tyrannical march.
Seconds became droplets of amber,
Preserving moments I'd rushed through before—
A child's laugh, the scent of rain-soaked earth,
The gentle weight of my own beating heart.

For the first time in my life
I tasted freedom not as escape,
But as the courage to remain
Fullly present in my own story,
Neither hero nor villain,
But gloriously, imperfectly human.

For the first time in my life,
I am enough.

For the first time in my life

I stepped into the ocean
and felt no need to conquer it.
The salt-sting welcomed me
like an honest friend.

For the first time in my life
I watched a sunrise without
documenting its existence,
letting the colors dissolve
on my retinas alone.

For the first time in my life
I spoke without rehearsing,
let words tumble unpolished
from a throat no longer
tight with anticipation.

The world didn't end
when I abandoned perfection.
Instead, it expanded—
filled with textures
I'd numbed myself to feeling.

For the first time in my life
I recognized my shadow
as neither enemy nor stranger
but the necessary darkness
that proves I am standing
in my own light.

FOR THE FIRST TIME IN MY LIFE

For the first time in my life
I heard the whispers of my ancestors
Carried on winds that crossed oceans,
Deserts, mountains, and time itself.

For the first time in my life
I understood that courage isn't
The absence of fear, but fear
Held tenderly in trembling hands.

Memories not yet made
Beckoned from horizons
I once thought unreachable—
Now they seem like promises.

The clock that once raced
Against my beating heart
Has slowed to match my footsteps,
Patient as I gather what I need.

For the first time in my life
I taste the sweetness of uncertainty,
Savor the bitter edge of change,

Their voices rise like morning sunlight,

The Stadium's Roar

Their flags and their banners they are waving,
With joy and excitement they shout,
The stadium trembles with passion,
As champions battle it out.

Painted faces, scarves of allegiance,
A kaleidoscope of tribal pride,
Thousands become one creature,
With a single heart inside.

Drums beating like ancient wartime,
Songs carried through generations,
The poetry of belonging,
Across all borders and nations.

See how they rise in unison,
When glory hangs by a thread,
How strangers embrace like brothers,
When the winning goal is fed.

In this cathedral of emotion,
Where faith never runs in drought,
Their flags and their banners keep waving,
With fervor they continue to shout.

The Festival of Light

Their flags and their banners they are waving,

As lanterns ascend to heaven,

Children with sparklers painting

Elders sharing ancient stories

The village square transformed to magic,

Music weaves through conversations,

Strangers become momentary family,
United in collective dream.

So raise your eyes to witness,
This communion of soul and sound,
As flags flutter like heartbeats,
And joy in simplicity is found.

Ghosts of Revolution

Their flags and their banners they are waving,
With joy and excitement they shout,
But I see through time's thin curtain
To the blood that brought this about.

Phantom armies march beside them,
Silent footfalls on cobbled stone,
Ancestors who paid freedom's ransom,
Whose names are carved in bone.

Can you hear beneath the cheering
The echoes of yesterday's pain?
The whispered prayers of the fallen
Who died so we might remain?

The colors seem brighter when knowing
What darkness they rose to defeat,
The symbols more sacred when feeling
The pulse of history's heartbeat.

So wave your flags with reverence,

But remember those spectral watchers

CARNIVAL OF SOULS

CHILDREN OF THE GAME

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Their flags and their banners they are waving with joy and excitement they shout'

CELEBRATION'S CHORUS

Whatever the reason, their jubilance soars,

To welcome the dawn of what all have decreed.

Their flags and their banners still wave in the breeze,

REVOLUTION'S DAWN

And excitement they shout, voices rising like flame.
The chains of oppression they vow to destroy,

VICTORY'S EMBRACE

The years of defeat now washed clean in this tide,
The drought finally broken by sweet victory's rain.

Sweat-drenched heroes collapse in exhausted bliss,

No moment more perfect, more sacred than this—

The crowd surges forward in rapturous waves,

The memory of struggle each heart now engraves
As the impossible journey gloriously ends.

Confetti descends like multicolored snow,

PARADE OF SOULS

Their flags and their banners they are waving with joy
And excitement they shout as the procession begins.
Ancient traditions no time can destroy,
Connecting the present to what's always been.

The festival streets lined with wide-eyed delight,
Lanterns aglow with ancestral flame.

Masks carved with stories of gods and of beasts,

Drums beating rhythms old as the earth,

CHILDREN'S CRUSADE

Their voices untainted by cynical thought,

What shame should we feel as they lead the way,

Their passion a beacon, their courage a ray

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
WAR'S CHARADE

War's a joke for me and you,
While others bleed and others die.
We watch it all through screens of blue,
Remote-controlled empathy gone awry.

In living rooms, we sit and stare,
At conflicts raging worlds away.
Our coffee warm, our cupboards bare
Of understanding what we say.

The generals laugh, politicians smile,
As stock in weapons climbs and soars.
We shake our heads, we sigh awhile,
Then change the channel, bored by wars.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until it knocks upon our door.
Then suddenly the joke is through,
And humor dies forevermore.

DISTANT LAUGHTER

War's a joke for me and you,
Safe behind our borders strong,
While children huddle, cold and few,
Wondering what they did wrong.

We debate with heated words,
Theories spun in armchairs deep,
While distant sounds of falling birds
Disturb a mother's broken sleep.

Flags wave proudly, anthems sung,
Glory promised, honor sworn.
Yet in the end, when day is done,
Only silent graves are born.

War's a joke for me and you,
A game of chess with living pawns.
But for those whose lives are through,
No laughter greets their final dawns.

THE SPECTATORS

'War's a joke for me and you,'
We who never felt its sting,
Who watch destruction from our view
Like it's some theatrical thing.

With popcorn crunching 'tween our teeth,
We scroll through images of pain,
A thumb-flick past a funeral wreath,
To advertisements once again.

The privilege of distance grants
A certain callousness of heart.
We speak in philosophical rants
While worlds are being torn apart.

So tell me, as we sit and judge,
Or simply turn our gaze away,
Does laughter hide a secret grudge
Against our own complicity today?

PAPER SOLDIERS

'War's a joke for me and you,'
Said the politician's careful tongue.
While signing orders, black on blue,
Sending children with songs unsung.

The boardrooms where the missiles birth
Echo with calculated mirth.
As profits soar beyond all worth,
Blood fertilizes foreign earth.

We trade in abstract concepts now —
Freedom, justice, sovereign right —
While families wonder when and how
They'll survive another night.

So raise your glass in mock salute,
To battles fought by proxy hands.
The truth of war remains acute
For those who die in distant lands.

LAUGH TRACK

War's a joke for me and you,
A punchline in a dark refrain.
The horror wrapped in evening news,
Sanitized to hide the pain.

We've grown accustomed to the show,
The rhythm of destruction's beat.
A constant background hum we know,
As normal as the food we eat.

But listen close between the lines,
When laughter fades to hollow sound.
The truth in every soul unwinds:
No victor stands on hallowed ground.

Perhaps the cosmic jest reveals
That while we play at being gods,
The universe in silence feels
The weight of all our foolish odds.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
War's a joke for me and you,
While distant bombs like thunder boom.
We scroll past headlines, sipping brew,
Numb to horrors that consume.

Safe behind our screens we sit,
Debating conflicts we don't know,
Opinions formed from half-truths lit
By media's curated show.

Children huddle, mothers weep,
Soldiers fall on foreign soil,
While we in comfort, safely sleep,
Untouched by their mortal toil.

War's a joke until it's not,
Until it reaches our front door.
Until our privilege is forgot,
And peace becomes what we implore.

So laugh now at the farce we see,
Distant suffering, abstract pain.
Pray that war will never be
More than words in our domain.

War's a joke for me and you,
As we sit in plush salons,
Sipping wine of crimson hue,
While others' blood stains distant lawns.

We debate with clever words,
Theories spun from armchairs soft,
While death circles like hungry birds
Over trenches dug aloft.

Ironic how we speak of peace,
With bellies full and hands unstained,
Our righteous anger finds release
In tweets and posts, safely contained.

The generals laugh, the merchants smile,
As coffers fill with golden spoil,
The poor and young march rank and file,
To die on unfamiliar soil.

So raise a glass in mockery,
To conflicts that we'll never see,
This bitter, ancient comedy—
War's a joke for you and me.

War's a joke for me and you,
Or so the poet Sassoon said.
But jokes need punchlines, follow-through,
And war leaves millions cold and dead.

We laugh at things we cannot face,
The horror too immense to hold.
Humor becomes our hiding place,
When truth's too bitter to be told.

In boardrooms far from battlefields,
Old men move markers on a map.
Their fortunes grow as nations yield,
While mothers cradle death in lap.

The propaganda spins its tale,
Of glory, honor, duty, right.
But underneath the noble veil,
Lies profit, power, and fright.

So yes, war's joke's on me and you,
The cosmic jest we can't escape.
The punchline old yet always new:
Humanity, its own landscape.

War's a joke for me and you,
Who've never heard the bullets sing,
Nor felt the earth shake, breaking through
The silence that the mornings bring.

War's a headline that we read,
Between our coffee and our toast.
A distant drama guaranteed
To entertain from coast to coast.

The politicians wave their flags,
While sending others' kids to die.
The poor return in body bags,
The rich need never question why.

We change our profile pictures, pray,
And think we've done our righteous part.
Then scroll to what the Kardashians say,
Compartments of the human heart.

So laugh with me at this dark jest,
This cosmic, cruel absurdity.
Where peace is what we claim to quest,
While feeding on barbarity.

War's a joke for me and you,
A game of chess with human pawns.
The kings and queens remain askew,
While knights and bishops plot till dawn.

We watch explosions on TV,
Like fireworks against night sky.
Detached from true calamity,
Too privileged to question why.

The arms dealers count their gold,
Politicians speak of pride.
The truth of suffering untold,
As humanity divides.

Children play with plastic guns,
Trained to glorify the fight.
While somewhere else, someone's sons
Breathe their last this very night.

So laugh with me at this charade,
This circus of our own design.
Where peace is endlessly delayed,
And death becomes the bottom line.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
WAR'S A JOKE

War's a joke for me and you,
While distant bombs fall out of view.
We scroll through headlines, briefly sigh,
Then carry on as others die.

Comfortable in our remove,
No need for us to disapprove
Beyond a tweet, a fleeting thought,
While elsewhere lives are sold and bought.

War's a joke until it's not—
Until the suffering hits our spot,
Until the refugees arrive
With stories of their fight to survive.

Perhaps the joke's on us instead,
Who think ourselves so far ahead,
Yet fail to see the common thread
That binds all hearts, alive or dead.

LAUGH TRACKS

War's a joke for me and you,
Canned laughter on our TV screens.
We watch the graphics, bold and blue,
Not knowing what destruction means.

Strategic points and arrow lines,
Commentators' calm debate.
While somewhere else, in real time,
Humanity disintegrates.

We change the channel, make some tea,
Discuss it like a football match.
Remote control reality—
A passive, privileged dispatch.

The punchline lands in foreign soil,
The setup costs we never pay.
While others bleed and burn and toil,
We keep our comfortable way.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until the day we find it true.

THE SPECTATORS

War's a joke for me and you,
A distant game we never play.
We read the score when it comes through,
And shake our heads, then look away.

Safe behind our borders drawn,
We speak of peace with bloodless lips.
While mothers search from dusk to dawn
For children lost in burning ships.

We debate the politics,
The strategies, the who-did-what.
While elsewhere, time no longer ticks
For those whose names will be forgot.

The privilege of our remove
Makes mockery of human pain.
What suffering would it behoove
Us spectators to explain?

War's a joke for me and you—
The cruelest punchline ever true.

DISTANT THUNDER

War's a joke for me and you,
We who've never heard the sound
Of shells that tear the sky in two
Or felt our homes shake to the ground.

We pontificate and preach
From comfortable ivory towers,
While chaos spreads beyond our reach
And death counts rise by hours.

We change our profile pictures, pray,
And think we've done our human part.
Then sleep in peace at close of day,
No shrapnel lodged within our heart.

Somewhere a child clutches tight
A photo of what used to be,
While we debate who's wrong, who's right,
In our secured democracy.

War's a joke for me and you—
A bitter truth we must face too.

THE PRIVILEGED VIEW

War's a joke for me and you,
We laugh from safe and distant shores.
Our battles fought with words untrue,
While others fight with bombs and wars.

We argue points of history,
Philosophy, and righteous cause.
While families flee in misery,
We pause for coffee, hardly pause.

The headlines fade from day to day,
Our outrage dies by week's end too.
How easily we look away
When suffering's beyond our view.

The luxury of apathy—
A birthright we did not earn.
While oceans fill with refugee,
And cities we don't know now burn.

War's a joke for me and you,
But somewhere, it's the only truth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:

Perhaps the joke's on me and you,

War's a joke for me and you,
Said the poet, eyes of blue.
But beneath those words, a darker truth—
The privilege of distant youth.

We laugh at sabers rattling loud,
Safe behind our peaceful shroud.
Cartoons mock the powerful men
Who sign death warrants with a pen.

But somewhere far from where we stand,
A child picks shrapnel from the sand,
And wonders why the skies above
Rain fire instead of peace and love.

The joke's not funny anymore
When hunger knocks upon your door,
When hospitals become the front,
And children bear war's heaviest brunt.

So when we speak of war in jest,
Remember those who cannot rest,
Whose lives became the punchline to
A joke that's false, a joke untrue—
War's no joke for them, just me and you.

War's a joke for me and you,
A headline skimmed while sipping brew.
We shake our heads, we click our tongues,
While distant lands fill graves with young.

War's a debate on evening news,
A topic where we share our views.
Intellectual games we play,
From conflict safely tucked away.

War's a joke until the day
It takes someone we love away.
Until the bombs fall on our street,
Until retreat means true defeat.

The powerful laugh behind closed doors,
As they tally gains from distant wars.
Sending others' children to the fight,
While their own sleep soundly through the night.

So yes, war's a joke for me and you,
A bitter punchline, sadly true.
But for those caught in its deadly game,

War's a joke until it's not,
Until the joke knocks at your door,
Until the punchline is your name,
Until you can't laugh anymore.

So maybe war's not quite a joke,
But tragedy in jest's disguise,
A mirror held to show us all
The truth behind our privileged lies.

War's a joke for me and you,
A game of chess with living pawns.
We watch from balconies of glass,
As others bleed upon our lawns.

War's a joke in marble halls,
Where suits decide which lives to trade.
The currency of power's game,
Is measured in the graves we've made.

War's a joke in history books,
Sanitized for tender minds.
We learn of glory, not of grief,
Of victory, not what's left behind.

War's a joke until the day,
The laughter catches in your throat.
When faces in the casualty list,
Become the ones you used to know.

Perhaps the joke was never funny,
Perhaps we laughed to mask our fear.
That war's not distant after all,
But always lurking, always near.

War's a joke for me and you,
We chuckle at the evening news.
Remote control in hand, we flip
Between the bombs and cooking shows.

War's a joke we tell ourselves,
To ease the guilt of comfort's price.
'Not our children,' we assure,
'Not our homes,' we rationalize.

War's a joke on distant shores,
Where maps have names we cannot say.
We shake our heads in brief dismay,
Then plan our peaceful holiday.

But jokes have ways of traveling,
Across the borders we erect.
And laughter turns to hollow screams,
When violence comes to collect.

So let us pause before we smile,
At war's dark comedy routine.
For what's a joke to me and you,
Is someone else's dying dream.

War's a joke for me and you,
A headline skimmed at breakfast time.
A conversation starter brief,
Before we change to weather's clime.

We trade our hot takes casually,
Geopolitics between bites.
Expert opinions formed from tweets,
Then on to sports and Friday nights.

Meanwhile in lands we'll never know,
The punchlines land as mortar shells.
The laughter sounds like screaming crowds,
The applause like funeral bells.

War's a joke we tell ourselves,
To keep the truth from sinking in:
That we are safe by accident,
Of birth and luck and privileged sin.

So when we joke of distant wars,
And pontificate on right and wrong,
Remember that our comedy
Is someone else's funeral song.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

responses.text:
WAR'S LAUGHTER

War's a joke for me and you,
While distant bombs light up the sky.
We scroll past headlines, sipping brew,
As strangers in far countries die.

We share memes about the fight,
Debate politics with ease.
Privileged distance, cushioned sight,
Safe behind our boundaries.

But somewhere children cannot sleep,
Their homes reduced to dust and stone.
Somewhere mothers kneel and weep
O'er bodies they once called their own.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until it knocks upon our door.
Until the punchline follows through,
And we aren't laughing anymore.

ARMCHAIR GENERALS

'War's a joke for me and you,'
We parrot from our sheltered rooms,
Opining on what troops should do
While death in foreign lands still looms.

We trade our quips and clever takes,
On conflicts we have never known.
The privilege of our debates—
To theorize from safety's throne.

But ask the soldier, mud-caked, spent,
Or civilians caught between the lines,
Whose homes and hopes lie torn and rent,
If they find humor in these times.

Perhaps the joke's on us instead,
Who treat as sport what others dread,
Who find amusement, safe in bed,
While others count their many dead.

THE SPECTATORS

'War's a joke for me and you,'
A bitter truth wrapped in a lie.
We watch like it's a film review,
As missiles streak across the sky.

We pick our sides like sports teams now,
Cheering victories from afar.
Our hot takes shared, we take a bow,
Detached from all the blood and scar.

The algorithms feed our rage,
With snippets crafted to inflame.
While we perform upon life's stage,
Real people die in freedom's name.

Perhaps one day we'll understand
That distance is our privilege,
When war arrives on our own land,
And laughter turns to sacrilege.

DISTANT THUNDER

'War's a joke for me and you,'
A line that cuts with vicious truth.
We've never felt the bullets through
Our flesh, or lost our promised youth.

We argue politics and sides,
On social media we shout.
While somewhere else, death's shadow hides
In places we know nothing about.

The coffee cools beside our screens,
As we scroll past another blast.
Not knowing what such horror means,
To those for whom peace didn't last.

So laugh we might, from safety's shore,
At conflicts drawn on distant maps.
But karma listens, keeping score,
And history's wheel forever laps.

THE INHERITANCE

'War's a joke for me and you,'
Our grandfathers might disagree.
They who marched in columns true,
Returned with scars we cannot see.

We've inherited their peace,
Mistaken it for natural state.
Assumed that conflicts simply cease,
That violence won't infiltrate.

We mock the drums of distant strife,
As though destruction's someone else's game.
Unaware how fragile life
Can shatter when we fan the flame.

So laugh today, if laugh you must,
At battles fought on foreign soil.
But remember empires turn to dust,
And even victors' blood will boil.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
From childhood's hour I have not been
As others were—I have not seen
As others saw—I could not bring
My passions from a common spring.
From the same source I have not taken
My sorrow; I could not awaken
My heart to joy at the same tone;
And all I loved, I loved alone.

The shadows of my solitude
Were companions in my brooding mood,
In mystery wrapped, I wandered far
Guided only by a distant star.
Different paths my feet have trod,
Different whispers heard from God,
And in this strange divergent way
I found beauty in the shades of gray.

From childhood's hour I have not been
One to follow the beaten path.
I've wandered through forests unseen,
Escaping the aftermath
Of conformity's crushing weight.

From childhood's hour I have stood
At the edge of imagination's sea,
Where others wouldn't or couldn't or should
Not venture—but wildness called to me.

From childhood's hour I have known
The secret language of wind and tree.
In solitude I've grown and flown
On wings invisible but free.

Perhaps we never truly leave
The children that we used to be.
We simply learn to weave
Our innocence with what we see.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Acquainted with ordinary things.
The world I knew was in-between
Reality and dreamings.

Strange creatures lurked beneath my bed,
Not monsters but companions dear.
While others slept, I'd talk instead
To stars that seemed to hover near.

My mother worried for my soul,
My father for my scattered mind.
Yet I was never less than whole—
Just differently designed.

And now as years have claimed their due,
And wisdom settles in my bones,
I see that what I always knew
Was truth that few have known:

That magic isn't something lost,
But something we refuse to see.
And childhood never bears a cost
If you keep its wonder free.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A keeper of time's steady march.
Instead, I've watched the moments lean
Against eternity's grand arch.

The clocks that others wound with care
I left untouched upon the shelf.
While they rushed here and hurried there,
I stretched each second to itself.

Perhaps that's why the years feel thin,
Like pages in a borrowed book.
The story others hurry through,
I savor with a lingering look.

From childhood's hour I have lived
A lifetime in a single day.
And in that strange infinity,
Found all for which one ought to pray:

The patience of a growing tree,
The wisdom of the waiting stars,
And time enough, at last, to be
Exactly as we truly are.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Content to walk on solid ground.
My thoughts like kites without a string
Soared high where eagles dare be found.

My mother called it daydreaming,
My teachers called it wasted time.
But I was secretly weaving
New worlds with nothing but my mind.

If you had asked me where I went
During those silent, distant hours,
I couldn't tell you what I meant
By climbing thought's invisible towers.

Now older, I still find my way
To places others cannot see.
From childhood's hour until today,
My greatest gift: to disagree

With those who claim imagination
Is something we should leave behind.
For I have found my true salvation
In the boundless reaches of my mind.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
From childhood's hour I have not been
As others were—a dreamer lost
In worlds unseen, where shadows toss
Their whispers to the wind.

I wandered paths with thorns unkind,
While others played in meadows green.
My soul was old before its time,
My eyes had witnessed things unseen.

The stars spoke different words to me,
The moon, a confidant at night,
When darkness wrapped its arms around
And held me in its quiet might.

Perhaps that's why I write these words,
To bridge the gap of loneliness,
To reach across the void of time
And find in verse, some gentleness.

From childhood's hour, apart I stood,
But in this difference, found my voice—
A haunting melody of truth
That makes my fractured heart rejoice.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Acquainted with simplicity.
Instead, complexity has grown
Like ivy on my soul's stone walls.

The games of youth passed me untouched,
My hands too busy holding ghosts,
Collecting shadows, counting stars,
And measuring the space between.

I watched as others learned to laugh
Without the weight of knowing why.
They danced in ignorance so sweet,
While I stood sentinel to time.

The universe unfolded maps
Across my small and trembling palms.
Too much to bear, too much to see,
Too much to understand at once.

And now in age, I long to find
That childhood I was never granted—
To feel the simple joy of being,
Unburdened by the gift of sight.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A creature of conformity.
My spirit wild, my thoughts unchained,
A misfit in humanity.

The clocks tick different in my mind,
The colors shine with sharper hue.
I taste the lightning in the storm
And dance in morning's silver dew.

They tried to mold me, shape my ways,
To fit the patterns they had drawn.
But like a river to the sea,
I flowed where nature called me on.

Sometimes I've wished for simpler thoughts,
For quieter dreams that let me rest.
But then I'd miss the midnight songs
That echo in my restless breast.

So let me be this strange, wild thing,
This child who never learned to bend.
For in my difference lies my strength—
A flame that burns until the end.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A stranger to the dark within.
While others feared the monsters there,
I called them friends and let them in.

My mother worried, father frowned,
At conversations they couldn't hear.
The shadows danced upon my walls
And whispered secrets in my ear.

I learned the language of the night,
The poetry of fallen stars.
Collected pieces of the moon
And kept them in my memory jars.

Perhaps that's why I walk alone,
With one foot here and one beyond.
The veil between the worlds so thin,
I can't help but to respond.

From childhood's hour, set apart,
A traveler between two realms.
Not fully here, not fully there—
A compass with no northern helm.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Content to simply watch the sky.
Instead, I've climbed the tallest trees
To touch the clouds as they passed by.

I've tasted dirt and swallowed stars,
Made friends with creatures of the deep.
Collected stories in my bones
And planted dreams too wild to keep.

The adults called it recklessness,
This hunger for experience.
But how else could I truly know
The world in all its excellence?

Now weathered by the passing years,
My body slows but not my mind.
I still refuse the common path,
Leave safety and restraint behind.

From childhood's hour until now,
I've lived a hundred different lives.
And when at last my time has come,
I'll leave with no regrets, no sighs.

responses.text:

From childhood's hour I have not been

Perhaps in dreams I might return
To innocence I never earned,
But waking finds me still alone,
A child who never was, full grown.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Familiar with the world of men.
Instead, I dwelled in realms apart,
With whispered secrets in my heart.

The trees became my confidants,
The moon, my guide through nighttime haunts.
While others learned their ABCs,
I studied cloud philosophies.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Contained by boundaries or skin.
My soul expanded with the wind,
Beyond what parents could rescind.

And now, though years have come and gone,
That child still wanders on and on—
Still searching skies for something more,
Still knocking on the cosmic door.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Acquainted with simplicity.
Complexity has been my friend,
And doubt, my constant company.

While others played with toys and games,
I questioned why the sky was blue.
While others learned to call their names,
I wondered if their words were true.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Content to merely just exist.
I've always sought what lies within
The shadows that most have dismissed.

Perhaps this curse is also grace—
To see beyond the veil of things,
To find in every empty space
The echo of forgotten wings.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A creature of conformity.
My spirit wild, my thoughts untamed,
I dance with my deformity.

The world insists on perfect lines,
On boxes neatly stacked and square.
Yet I have always colored wide
Beyond the margins they prepare.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Accepted for this heart I bear.
A puzzle piece that won't fit in,
A song that fills unwelcoming air.

But in this difference lies my strength,
In isolation, I found voice.
The path less traveled gave me length
To grow beyond their limited choice.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A keeper of the common time.
My clock ticks slower, faster, when
It wishes, with no reason, rhyme.

I watched the others grow and change
In steady, measured, counted days,
While I existed in a range
Of moments caught in curious ways.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Collecting memories like pearls,
But rather letting them sink in
Like stones that ripple distant worlds.

Perhaps we're all just passing through,
These bodies temporary homes.
But I have always known this truth:
We're more than flesh and blood and bones.

responses.text:

Of my own mind, a prisoner made
Where childhood's colors seemed to fade

From childhood's hour I have not been
Comfortable in my own skin.

I watched the stars when others slept,
Collected dreams while mothers wept,

My hands were small but thoughts were vast,
A future tangled with the past.
The games that pleased the other youth
Could never mask my search for truth.

From childhood's hour I wandered far,
Guided by some distant star.
Not lost, perhaps, but set apart,
With wisdom heavy in my heart.

So do not pity what you see—
This solitude has made me free.
From childhood's hour I have not been
Like you—and that's where I begin.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A follower of beaten paths.
Instead I danced in wild rains,
And counted lightning's aftermath.

The world told stories I'd not heard,

My mother worried, father frowned,

From childhood's hour I have not been

Perhaps this difference marked me strange,

From childhood's hour I have not been

Instead, a wildfire, burning bright,

The world insisted: learn to bend,

But something in my spirit knew

I watched the seasons change their guard,

From childhood's hour I have not been
A mirror of society's face.

So judge me not for paths untrod,

From childhood's hour I have not been
Accepting of the world I see.

I heard the whispers of the trees

I saw the patterns in the stars

My teachers called it daydreaming,

But I was mapping other worlds
Beyond the borders of the day.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Content with simple explanations.
The universe holds mystery
Beyond our mortal limitations.

So if I seem distant at times,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'From childhood's hour I have not been'

responses.text:
From childhood's hour I have not been
As others were—I have not seen
As others saw—I could not bring
My passions from a common spring.

I walked a path of shadows cast,
Where innocence could never last.
My soul, a vessel deep and wide,
Carried waters others denied.

The stars that others wished upon
Were to me ancient worlds long gone.
The laughter shared on summer days
Reached me through a distant haze.

From childhood's hour I stood apart,
A different mind, a different heart.
Not cursed, not blessed, but set aside
To wander where the dreamers hide.

And in this solitude I found
A voice that makes its own sweet sound.
Though childhood's hour has long since passed,
Its echoes through my verses last.

From childhood's hour I have not been
One to follow the beaten path.
I've wandered through the wilderness,
Gathering stories in my grasp.

The clock ticked differently for me,
Seconds stretched like taffy pulled.
Minutes folded into memories,
Hours into lessons culled.

My mother worried, father frowned,
As I collected scattered dreams.
While other children played with toys,
I chased the moon's reflective beams.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Content with simple explanations.
I questioned stars and interrogated clouds,
Seeking cosmic revelations.

Now grown, I find that childhood's gift
Was never truly left behind.
It walks beside me, hand in hand,
A compass for my seeking mind.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Tethered to the world of men.
A spirit wild, untamed and free,
Dancing with eternity.

The games they played seemed dull to me,
When I could touch infinity.
Their nursery rhymes and counting songs,
While I heard universal throngs.

My eyes perceived what others missed—
The veil between worlds, gossamer-kissed.
My hands reached out to phantom things,
My heart soared high on spectral wings.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A daughter of this earthly scene.
Half-here and half in realms unknown,
A seedling from elsewhere wind-blown.

Perhaps one day I'll find my place,
Between the stars in endless space.
Or maybe I am meant to be
A bridge between what few can see.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Acquainted with simplicity.
Complexity has been my friend,
And doubt my constant company.

The playground's joy eluded me,
As did the comfort of belief.
Instead I found philosophy
And questions beyond all relief.

My toys were thoughts, my games were words,
My playmates were the ancient dead.
I soared with Plato's abstract birds
While others kicked a ball instead.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A vessel empty, waiting, pure.
But rather filled with echoes of
The wisdom time cannot obscure.

And though I missed what others had—
That golden age of innocence—
I gained a different kind of wealth:
A mind that bridges difference.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Like willow trees that simply bend.

The river of my youth ran deep,

My mother called me stubborn child,

From childhood's hour I have not been

And now as twilight claims the sky,

Perhaps in this divergent way

From childhood's hour I have not been

The world's sharp edges shaped my skin

I learned too young what others learn
Much later, if they learn at all:

Time moves differently for those
Whose youth was stolen by the night.
We measure days in afterglows,

Yet from these ashes, strange and new,
A different kind of wonder grows—
A wisdom darker, deeper, true;

From childhood's hour I have not been

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

responses.text:
My God, how many are my fears!
They crowd like shadows in the night,
Each one a specter, cold and clear,
That steals away my inner light.

They whisper doubts into my ear,
Of failures past and those to come,
They paint the future bleak and drear,
Till hope lies broken, cold, and numb.

Yet in this darkness, I recall,
That stars shine brightest in the black,
That courage rises when we fall,
And strength is found in what we lack.

So let my fears like mountains stand,
I'll climb their slopes with steady breath,
With trembling heart and outstretched hand,
I'll face what terrifies till death.

For fears, though many, cannot claim
The essence of my soul divine,
They are but shadows without name,
When in Your light, I choose to shine.

My God, how many are my fears!
A legion marching through my mind,
Each footfall echoes, sharp and clear,
No sanctuary can I find.

They wear the faces of my loves,
Of time's swift passage, death's cold hand,
Of failure's sting and loss above
All earthly pain I understand.

These fears, like ravens, peck and claw
At tender hopes I dare not speak,
They find in me each hidden flaw,
And render strong intentions weak.

Yet in this tempest of unrest,
I feel a presence, calm and still,
That whispers through the wild protest
Of doubts that seek my soul to kill.

'Fear not,' it says, 'though darkness reigns,
And terrors circle like the tide,
I walk beside you through these pains,
In me, your fears cannot abide.'

My God, how many are my fears!
Uncountable as desert sands,
They drift in dunes across the years,
And slip like water through my hands.

I fear the silence and the noise,
The empty room, the crowded street,
The loss of grief, the loss of joys,
Both victory sweet and harsh defeat.

I fear the love I cannot keep,
The truth I'm not yet strong to bear,
The promises too rich, too deep,
The answered and unanswered prayer.

Yet fear itself may be a door,
A threshold to a braver place,
Where I might find what lies before
Is neither terror nor disgrace.

But simply life, with all its turns,
Its mysteries and its surprise,
Where wisdom waits and courage learns
To see through fear's deceptive eyes.

My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply like autumn leaves,
Collecting in the gutters of my soul,
Dampening every joy that I perceive.

I fear the dawn that brings new tasks,
I fear the night that brings no rest,
I fear the masks that others wear,
And more, the masks upon my breast.

I fear the words I've left unsaid,
The bridges burned, the chances missed,
The dreams abandoned in their bed,
The lips that never have been kissed.

But what if fear is just a guide,
A lantern showing what I love?
For would I fear to lose the tide
If I cared not for stars above?

Perhaps my fears, so vast and deep,
Are but reflections of my heart,
Revealing treasures that I keep,
Illuminating, not apart.

My God, how many are my fears!
A constellation of anxieties,
Each one burning bright against
The darkness of my certainties.

They come like thieves to steal my peace,
Like winter storms to chill my bones,
Like judges passing harsh decrees
On actions past and seeds unsown.

I fear the changes time will bring,
The constancy of grief and pain,
I fear my voice too weak to sing,
My efforts rendered all in vain.

Yet in this litany of dread,
I find a curious kind of power,
For fears acknowledged can be shed
Like petals from a fading flower.

So let me count these fears as friends,
As teachers showing what I prize,
For in their presence something bends
Toward courage hidden in disguise.
