prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text:
THE SERPENT'S WHISPER

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Of innocence surrendered to temptation's spell.
Scales gleaming in Eden's perfect light,
Forked tongue promising wisdom's delight.

One bite—the universe forever changed,
Knowledge and mortality strangely exchanged.
Red flesh revealing secrets never meant to know,
Seeds of doubt that would eternally grow.

We are all gardens waiting for rain,
All trees bearing fruit of pleasure and pain.
The serpent still whispers in modern ears,
Offering answers to our deepest fears.

What forbidden knowledge do we seek today?
What paradise are we willing to pay?
The snake and the apple, ancient as time,
Echo in every decision, every climb.

Perhaps the sorriest part of this tale
Is how we repeat it, without fail.

FALLEN FRUIT

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
A narrative of knowledge where innocence fell.
Coiled around branches in dappled light,
The tempter's eyes glowing, hypnotic and bright.

We blame the serpent, we blame the tree,
We blame the woman who dared to see
Beyond the garden's protective wall
Into the vastness that awaited us all.

But what if the apple was freedom's first taste?
What if the garden was simply a waste
Of human potential, of questions unasked,
Of curiosity eternally masked?

Perhaps the serpent was wisdom in disguise,
Offering truth instead of comfortable lies.
The sorry tale might not be the fall from grace,
But the centuries spent trying to erase

Our hunger for knowledge, our thirst to know why—
To reach for the fruit that hangs in the sky.
The snake and the apple, eternally twined,
Remind us that growth and pain are aligned.

EDEN'S ECHO

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
A whispered warning that through ages dwell.
In paradise lost among emerald leaves,
A slithering question that silently weaves.

The fruit's skin blushing with secrets untold,
More precious than gardens of silver and gold.
One choice, one moment, one fateful bite—
Dividing forever the darkness from light.

We carry this story in our very bones,
In choices we make when we think we're alone.
The serpent still offers what seems to be more,
While standing between us and some sacred shore.

I too have tasted forbidden delight,
Have welcomed the knowledge that comes with the night.
I too have been banished from innocent days,
Left wandering through life's complicated maze.

Yet in this exile, this world of sweat and tears,
I've found deeper beauty through passing years.
The snake and the apple, that sorry refrain,
Reminds us that wisdom is daughter to pain.

ORIGINAL SIN

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Of paradise corrupted under temptation's spell.
Scaled deceiver with eyes like ancient stone,
Offering knowledge better left unknown.

The crimson fruit, so innocent in form,
Harbored power to create a storm
That would rage through human history,
A legacy of shame and mystery.

We've painted serpents villains ever since,
Made apples symbols that make us wince.
Yet daily we repeat that first mistake—
Reaching for what we should not take.

The hunger for the thing forbidden calls
With promises that pleasure never stalls.
But in each bite of what we shouldn't taste,
We find the sweetness quickly turns to waste.

So here we stand outside the garden gate,
With knowledge heavy, wisdom come too late.
The snake and the apple continue still
To test our strength and bend our will.

BEYOND THE GARDEN

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
But listen closely—there's more I must unveil.
Beyond the simple morals we've been taught,
Lies deeper truth that rarely gets caught.

A serpent coiled 'round the tree of life,
Offered not just conflict, not just strife,
But possibility—the chance to grow
Beyond the boundaries we've come to know.

The apple's flesh, so crimson and sweet,
Contained the questions we all must meet:
Who are we beyond what we've been told?
What mysteries might consciousness unfold?

Perhaps the sorrow in this ancient tale
Is not that innocence was set to fail,
But that we've misunderstood the gift—
The painful, necessary, sacred shift

From blissful ignorance to aware,
From mindless happiness to souls laid bare.
The snake and apple, eternally entwined,
Mark where humanity was redefined.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text:
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the dust devils dance and the sun knows no rest,
A weathered old homestead stands silent and bare,
With windows like eyes that just vacantly stare.

The windmill creaks slowly, a metallic refrain,
As it waits for the blessing of life-giving rain.
Fence posts stand like sentries around barren fields,
Where the hard-scrabble earth gives such miserly yields.

A man sits on his porch as the day fades to night,
His face deeply etched by the harsh desert light.
His hands tell a story of decades of toil,
Of a lifetime of battling the sun and the soil.

Yet his eyes hold a gleam of a stubborn desire,
A spirit unbroken, a slow-burning fire.
For this land is his canvas, his burden, his home,
This lonely selection where wild creatures roam.

Under vast starlit skies, he finds solace and peace,
A freedom untethered that will never cease.
On this lonely selection far out in the West,
He has found what he sought - his own place to rest.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the eucalypts whisper and magpies nest,
A woman stands gazing at crimson-stained skies,
The vastness of country reflected in her eyes.

The paddocks stretch endless, the soil cracked and dry,
She remembers the rains that once fell from on high.
Generations before her have weathered these lands,
Their legacies etched in her calloused hands.

The sheep bleat their chorus as twilight descends,
A boundary rider returns as his long day ends.
The homestead lights flicker, a beacon of home,
A sanctuary fixed while the wild dingoes roam.

She carries the weight of decisions unmade,
As drought grips the land and the green begins to fade.
Yet somewhere deep in her, resilience grows,
Like the hardy wildflowers that somehow still show.

On this lonely selection far out in the West,
She finds in its harshness a strange kind of rest.
For the land may be cruel, and the seasons unkind,
But it's here in this vastness she's freed her mind.

ON THE EDGE OF NOWHERE

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the horizon embraces the sky's golden crest,
I planted my dreams in this unforgiving soil,
Each seed watered daily with sweat from my toil.

The crows mark my progress with skeptical calls,
As I build with bare hands these humble stone walls.
My nearest neighbor, ten long miles away,
Leaves only myself to greet each breaking day.

The fierce summer heat bends the air into waves,
While winter winds howl like lost souls from their graves.
Yet between these extremes lies a beauty so pure,
A rugged perfection that makes my heart sure.

The night brings a blanket of stars overhead,
More numerous than thoughts in a wanderer's head.
They witness my solitude, silent and bright,
Companions that guide me through each lonely night.

Some call it madness to live so removed,
From comforts of cities and paths well-approved.
But here on my selection, far out in the West,
I've found that my spirit has finally found rest.

DUST AND DREAMS

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where red earth meets blue sky in silent unrest,
A single roof rises from sparse, stubborn land,
A defiant small kingdom built by human hand.

The cockatoos scatter at first light of dawn,
Screaming white prophecies over yellowing lawn.
The water tank's shadow grows short with the day,
As merciless sun burns all mercy away.

Inside the tin cottage, faded photos remain,
Of ancestors who prayed for the gift of the rain.
Generation by generation, they worked without yield,
Their hopes buried deep in each unproductive field.

Yet beauty emerges in unexpected ways—
Wildflowers erupting after long-awaited days
Of rainfall that transforms the parched, cracking plain
Into carpets of color that won't last, but remain

Etched in memory when drought returns once more,
As it always has done in the cycles before.
On this lonely selection far out in the West,
The harshest of lands puts the strongest to test.

And I, just a traveler passing through space,
Find myself humbled by this unyielding place.

THE SELECTOR'S LEGACY

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the galahs and the sunset share hues of the best,
Stands a homestead of timber, corrugated and worn,
Its verandah still facing the land where I'm born.

My grandfather's hands raised these walls from the earth,
My grandmother's garden gave beauty its birth.
Through droughts and through flooding, through fire and through frost,
They clung to this patch when all hope seemed lost.

The windbreak of gum trees now tower so high,
Their shadows stretch long as the emus pass by.
The dam in the gully holds secrets and time,
Reflecting the stars when the night is sublime.

I walk these same paddocks my ancestors knew,
My boots raising dust just as theirs used to do.
The sheep tracks and cattle pads crisscross the hills,
Where kookaburras laugh and the butcherbird trills.

Some nights when the quiet wraps 'round like a shawl,
I swear I can hear their voices still call.
On this lonely selection far out in the West,
Their spirit remains, putting me to the test.

For I am the keeper of all they have built,
This harsh, loving country, this blessing, this gilt.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
Everyone Has a Fear

Everyone has a fear, a shadow that follows,
Silent as midnight, deep as forgotten hollows.
Some fear the darkness that swallows the light,
Others the heights that make their souls take flight.

Fears like spiders that crawl across skin,
Or oceans so vast where swimming grows thin.
Fears of rejection when hearts are laid bare,
Or the crushing silence when no one is there.

Yet in these fears, we find common ground,
In vulnerability, humanity is profoundly found.
For what makes us tremble also makes us brave,
When we face what haunts us, refusing to cave.

So wear your fear like armor, not chains,
Acknowledge its presence, but don't let it reign.
For everyone has a fear—this truth binds us all—
It's how we rise after fear makes us fall.

The Universal Shadow

Everyone has a fear that whispers at night,
A personal demon, refusing to take flight.
Mine lurks in corners where memories fade,
Yours might be storms or decisions unmade.

The businessman fears his empire's collapse,
The artist dreads the moment inspiration laps.
Children fear monsters with teeth sharp and long,
Elders fear leaving with too much unsaid, undone.

Fear is democracy's truest expression,
No wealth can purchase complete exemption.
It binds the beggar to the queen on her throne,
This shared inheritance we've always known.

Some fears are rational, some purely mad,
Some inherited from the lives we've had.
But in acknowledging this common thread,
We find connection in the things we dread.

So when your fear grips with merciless hands,
Remember you're not alone where you stand.

Whispers of Dread

Everyone has a fear, a trembling inside,
A quickened heartbeat impossible to hide.
The soldier fears not death but dying alone,
The writer fears a story forever unknown.

Everyone has a fear that shapes their days,
Guiding their footsteps in invisible ways.
The dancer fears the moment her body betrays,
The lover fears the words his heart never says.

Fears like fingerprints, uniquely our own,
Yet in this garden of dread, we're never alone.
The powerful fear losing their careful control,
The faithful fear questions that challenge their soul.

We carry these burdens through each waking hour,
Some like seeds, others blooming full flower.
But fears, when faced, often shrink in the light,
Revealing their shadows aren't infinite in might.

So acknowledge your fears, give them their due name,
For everyone carries this flickering flame.

The Equalizer

Everyone has a fear—the great equalizer,
Rich man, poor man, fool or the wiser.
It creeps through defenses we carefully build,
Leaving confident voices suddenly stilled.

The mother fears harm to her innocent child,
The climber fears falling when mountains grow wild.
The scholar fears finding his knowledge was wrong,
The singer fears losing the notes to her song.

Fears don't discriminate, choose, or select,
They find all our hearts, demand our respect.
Some fears are ancient as humanity's dawn,
Others newly birthed when safety is gone.

But what if our fears are not chains but guides?
Teaching caution when danger truly resides?
Perhaps in our trembling, wisdom can grow,
As we learn which winds truly threaten to blow.

So stand with your fear, acknowledge its voice,
But remember always: brave action's your choice.

Shared Shadows

Everyone has a fear that follows like breath,
From first infant cries to the whispers of death.
Some are born screaming of thunder and noise,
Others develop as life steals our joys.

The doctor fears failing when lives hang in balance,
The judge fears injustice despite all her talents.
The father fears proving inadequate, small,
The daughter fears never measuring up at all.

Fear is the shadow we cannot outrun,
The price that we pay for living under the sun.
It teaches survival, keeps senses alert,
Though sometimes it blinds us to joy and diverts.

In darkest of moments when fear grips your throat,
Remember this truth, this comforting note:
No soul walks this earth completely immune,
To the tremble of fear under sun or full moon.

So reach out your hand when someone stands scared,
In our vulnerable moments, humanity's bared.

THE UNIVERSAL TREMOR

Everyone Has a Fear

Everyone has a fear that whispers at night,
A shadow that follows when there is no light.
Some dread the darkness, some fear the height,
Others tremble at spiders or take sudden flight.

Everyone has a fear they try to conceal,
Buried beneath smiles, refusing to reveal.
The businessman in his suit, the dancer on stage,
The writer with her pen, the sage in old age.

Everyone has a fear that shapes who they are,
Guiding decisions, both near and far.
It builds our walls and draws our lines,
It's the caution in our steps, the warning signs.

Yet everyone has a fear they can learn to face,
With trembling hands and quickened pace.
For in confronting what makes us weak,
We find the strength and courage we seek.

The Universal Shadow

Everyone has a fear, a private haunting,
Some ancient dread, persistent and daunting.
It hides in closets, beneath beds, behind eyes,
Wrapped in silence, disguised in lies.

The soldier fears not death but being forgotten,
The artist dreads a canvas left barren, misbegotten.
The lover fears abandonment's cruel sting,
The singer, the moment their voice cannot sing.

Everyone has a fear—it binds humanity tight,
A shared inheritance, our common plight.
In boardrooms and schoolyards, hospitals and homes,
This shadow companion wherever one roams.

Perhaps in this sharing we find common ground,
In vulnerability's echo, connection is found.
For everyone has a fear they carry inside,
A truth universal, no matter how we hide.

Whispers of Dread

Everyone has a fear, a trembling within,
A crack in the armor that shields our skin.
It crawls through dreams like morning frost,
Reminds us of battles already lost.

The child fears monsters with gleaming teeth,
The adult, the monsters that lurk beneath
Smiles and handshakes, contracts and vows—
The unsaid things time never allows.

Everyone has a fear, like fingerprints unique,
Yet universal in how it makes us weak.
The wealthy man fears poverty's return,
The loveless heart fears passion's burn.

But fears are teachers in disguise,
Revealing truths we'd otherwise despise.
They show us edges we dare not cross,
And sometimes, what we can afford to loss.

So carry your fear like a secret map,
A guide to places where your soul might snap.
For everyone has a fear—this much is true—
But courage isn't fearlessness, it's what you do.

The Equalizer

Everyone has a fear, it waits like patience stone,
A whispered truth, in marrow and bone.
The general commanding armies vast
Still flinches at shadows his childhood cast.

Everyone has a fear, the beggar and queen,
The spaces between what is heard and seen.
Some fear the thunder, some the quiet room,
Some fear blossoming, others fear the bloom.

The mountains that tower, ancient and tall,
Fear the persistence of raindrops that fall.
The ocean so mighty, boundless and deep,
Fears the shore that determines where it can reach.

Everyone has a fear—it's how we know we're alive,
The price of consciousness, the cost to survive.
Not a weakness to conquer or shame to hide,
But the tender proof that we haven't died inside.

So wear your fear like a badge, not a chain,
The beautiful evidence of joy, of loss, of pain.
For in this one truth, we are forever the same:
Everyone has a fear they cannot tame.

Shared Shadows

Everyone has a fear that follows like breath,
Some fear abandonment, others fear death.
Some fear the darkness when day turns to night,
Others fear speaking their truth outright.

The child who seems fearless climbing trees,
Still dreads the monsters carried by the breeze.
The CEO in her tower of glass and steel,
Fears the moment her weakness might reveal.

Everyone has a fear—it binds us as one,
The thread through humanity that cannot be undone.
From ancient cave-dwellers watching for beasts,
To modern souls fearing as connection decreases.

Perhaps our fears are not walls but bridges instead,
Connecting our hearts through the words left unsaid.
In acknowledging fear, we find common space,
A shared vulnerability, a collective embrace.

So when next you tremble, remember this thought:
You're not alone in the battles you've fought.
Everyone has a fear they're trying to bear,
A universal burden we're all meant to share.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
Everyone Has a Fear

Everyone has a fear that whispers in the night,
A shadow lurking just beyond the light.
Some fear the darkness, some the breaking dawn,
Some fear the path where certainty has gone.

I've seen brave soldiers tremble at a spider's crawl,
And fearless climbers who can't face a crowded hall.
The CEO who commands with iron will
Might dread the silence when the world stands still.

Fears are the ghosts of wounds we've earned,
Or warnings of flames where others burned.
They're ancient guardians from tribal days,
When danger lurked in a thousand ways.

So when you meet someone standing tall,
Remember they too have fears that call.
For courage isn't the absence of fright,
But facing your demons in the fading light.

The Universal Shadow

Everyone has a fear, a private haunting,
A specter that follows, forever taunting.
Some carry theirs like a stone in their shoe,
Others build fortresses, massive and true.

Mine lives in the spaces between my breaths,
In almost-phone calls and near-certain deaths.
It wears the face of those I've loved and lost,
And calculates carefully what each choice cost.

Yours might roar like thunder or whisper like rain,
It might taste like metal or feel like pain.
It might keep you running or hold you in place,
Or hide behind smiles on your everyday face.

We're all just travelers carrying these weights,
Some fears we conquer, some fears we create.
But in our shared trembling, perhaps we might find
The comfort of knowing we're one of a kind.

Phobia's Garden

Everyone has a fear planted deep in their soul,
A seed watered by trauma, experience, or lore.
Mine blooms like nightshade when thunder cracks the sky,
Yours may flourish in crowds where strangers brush by.

Some fears grow like ivy, creeping slow through the years,
Wrapping around achievements, relationships, careers.
Others burst like sunflowers after one terrible day,
Sudden and towering, impossible to sway.

We tend to these gardens with rituals and rules,
Avoidance and worry our well-worn tools.
We build fences of reason to keep them contained,
Yet somehow they flourish, wild and untamed.

But what if these fears, so carefully grown,
Are simply the shadows of strengths we've never known?
Perhaps in the soil where our deepest fears reside,
Lies courage and wisdom waiting just inside.

The Equalizer

Everyone has a fear, this much I know is true,
A secret vulnerability shared by me and you.
The CEO in her tower, the vagrant on the street,
Each harbors a terror they desperately seek to beat.

Fear is democracy's purest form,
It cares not for shelter, status, or being warm.
It finds the crack in every human heart,
And through this fissure, makes its art.

I've seen the bravest firefighter flinch
At the dentist's drill, not giving an inch.
I've watched scholars of tremendous brain
Panic at heights with unmasked pain.

Perhaps our fears are not our weakness after all,
But reminders of our humanity, however small.
For in our trembling, our sweating, our desperate plea,
Lies the truth that binds us—our shared humanity.

Mirrors of Dread

Everyone has a fear that follows like a ghost,
A personal demon that knows them the most.
It wears different masks from person to person,
Some fears lighten with age, while others worsen.

The child fears monsters beneath the bed,
The mother fears futures that fill her with dread.
The old man fears time's relentless race,
The young woman fears being put in her place.

We hide them in laughter, in work, in drink,
Push them down deeper than we dare to think.
But fears are just mirrors reflecting parts
Of the human condition we hold in our hearts.

So when next your fear grips you tight in the night,
Remember you're not alone in your fright.
For everyone trembles at something unseen—
It's the price that we pay for daring to dream.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

responses.text:
Celestial Ignition

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
As metal dragons roar and climb,
Breaking free from earthly chains,
Piercing through the veil of time.

A symphony of flame and steel,
Dancing upward, fierce and bright,
Leaving trails of human dreams
Etched across the canvas night.

Stars bear witness to our reach,
Ancient eyes that watch and wait,
As we send our hopes aloft
Challenging the hand of fate.

Embers drift like newborn stars,
Whispering tales of what might be,
When we've crossed the final void
And sailed the cosmic sea.

So fire up the sky, brave souls,
With rocket sparks and burning will.
For in each launch, we touch the gods,
And make our mortal hearts stand still.

Ignition Point

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Watch chemistry defy the dark,
As fuel and flame conspire to rise
Beyond the reach of mortal eyes.

Each blazing trail, a human mark
Upon the void, a question mark
That asks if we were meant to stay
Or scatter seeds across the way.

The children point with open mouths,
Their faces lit by burning routes,
Their futures written in the glow
Of paths they may someday come to know.

The earth below grows small and blue,
A marble spinning, old yet new,
While calculations, dreams, and art
Propel us from our humble start.

So fire up the sky tonight!
And in that momentary light,
Feel centuries of wonder burst
As we, the star-born, quench our thirst.

Ascension

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Illuminate the midnight hour.
Human ingenuity takes flight,
A testament to will and power.

The countdown echoes in our bones,
A heartbeat shared across the land.
Three... two... one... ignition blooms
As dreams escape from gravity's hand.

Oxygen embraces kerosene
In passionate, explosive kiss.
Thrust defies our earthly bonds,
Propelling us toward cosmic bliss.

We were not born with wings or gills,
Yet swim through stars and soar through space.
Metal carapace and burning core,
Our substitute for nature's grace.

In rocket trails we write our names
Across the universe's face.
Each launch a prayer, a question mark,
A seed of hope cast into space.

So fire up the sky again!
With sparks that challenge heaven's gate.
For in our quest to touch the stars,
We glimpse what might be human fate.

Prometheus Unbound

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Steal flame once more from jealous gods.
Not content with earthly bounds,
We break the ancient, cosmic odds.

Combustion's child, the rocket leaps
On pillars forged of science and math,
A calculated rebellion
Against our predetermined path.

The ground trembles, releases grip
As metal phoenix starts to climb.
The air splits open, wounded deep
By human will sublime.

Consider how the stars must feel
To see us rising toward their light,
Their distant kin returning home
On wings of chemical might.

The sparks that trail behind our reach
Are breadcrumbs leading others up,
A constellation born of need,
Ambition's overflowing cup.

So fire the rockets, launch the dreams,
Ignite the darkness, claim the void.
For in each spark that climbs the sky,
Our cosmic purpose is deployed.

Skyward Alchemy

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Transmute the night to burning day.
Chemistry and courage blend
To forge our interstellar way.

The launchpad hums with potential,
A modern altar to our quest.
Engines growl like hungry beasts,
Impatient for their fiery test.

We gather round with upturned eyes,
Inheritors of ancient drive
That pushed us from primordial pools
To shores where dreams of stars arrive.

Each launch a revolution makes,
A turning point in human tale.
The rocket's path—a sentence writ
In flame across the cosmic veil.

The children watching will remember
This moment when the heavens burned,
When boundaries between earth and space
Were briefly, brilliantly overturned.

So fire up the sky once more!
With rocket sparks and human art.
For in that blaze we glimpse ourselves—
Both what we are and might yet start.

Who learned to package lightning's power,
Converting danger into thrust,
To climb beyond our earthly tower.

Each launch a rebellion against
The gravity that held us down.
Each spark a tiny evidence
That we were never meant for ground.

So watch them rise on pillars bright,
Those monuments to human flight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My refuge when storms assail,
The lighthouse when darkness falls,
The whisper in the gale.

When shadows stretch across my path,
And doubt clouds my weary mind,
You are the flame that never dims,
The truth I seek to find.

In valleys low or mountains high,
Your presence never wanes,
The constant in my changing world,
The balm for all my pains.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other shall I seek,
For in Your arms I find the strength
That lifts me when I'm weak.

Through desert lands and flowing streams,
Through joy and bitter tears,
You are the compass of my soul,
The anchor through the years.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other name I call.
In cosmic dust and starlit space,
I hear Your gentle thrall.

The universe expands in You,
Each atom bears Your trace.
In quantum leaps and gravity,
I glimpse Your hidden face.

Science and faith, not foes but friends,
Two paths to truth divine.
Reason illuminates Your works,
Where wonder and awe combine.

When questions rise like morning mist,
And doubt seems to prevail,
You meet me in the mystery,
Beyond the thinning veil.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Transcendent yet so near.
In equations and in poetry,
Your whispers I can hear.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Amid this fractured world,
Where nations clash and hatred burns,
Your peace remains unfurled.

In refugee camps and battle lines,
In hospitals of pain,
You walk unseen but ever-felt,
Where human hopes remain.

The child who cries, the mother's tears,
The soldier's final breath,
You hold them all in tender hands
Beyond the reach of death.

When justice seems a distant dream,
And mercy hard to find,
You plant the seeds of love and truth
Within the human mind.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
In this divided earth,
The healer of our broken hearts,
The source of second birth.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not carved from stone or tree,
Not bound by temple walls or books,
But dwelling deep in me.

I sought You in the sacred texts,
In rituals old and new,
But found You in the silent space
Where truth comes shining through.

No doctrine can contain Your grace,
No creed Your love define,
For You are more than human words
Can capture or confine.

In every faith that seeks the good,
In hearts that love and care,
Beyond all names and forms and thoughts,
Your presence lingers there.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Yet shared by all who see
That boundaries between souls dissolve
In Your infinity.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Through seasons of my life,
In childhood's dawn, in youth's bright noon,
In age with wisdom rife.

When first I walked on trembling legs,
You steadied every stride.
When passion led to foolish paths,
You gently turned the tide.

In middle years of work and strain,
When burdens weighed me down,
You taught me how to carry loads
Without complaint or frown.

Now as the twilight softly falls,
And silver streaks my hair,
I see Your hand in all my days,
Your purpose everywhere.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Through time's relentless flow,
The author of my story's arc,
Beginning, middle, close.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My refuge in the darkest night,
When shadows creep and fears are sown,
You stand as my unfailing light.

In valleys deep where echoes fade,
And mountains high where winds prevail,
Your presence is my accolade,
A love that time cannot curtail.

I seek You in the morning dew,
In sunset's glow and starry skies,
In every breath, Your grace anew,
Beyond where mortal vision lies.

My soul thirsts for Your living stream,
A desert wanderer seeking rest,
Your mercy more than I could dream,
In Your embrace, I'm truly blessed.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My beginning and my end,
The cornerstone, the sacred stone,
My maker, savior, and true friend.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other name my heart shall claim.
Through windswept valleys I have known,
Your whisper calls me by my name.

The universe bows at Your feet,
Yet You bend low to hear my prayer.
In solitude, our souls can meet,
Your presence found most deeply there.

When midnight doubts like shadows loom,
And questions echo without end,
You pierce the darkness of my room,
Not just Creator—but my friend.

I've wandered far on pathways steep,
Sought comfort in what cannot last.
Yet still Your love runs wild and deep,
Forgetting all my troubled past.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
The anchor when my ship is tossed,
The shepherd when I've furthest roamed,
The finder of what I thought lost.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No earthly treasure compares to Thee.
In life's vast desert, parched and blown,
You are the spring I long to see.

When dawn breaks golden on the hills,
I feel Your breath in morning air.
When twilight all the valley fills,
I know Your hand has placed me there.

The world may offer fleeting joys,
And tempt with pleasures soon to fade.
But You provide what time destroys—
A love no shadow can invade.

In silence when no words will come,
You read the language of my heart.
When grief has left me cold and numb,
You warm the spaces torn apart.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My first love and my final rest.
The seed from which my hope has grown,
The answer to my soul's request.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No idol shares Your sacred throne.
Through tempests wild and waters deep,
Your faithful watch You ever keep.

I've chased the hollow things of earth,
And found them empty, void of worth.
Like mist that vanishes by noon,
They promise much, but perish soon.

Yet You remain when all has passed,
Eternal, boundless, unsurpassed.
The Alpha and Omega too,
Beginning, end—forever true.

My soul finds shelter in Your name,
When praise flows free or in my shame.
You meet me in my darkest night,
And guide me toward Your perfect light.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My heart is Yours, Your will my own.
Though kingdoms fall and stars grow dim,
I'll raise forever my soul's hymn.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not distant star nor cosmic force,
But intimate as breath in bone,
My journey's end, my journey's source.

When chaos claims the frantic day,
And noise drowns out my silent plea,
You carve within my heart a way
To find myself by finding Thee.

The world's religions seek Your face
Through different names and ancient rites.
Yet I have known Your strange embrace
In ordinary days and nights.

You dwell beyond what words can tell,
Yet closer than my very skin.
In sacred heights where angels dwell,
And depths where doubts and fears begin.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Mysteries I cannot comprehend.
Yet in this truth my faith has grown:
You walk beside me to the end.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My refuge in life's tempest wild,
When shadows lengthen, light has flown,
You claim me still as cherished child.

In silent valleys, mountain heights,
Through desert wastes and verdant plains,
Your presence fills my days and nights,
Your mercy like the gentle rains.

When doubt encroaches on my soul,
And fear its tendrils tight entwines,
You make the broken spirit whole,
Your love the balm that realigns.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No earthly treasure holds such worth,
No kingdom, power, or lofty throne
Can match your gift of second birth.

So let me walk in humble grace,
My heart attuned to your design,
Until at last I see your face,
And know completely I am thine.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not fashioned from the dust of stars,
Nor conjured by my thoughts full-grown,
But ancient beyond time's far bars.

When morning breaks the eastern sky,
I seek Thee like the thirsty land,
My soul, a vessel running dry,
Awaiteth filling from Thy hand.

The world offers its tarnished gold,
Its fleeting pleasures, hollow fame,
But Thou—the treasure I shall hold
When all else fades to ash and name.

In darkness deep as midnight's core,
Thy light remains my guiding flame,
The lamp that shows the hidden door
When doubt and fear would stake their claim.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My beginning and my final rest,
The cornerstone, the keystone known,
The answer to my soul's long quest.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other can thy place assume.
When twilight shadows stretch and groan,
You fill with light the gathering gloom.

Like desert travelers parched and worn,
My spirit thirsts for living streams.
In barren places, dry, forlorn,
Your presence satisfies my dreams.

The world's cacophony grows loud,
Its siren songs entice and call.
Yet in the silence, disavowed
Of earthly clamor, I recall:

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not carved from wood nor hewn from stone,
Not distant on celestial throne,
But dwelling in this heart of bone.

So let me walk this pilgrim way,
With eyes fixed firm on things above,
Until the dawn of endless day
Reveals the fullness of thy love.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Beneath the vast expanse of sky,
Amidst the cosmos' endless moan,
You hear each whispered prayer and sigh.

When mountains crumble into dust,
And oceans drain like morning dew,
In You alone I place my trust,
My compass needle pointing true.

Not in the temple's hallowed halls,
Nor sacred texts of ancient lore,
But in the heart where spirit calls,
I find You knocking at the door.

Through winter's grip and summer's blaze,
Through autumn's gold and spring's rebirth,
You guide my steps through tangled ways,
My anchor in this shifting earth.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No idol shares Your holy place.
Your mercy-seed in me is sown,
Eternity within Your grace.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
A truth etched deep within my soul.
Not one among the many known,
But He who makes the broken whole.

In midnight hours when terrors creep,
And shadows dance on bedroom walls,
Your watchful eye does never sleep,
Your ear attentive to my calls.

The universe, Your canvas vast,
With galaxies like scattered gems,
Yet You attend the least, the last,
The wilting flowers on broken stems.

When pride would build its tower high,
And self would claim the central throne,
Your gentle whisper draws my eye:
"Remember, I am God alone."

So let me walk in humble awe,
Not grasping tight to worldly things,
But finding in Your perfect law
The freedom that surrender brings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My rock, my refuge, and my shield.
When darkness falls and I feel prone
To doubt the grace that Thou dost yield.

In valleys deep where shadows loom,
Thy presence never leaves my side.
Like morning light dispelling gloom,
In Thee my trembling heart confides.

When oceans rise and tempests blow,
When mountains crumble to the sea,
Thy steadfast love helps me to know
That I am Thine eternally.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No earthly treasure compares to Thee.
Upon my heart Thy name is sewn,
My soul finds rest in Thy decree.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other power shall I seek.
Through barren lands and paths unknown,
Thy voice—the only one I speak.

The world offers its hollow gold,
Its fleeting pleasures, fading fast.
But in Thy presence, wealth untold
Awakens joy designed to last.

When evening shadows cloak the sky,
And silence wraps around my soul,
I feel Thy spirit drawing nigh,
Making my broken spirit whole.

Thy love—a vast uncharted sea,
Thy mercy—deeper than the grave.
O God! Thou art my God alone;
The only one with power to save.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not distant star nor cosmic force,
But intimate as breath in bone,
My journey's end, my journey's source.

In wilderness I wander far,
Parched lips that thirst for living streams.
Yet even there, where scorpions are,
You meet me in my waking dreams.

What masterpiece could I create
To honor all You've done for me?
What anthem could articulate
The boundless love I cannot see?

So here I stand with empty hands,
No offering but this frail heart.
O God! Thou art my God alone;
Complete in me what You did start.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Beneath the weight of starry skies,
I stand before Thy mighty throne,
Where human wisdom quickly dies.

The universe, Thy canvas vast,
Where galaxies like dust are strewn.
Yet Thou dost see me, unsurpassed
In care for one so small, so soon
To pass like shadows in the noon.

What mystery that Thou shouldst care
For creatures forged from common clay,
That Thou wouldst listen to my prayer
Amid the cosmos' grand display!

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Infinite, yet intimately known.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
When morning breaks with golden light,
When evening falls and day has flown,
In darkness deep as well as bright.

Not in the temples made by hands,
Nor sacred books with gilded edge,
But in the heart's most barren lands
I find Thee true to every pledge.

The world may offer crowns of fame,
And wealth may tempt with promises,
But these are shadows without name
Compared to what Thy love gives.

So let me walk this pilgrim way,
A traveler bound for heaven's throne.
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My all, my breath, my cornerstone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:

O God! Thou art my God alone;

O God! Thou art my God alone;

I find within Your sacred powers

The world may offer fleeting gold,

But I have felt Your hand to hold

My spirit, like a compass true,

Each breath becomes a prayer to You,
Each moment, sacred, never still.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
The author of my deepest song,
The cornerstone, the precious stone,
To You, and You alone, I belong.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not distant star nor phantom dream,
But present in my flesh and bone,
In every tear, in every stream.

When doubt creeps in like morning fog,
And faith seems but a childish tale,
You meet me in my dialogue
Of questions where my courage fails.

I've sought You in cathedral walls,
In scripture's ancient, hallowed lines,
In mountaintop where eagle calls,
In ocean depths where pearl reclines.

Yet found You closest in the space
Between my heartbeats' steady drum,
The quiet pause, that breathless place
Where words dissolve and You become.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not mine to own but to receive,
A mystery partly known, partly shown,

O God! Thou art my God alone;

I wander through this wilderness,

The world proclaims a thousand gods,

But these are shadows, wispy smoke,

O God! Thou art my God alone;

O God! Thou art my God alone;

responses.text:

O God! Thou art my God alone;

O God! Thou art my God alone;

When I am broken, lost, undone,

O God! Thou art my God alone;

O God! Thou art my God alone;
