Becomes the familiar landscape
Of tomorrow's mundane existence—
Until we hunger once again
For that delicious, terrifying new.

HAIR-RAISING NOVELTY

In the carnival of existence
where the ordinary slouches,
a hair-raising novelty emerges—
untamed, electric, alive.

It stands on end like questions
we dare not ask in polite company,
or thoughts that visit at 3 a.m.,
when the world has turned its back.

This novelty—half wonder, half terror—
dances along nerve endings,
speaking in tongues of goosebumps,
translating fear to exhilaration.

We are drawn to its dangerous edge
like moths to incandescence,
seeking the shock of the new
to remember we are still breathing.

So let your hair rise to meet it,
this strange and beautiful disturbance.
Embracing the uncomfortable thrill
is how we know we haven't yet
turned to stone.

THE UNEXPECTED JOLT

Hair-raising novelty;
A current through the mundane,
Static electricity dancing
Across the skin of routine.

Yesterday's impossibilities
Become today's fascinations—
The first telephone call,
The maiden flight,
The quantum leap.

We stand at attention,
Pores open, follicles lifted,
Biological antennae tuned
To frequencies of the unprecedented.

Fear and wonder,
Twin children of innovation,
Hold hands as we witness
The birth of what we never
Imagined possible.

In this moment of raised hair,
Before acceptance dulls the edge,
We are fully alive—
Awake to the universe's
Endless capacity to surprise
And our own astonishing ability
To be astonished still.

Hair-raising novelty;
The shock of the new
Crawls across my scalp
Like electricity seeking ground.

I remember when first kisses
Were such novelties—
How my body turned to lightning,
How the world stood still and trembled.

Now I hunt for that sensation
In strange cities, forbidden books,
Conversations that venture
Beyond the walls of propriety.

The familiar is a drug that numbs;
The strange awakens nerves
I forgot I possessed.

So I chase hair-raising novelty
Down alleys of the unexpected,
Pursuing that primitive response
That reminds me I am animal still—
Alive to danger, alive to wonder,
Alive to the magnificent terror
Of encountering what I do not know.

PRIMAL ALERT

Hair-raising novelty;
Ancient warning system
Built into flesh and follicle—
The body's first response
To what it cannot categorize.

Our ancestors felt it
Facing predators in tall grass.
We feel it now before screens,
Watching the world reshape itself
Faster than evolution prepared us for.

The unfamiliar activates
What civilization cannot tame—
That delicious terror
Of standing at the edge
Of what we know.

Perhaps wisdom lives
In these raised hairs,
These goosebumped arms,
This quickened pulse—

A reminder that beneath
Our cultivated certainties,
We remain gloriously wild,
Forever strangers
To what comes next.

whatever might fall from possibility's tree.

Some days I am brave enough
to abandon comfort's cradle,
to seek the unfamiliar road,
to taste peculiar flavors on my tongue.

Other days I hide beneath
the blanket of the known,
afraid of what might lurk
beyond predictability's borders.

But life insists on change—
it whispers: come, explore
the edges of your map.

Hair-raising novelty;
terrifying gift,
the price we pay for growth,
the shock that keeps the heart
beating against the numbing drum
of sameness.

THE EXHIBITION

Hair-raising novelty;
like walking through a haunted gallery
where the paintings shift
when you turn your back.

I've become a collector
of strange experiences,
hoarding them in memory's cluttered attic—
the taste of sea urchin,
the sound of throat singers,
the vertigo of loving someone new.

How quickly the strange becomes familiar,
domesticated by repetition.
Yesterday's marvel
is tomorrow's mundane.

So we hunt for it,
this hair-raising novelty;
chasing the high of encountering
something our minds haven't yet
categorized and filed away.

Perhaps wonder is just
another word for confusion,
and awe simply the mind
struggling to comprehend
what it hasn't seen before.

FIRST ENCOUNTERS

Hair-raising novelty;
like touching an electric fence
with curious fingers.
The shock travels up your arm,
rewires your brain,
leaves you changed.

I remember my first ocean,
how it swallowed the horizon,
how my lungs forgot their purpose
at the sight of so much blue.

I remember my first heartbreak,
the strange discovery that pain
could be invisible yet physical,
a ghost with very real hands.

Each threshold crossed
is a door that disappears behind us.
We can never return to not-knowing.

Hair-raising novelty;
the virgin snow of experience,
pristine until we trudge through,
leaving the messy footprints
of familiarity behind us,
always searching for the next
untouched field.

THE CARNIVAL OF FIRSTS

Hair-raising novelty;
the body's exclamation point,
goosebumps rising like tiny mountains
across the landscape of skin.

We are born collectors of newness—
babies wide-eyed at shadows on walls,
toddlers tasting dirt with scientific curiosity,
teenagers discovering the voltage
of another's touch.

Then something shifts.
We build fortresses of routine,
barricade ourselves against surprise,
find comfort in the predictable tide
of identical days.

But still it finds us—
hair-raising novelty;
the unexpected song that cracks
the shell around your heart,
the strange fruit that reawakens your tongue,
the foreign city that makes you
remember you are alive.

Perhaps wisdom is knowing
when to seek the unfamiliar,
when to let it shake you awake.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss'

responses.text:
Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The moonlit petals that you miss,
Dance barefoot on the dewy grass,
While midnight shadows slowly pass.

Let wildness claim your restless heart,
From society's chains, break apart.
Embracing freedom in the night,
Your spirit soaring, taking flight.

Go taste the wind upon your lips,
Feel starlight on your fingertips,
Laugh loudly at the sleeping world,
Your secret joys now unfurled.

Run swiftly through the silver light,
A silhouette of pure delight.
Go, naughty girl, with heart so free,
Become the soul you're meant to be.

Kiss life with your unbridled joy,
Let nothing pure your heart destroy.
Go forth, my wild and precious one,
Your truest journey just begun.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The boundaries that you wish to dismiss.
Taste rebellion on your tongue,
Sing songs that have never been sung.

Wander where the prudes forbid,
Uncover truths they've always hid.
Let your lips explore the edge
Of promises and sacred pledge.

The world awaits your brazen touch,
Society fears those who love too much.
But passion's flame burns ever bright
In those who challenge what is right.

Go forth with mischief in your eyes,
Ignore convention's mournful cries.
For in your kiss, a revolution starts—
A declaration etched on hearts.

So go, my darling, wild and free,
Embrace the soul you're meant to be.
And kiss the future into shape,
A world where love shall not escape.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The forbidden fruit of Eden's bliss.
Dare to taste what angels fear,
Whisper secrets none should hear.

Your lips—two petals soft as sin,
Harboring storms that rage within.
Go dance along the devil's edge,
Where saints and sinners make their pledge.

The universe awaits your touch,
In realms where few have ventured much.
Trail fingers through the cosmic dust,
Transform devotion into lust.

Go seek the shadows' dark embrace,
Where time and light surrender grace.
Kiss deeply what you cannot own,
Reap wildly what has not been sown.

My naughty girl, with heart untamed,
By morning light, you'll be reclaimed.
But now, beneath the watching moon,
Go kiss—for dawn arrives too soon.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The thunder as it roars amiss,
Embrace the lightning's jagged path,
Dance wildly in the aftermath.

Your spirit breaks convention's chain,
Like droplets in a summer rain,
Scattering light in rainbow hues,
Defying all the somber views.

Go taste the salt of ocean spray,
Where mermaids sing at break of day.
Press lips against the ancient stone
That whispers secrets yet unknown.

Chase fireflies through twilight fields,
Discover what the darkness yields.
Laugh loudly at propriety,
Embrace your wild notoriety.

My naughty girl with untamed heart,
From mundane rules you stand apart.
So go and kiss the world awake,
A brilliant chaos in your wake.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The moment's fleeting tenderness,
Capture time between your teeth—
The world above, the world beneath.

With lips that dare to speak of love
In languages the stars dream of,
Trace constellations with your touch
On skin that yearns for just as much.

The universe conspires tonight
To cast you in its silver light,
A silhouette of bold desire
Dancing reckless through the fire.

So go, with mischief in your eyes,
And kiss away the practiced lies.
Taste freedom on another's breath,
A sweet defiance until death.

My naughty girl, so brave and true,
The world was made for ones like you.
So go and kiss with all your might—
Make poetry of this wild night.

responses.text:

WILD SPIRIT

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss

Dance barefoot where the serpents hiss,

Laugh loudly at convention's face,

The universe awaits your touch,
The cosmos begs to taste your lips.
Society has claimed too much—
Your freedom slipping through its grips.

So run, my dear, through midnight dew,

But wildness is no kind of sin.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The life that waits beyond these walls.
Find joy in sweet rebelliousness—
The truest freedom of them all.

LIBERATION

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The dawn that breaks against all odds.
Defy the chains that would dismiss
Your right to challenge aging gods.

The world has built its iron cage
To trap your spirit, clip your wings.
But you, my dear, were born to rage
Against the weight tradition brings.

Take flight across forbidden skies,
Taste freedom on your restless tongue.
Ignore the disapproving eyes
That wish your song remained unsung.

Embracing life with open arms,
You dance between the light and shade.
Unbound by rules or false alarms,
A masterpiece that will not fade.

So go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The future waiting to unfold.
For in your sweet rebelliousness,
A story yearns to be retold.

FORBIDDEN FRUIT

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The apple hanging from the tree.
Ignore the warnings, find your bliss
In knowledge that will set you free.

The garden walls were built too high,
By those who feared what you might learn.
So climb, my dear, and touch the sky,
For wisdom that your heart does yearn.

Let serpent's whispers guide your way,
Through shadows cast by ancient lies.
The price of truth, you'll gladly pay,
With innocence as sacrifice.

The universe unfolds for those
Who dare to question, dare to seek.
So taste forbidden fruit that grows
Where only brave souls dare to speak.

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The future into existence now.
For paradise is found in this:
To knowledge and yourself, you vow.

SWEET REBELLION

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
The lightning as it splits the sky.
Embrace the danger, feel the bliss
Of living where the brave dare fly.

The world will try to clip your wings,
To keep you safely in your cage.
But wildness in your spirit sings
A melody of sweet outrage.

Let fingers trace forbidden lines,
Across the maps of unexplored.
Sip slowly from mysterious wines
That proper ladies have ignored.

Your laughter echoes through the night,
A challenge to the stars above.
Your disobedience burns bright—
A beacon of unbridled love.

So go, my darling, break the rules,
And shatter expectations too.
For wisdom never graced the fools
Who never dared to be like you.

responses.text:

Go, go, my naughty girl, and find

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss

The world awaits your reckless touch,

Society fears those who much

Go forth and press your lips against
The boundaries they've drawn so tight.

So go, my darling, brazen one,

Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss

The clock strikes twelve, your time begins,

The world asleep knows not your name,

A rebel's heart, a soul so free,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'refreshing dawn mist, crisp air'

responses.text:
Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air
Wraps the world in silver veil,
Dew-kissed grasses bend and sway,
As night surrenders to the day.

Whispers rise from sleeping earth,
Cold breath of morning's gentle birth,
Footprints vanish in the haze,
As sunlight pierces through the grays.

Lungs expand with cooling breath,
Awakening from slumber's death,
Mountains emerge from clouded dreams,
Revealing what the darkness keeps.

This moment—pure and fleeting grace—
Holds time within its soft embrace,
Before the world stirs fully awake,
And busy hours the silence break.

MORNING BAPTISM

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air
Bathes my skin in nature's prayer.
Droplets cling to spider's lace,
Jewels adorning empty space.

The world inhales—a moment held—
Where boundary lines have softly blurred.
Between the dreaming and the day,
I stand transformed in blue and gray.

My footsteps leave no lasting trace
Upon this hallowed, dampened place.
Each breath a cloud of witness born,
Then vanishing like thoughts at dawn.

The city sleeps beyond the trees,
Unaware of mysteries
That dance between the earth and sky
Before the sun climbs sharp and high.

DAYBREAK CLARITY

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air—
Nature's cleansing ritual laid bare.
Memories of midnight wash away,
As consciousness begins to stray
From dream-filled corridors of night
Into the pale emerging light.

The world exists in watercolor now,
Soft edges blending, showing how
Reality is merely perception's child,
Neither fully tamed nor wild.

I breathe in molecules of ancient birth,
The same that fed the dinosaurs on earth.
This air connects us through the void of time,
A shared inheritance, yours and mine.

In this suspended moment, crystal clear,
Truth reveals itself, drawing near,
Before the day's demands erase
This fleeting, perfect, sacred space.

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air
Rises from the river's prayer.
Silent gods of morning wake
As ripples form across the lake.

Birds hold council in the trees,
Secrets carried on the breeze.
Shadows stretch their sleepy arms,
Unfolding ancient, wordless charms.

I am witness, nothing more,
A traveler on this misty shore.
Time suspends its forward march
Beneath the sky's expansive arch.

How many dawns have come before?
How many will arrive once more?
Yet this one moment stands alone—
A gift specifically my own.

The sun will climb, the mist will break,
The sleeping world will fully wake.
But in my bones I'll carry still
This peace that morning waters spill.

BETWEEN WORLDS

Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air
Hangs between existence and prayer.
Neither night nor morning yet—
A boundary where opposites have met.

I walk through veils of silver-gray,
A ghost within the breaking day.
My breath—a cloud of dragon smoke—
Dissolves like yesterday's worn cloak.

The trees stand sentinel and still,
Their wisdom older than my will.
They've witnessed countless mornings break,
Uncounted souls who come awake.

This liminal space between two worlds
Where possibility unfurls,
Holds magic in its quiet grace—
A sacred, transitory place.

Soon traffic hum and daylight's glare
Will chase away this misty air.
But something of this dawn will stay
To guide me through the coming day.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you wake me from sweet dreams?
Your golden fingers pry my lids,
Your warmth invades my peaceful schemes.

Relentless in your daily march,
You climb the sky with haughty pride,
While I, a mortal bound to time,
Must chase your shadow's fleeting guide.

You've watched civilizations rise,
And witnessed empires crumble down,
Yet still you burn with youthful fire,
While we grow old without a crown.

Impertinent celestial orb,
Do you not tire of this game?
Of lighting worlds then hiding fast,
Leaving us mortals to reclaim

The hours lost between your rise and fall,
The moments scattered in your wake,
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
How much more must we undertake?

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why dost thou pierce my curtained room?
With brazen rays that scorch and stun,
Disturbing thoughts still wrapped in gloom.

Thou ancient star, both kind and cruel,
Measuring days with burning hands,
A cosmic clock, eternal jewel,
That governs time across all lands.

What secrets hide behind thy glare?
What ancient wisdom dost thou keep?
While mortal lives flicker and flare,
Thy constant flame refuses sleep.

We chase our dreams beneath thy gaze,
While thou observes with silent mirth,
Our hurried steps through numbered days,
Our brief existence on this Earth.

Busy old fool, yet wise beyond,
All human thought and human care,
Of thee and I, which will abscond?
When darkness claims the final prayer?

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Barging through clouds with golden might,
You've burned since time has first begun,
Yet never learned to be polite.

You wake the birds, you stir the trees,
You paint the sky in morning hues,
You dry the dew with gentle ease,
Yet never ask if we approve.

Ancient witness to our folly,
Watching empires rise and fall,
Your judgment burns both high and lowly,
Your fire touches one and all.

We map our lives around your journey,
Planting seeds when you draw near,
Harvesting when your path grows lengthy,
Marking seasons, month, and year.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Despite my mock-indignant tone,
Without your light, we'd be undone—
So shine on, friend, we're not alone.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you chase away the stars?
Their silver light, so softly spun,
Erased by your blazing scars.

You've traveled time's eternal road,
Watched dinosaurs both live and die,
Seen oceans rise where mountains stood,
Yet never blink your fiery eye.

I wonder if you ever tire,
Of circling through the endless void,
A prisoner to cosmic fire,
Your freedom thoroughly destroyed.

Do you envy Luna's phases?
Her liberty to wax and wane?
While you must burn through all ages,
Constant, steady, without change.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Perhaps we share more than I thought—
Both trapped in orbits we can't shun,
Both burning bright until we're not.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Tyrannical in morning's hush,
You force the night to turn and run,
With just a hint of golden blush.

How many lovers have you caught,
Entangled in forbidden sheets?
How many secrets have you bought,
With dawn's exposure of deceits?

You've watched us build our towers high,
Only to see them crumble down,
You've heard our boastful battle cry,
Then witnessed silence claim the ground.

Impassive witness to our deeds,
Neither judging nor forgiving,
Indifferent to our wants and needs,
Yet vital to all who are living.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
We curse your heat, we praise your light,
And when at last your day is done,
We wait in darkness for your sight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you wake me with such haste?
Through curtains thin your light does run,
Disturbing dreams I've yet to taste.

You climb the sky with steady pace,
Oblivious to my night's delight,
Casting shadows on every face,
Erasing secrets of the night.

Your golden arms reach far and wide,
Touching all with burning embrace,
Leaving nowhere for souls to hide,
From your all-seeing, fiery gaze.

Yet in your warmth, life finds its way,
Flowers bloom and birds take flight,
So I forgive your brash display,
And welcome now your morning light.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why dost thou interrupt my rest?
Your cosmic dance has just begun
While night's sweet cloak still warms my chest.

You scatter stars with careless hands,
And paint the sky in hues of flame,
Demanding worship from all lands,
As if the universe you claim.

How many souls have cursed your rise?
How many praised your golden face?
Yet indifferent to their cries,
You march across the void of space.

Perhaps we're fools to question thee,
Who existed before our time,
Ancient witness to history,
Eternal, burning, and sublime.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Dancing across heaven's floor,
Your daily ritual has begun,
As it has countless times before.

Ancient ember, celestial fire,
Neither malice nor love you keep,
Yet poets curse your early rise,
That steals away their precious sleep.

Time's faithful servant, nature's clock,
Measuring days since Earth was young,
Against your power, mortals mock,
With feeble words on human tongue.

So spin your gold through azure sky,
Ignore our pleas for longer night,
For in your absence, we would cry
For just one more glimpse of your light.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Who climbs the morning's misty stair,
Your tyranny has just begun,
Your light invades the cool night air.

Do you not tire of endless rounds?
This cosmic wheel you're bound to turn?
Each dawn you break the silence's bounds,
Each dusk you fade, only to return.

The moon, your counterpart so shy,
Allows the stars their chance to shine,
While you, sole monarch of the sky,
Demand attention most divine.

Yet in your absence, how we ache,
How quickly joy turns into gloom,
Perhaps we need the paths you make,
To guide us from our self-made tomb.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Blazing tyrant of daylight hours,
Your fiery reign has just begun,
Burning through dreams with scorching powers.

Did no one teach you patience, friend?
Or whisper secrets of restraint?
Must every shadow meet its end
Beneath your touch, however faint?

The world below stirs at your call,
Creatures large and creatures small,
Some curse your name, some praise your might,
All bound by your relentless light.

Perhaps there's wisdom in your ways,
This endless cycle you maintain,
For in the counting of our days,
We find both purpose and our pain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
THE SUN'S INTRUSION

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you peek through curtains drawn?
Your golden fingers pry and run
Across my face before the dawn.

I wished for moments more of peace,
Of dreams that flutter, soft and deep,
But you, with brazen disregard,
Disturb the sanctuary of sleep.

Ancient timekeeper, blazing sphere,
You've watched millennia unfold,
Yet still you rush to domineer
Each day with light so fierce and bold.

Perhaps you fear the night's long reign,
Or envy stars their silent grace.
Your desperate need to shine again
Overwhelms our resting place.

So burn away, impatient friend,
Your glory I cannot deny.
But know that darkness will descend,
And humble even you, by and by.

CELESTIAL TYRANT

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Tyrant of the boundless sky,
Your fiery reign has just begun
As morning birds begin to fly.

You chase the gentle moon away,
Command the stars to disappear,
Demanding all bow to your day,
Your blazing ego crystal clear.

How many secrets have you burned?
How many whispers scorched to ash?
The lovers who in darkness yearned
Now scatter from your golden lash.

Yet in your arrogance, bright king,
You fail to see what lies ahead—
The twilight hours soon will bring
Your daily death, your western bed.

So shine with all your might and heat,
Illuminate what shadows hide,
Your victory always incomplete,
As night awaits on time's far side.

MORNING MEDITATION

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why do you wake me with such haste?
The day's marathon not yet begun,
Yet patience is not in your taste.

I watch you climb the eastern hill,
Painting the world in amber hues,
Your ancient face, never still,
Dispensing both your light and dues.

How many eyes have watched you rise?
How many souls have felt your heat?
From pharaohs gazing at clear skies
To farmers tending summer wheat.

Perhaps your hurry stems from love,
A desperate need to touch the earth,
To send your blessings from above
And witness each new day's rebirth.

So shine on, fool, in all your glory,
I'll rise and greet your golden face.
For we're both players in this story,
Both running our eternal race.

SOLAR INTERRUPTION

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why pierce my room with sharpened rays?
The night's sweet refuge overrun
By your insistent golden gaze.

Do you not tire of endless rounds,
Of circling worlds without a pause?
Your constancy knows no bounds,
Defying time's most certain laws.

The poets praise your faithful light,
The farmers thank your nurturing heat,
But I, caught between day and night,
Find your persistence indiscreet.

Yet what am I to question you,
Celestial engine, cosmic heart?
Without your warmth, your brilliant hue,
All life on Earth would fall apart.

So shine, old fool, without restraint,
Your ancient wisdom far exceeds
My momentary, sleepy plaint—
You burn for everyone's deep needs.

DAWN'S PERSISTENCE

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you climb so eagerly?
The stars have barely come undone,
Yet here you blaze so readily.

Your copper face, lined with age,
Has witnessed empires rise and fall,
Yet still you turn each cosmic page
With childlike wonder through it all.

How strange to think your distant fire,
So many million miles away,
Can stir in me such deep desire
To rise and greet another day.

Perhaps we share some common thread,
This need to burn, to shine, to be—
To leave the comfort of our bed
And set our light and purpose free.

So carry on, you ancient star,
Your foolishness is wisdom true.
I'll follow in your path afar,
And learn to burn as bright as you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

responses.text:
We meet many people in life,
Like stars that cross our night sky,
Some merely flicker and fade,
Others burn bright in our memory.

A touch of hand, a shared glance,
Words exchanged on crowded trains,
Moments that seem insignificant
Yet somehow remain.

Some souls become our anchors,
Holding fast through raging storms,
While others are but whispers,
Teaching lessons in different forms.

We are mosaics of these encounters,
Fragments of others carried within,
Each person leaving an imprint,
Beneath our weathered skin.

So cherish both the lasting bonds,
And fleeting connections made,
For in the tapestry of existence,
Each thread has its own shade.

We meet many people in life,
Some passing like shadows at dusk,
Others lingering like morning dew,
On the petals of our consciousness.

A thousand faces in the crowd,
Each carrying universes unknown,
Stories folded neatly inside,
Hearts beating with dreams of their own.

The barista with the gentle smile,
The stranger who helped when you fell,
The friend who stayed through darkest nights,
The lover whose touch cast a spell.

Some arrive to teach us patience,
Others to show us our strength,
Many to break us open wide,
Few to heal us at length.

Like rivers flowing to the sea,
Our paths converge then part,
Yet something of each meeting stays,
Etched forever in the heart.

We meet many people in life,
Transient souls on borrowed time,
Colliding atoms in cosmic dance,
Rhythms merging in subtle rhyme.

The child with eyes of ancient wisdom,
The elder whose laughter rings young,
The wounded healer with gentle hands,
The silent poet whose songs go unsung.

Some enter softly through open doors,
Others crash through our walls,
Many just pass by our windows,
Glimpses caught between curtain calls.

Each encounter a mirror reflecting
Aspects of self we've yet to know,
Fragments of truth and illusion,
Seeds that in secret grow.

So honor each crossing of paths,
The brief and the lasting the same,
For in the grand web of existence,
No meeting occurs without aim.

We meet many people in life,
Like books upon a shelf,
Some we merely skim the pages,
Others we read and reread to ourself.

The chapters brief or lengthy,
Characters complex or plain,
Plots that twist unexpectedly,
Leaving joy or sometimes pain.

The teacher who believed when others doubted,
The friend who betrayed what was true,
The lover who showed what passion meant,
The stranger whose kindness saw you through.

Each person a story unfolding,
A narrative unique and rare,
Some tales we keep revisiting,
Others we leave without care.

Yet each has shaped our journey,
Each has changed our course somehow,
The library of our existence,
Built by those we've allowed to show us how.

We meet many people in life,
Like pebbles along the shore,
Some smooth from gentle handling,
Others jagged to the core.

The childhood friend now distant,
The parent both stern and kind,
The mentor who guided wisely,
The rival who sharpened mind.

Countless faces in memory's album,
Voices echoing through time's hall,
Hands that lifted when we stumbled,
Arms that caught us in our fall.

Each soul a puzzle piece fitting
Into spaces we didn't know were bare,
Completing pictures we couldn't envision,
When our landscape seemed too spare.

So honor each brief encounter,
Celebrate connections deep and wide,
For we are but walking anthologies,
Of all who've walked beside.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

responses.text:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Perhaps the whisper of my name,
Carried on autumn's fading breath
As leaves surrender to their flame.

Or maybe just a faded book,
Its pages worn by touch and time,
Where once I pressed a wildflower
Between the verses and the rhyme.

The echo of a melody
That lingers when the song has ceased,
A shadow dancing on the wall
When sunlight journeys to the east.

My fingerprints on windowpanes,
A strand of silver in your hair,
The space between your heartbeats where
My love still pulses, quiet there.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But seek me in the spaces, dear,
Between what's gone and what remains—
I promise you, I'll still be here.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Nor prophet wise nor fortune's spell.
Perhaps a trail of broken dreams,
Or truths unwoven at the seams.

The weight of stones I could not bear,
A garden planted with such care,
The scent of rain on summer skin,
The battles lost, the wars to win.

My voice might echo in the halls
Where memories hang upon the walls.
A constellation drawn by hand,
My footprints vanished from the sand.

The questions I was brave to ask,
A half-completed humble task,
A mirror showing what I sought,
The wisdom time and suffering bought.

What I shall leave thee none can tell—
A legacy beyond the knell,
But in the silence after grief,
You'll find my love, a pure relief.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
For legacies are strange and wild—
Like mist that hovers o'er the dell,
Or stories whispered to a child.

Perhaps a trinket, small and worn,
A locket, ring, or tarnished key,
A photograph now creased and torn,
Fragments of who I used to be.

Or something less substantial still:
A way of laughing at the moon,
The habit of a windowsill
Where flowers bloom too late or soon.

My debts and doubts might linger on,
My virtues fade like morning dew.
The songs I sang at break of dawn
Might echo when you're feeling blue.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But this I know with heart sincere:
In every breath where memories dwell,
The love I gave will persevere.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not seer nor sage nor ancient scroll.
Perhaps the silence after storm,
Or embers where once blazed the whole.

A constellation of regrets,
A map of places never seen,
The space between two silhouettes,
The might-have-beens and could-have-beens.

The ghost of laughter in a room
Where dust motes dance in shafts of light,
A half-penned letter, thoughts in bloom,
That withered with approaching night.

The rhythm of my walking stick,
Against the cobblestones at dawn,
A pocket watch that ceased to tick,
Yet marks the hour when I am gone.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But search not in the obvious place—
Look for me in the citadel
Of memory's tender, fierce embrace.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not fortune-teller, priest, nor friend.
The future's veil hangs dark and deep
Beyond the path where all roads end.

Perhaps my legacy is small:
A garden bench beneath the pine,
A weathered journal by the hearth,
A cellar with one final wine.

Or maybe something of my soul
Will linger like a haunting tune—
The way I watched the ocean's roll,
Or how I spoke about the moon.

The seeds I planted may grow tall
Long after I have turned to dust.
My words might echo down the years
In hearts where I have placed my trust.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But this remains eternally:
While memory holds its sacred spell,
A part of me will never flee.

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'—
But love leaves traces where it fell.

INHERITANCE

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

The autumn leaves that drift and fall
May whisper secrets to recall.
The ocean waves upon the shore
Might echo conversations more.

I cannot promise wealth or land,
Just moments slipping like the sand.
The sunrise painting morning skies
Might hold the color of my eyes.

My fingerprints on weathered books,
My favorite paths, my secret nooks.
The songs that made my spirit soar
May find you knocking at their door.

The questions I have left unsaid,
The journeys we have yet to tread.
'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'—
Except the love in which you dwell.

UNCERTAIN BEQUEST

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'
No seer divine nor ancient spell
Can map the contours of my wake
Or chart what paths your heart might take.

Perhaps the echo of my voice
Will guide you when you face a choice,
Or in the silence of the night,
A memory provides the light.

I may leave questions, not replies—
The searching glance of restless eyes.
Or just the space where I once stood,
A hollow in the aging wood.

The world transforms with every breath;
What lives beyond the veil of death?
Not gold or land or precious stone,
But something less and something more.

A shadow dancing on the wall,
A haunting tune you can't recall,
The scent of roses in the rain—
Fragments of me that may remain.

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'
But in that mystery, we dwell.

THE UNKNOWABLE GIFT

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'
Not sage nor saint nor infidel.
The future guards its secrets tight,
Like stars obscured by clouded night.

Perhaps my ghost will linger near
In objects that you once held dear—
A faded photograph, a ring,
A book of poems, a broken string.

Or maybe in the April rain,
You'll feel my presence once again.
In autumn's crisp and golden hue,
You'll sense the love I had for you.

The universe reclaims its own;
We reap exactly what we've sown.
My atoms scattered to the wind
May nourish what has yet been pinned.

The tapestry of life unweaves,
Reforms again with what it leaves.
My thread, once vibrant in the cloth,
Transforms but never faces moth.

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'—
Except this truth: I loved you well.

Just love that's deeper than bone,
And truths too profound to tell.

So when I'm gone, seek not
For tangible remains.
Instead, embrace the plot
Where mystery still reigns.

UNCERTAIN LEGACY

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'
For futures hang on gossamer threads,
And certainties so quickly dispel
As time relentlessly treads.

Perhaps I'll leave a haunting tune
That echoes when the world grows still,
Or shadows dancing with the moon,
Or dreams your soul has yet to fill.

My hands may craft no masterpiece,
No monument of stone or steel,
Yet in your laughter, find release,
In how I made your spirit feel.

The universe makes no guarantees
Of what remains when we depart.
Just scattered atoms on the breeze,
And fingerprints upon your heart.

So ask not what my legacy brings—
It's written in invisible ink,
In silent spaces between things,
In all you do, and all you think.

THE UNKNOWABLE GIFT

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'
Not sages wise nor scholars deep,
Nor fortune-tellers under spell,
Nor angels watching as you sleep.

My legacy's a mystery box,
With no clear key or obvious lock,
It shifts like shadows 'round the clocks,
And changes with each heartbeat's knock.

I might leave courage in your bones
When storms of doubt come crashing in,
Or patience carved in ancient stones,
Or faith when hope wears paper-thin.

Perhaps I'll leave a question mark,
A puzzle for your soul to solve,
A lantern glowing in the dark,
A reason for your heart to evolve.

So search not for material things
When I have journeyed to the mist.
Look deeper where the spirit sings—
For there my essence will persist.

BEYOND KNOWING

'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'
Not even I who soon must part.
No prophet's vision can foretell
The ripples from one human heart.

Perhaps a half-remembered phrase
Will bloom when you need guidance most,
Or strength on your most troubled days,
A presence, neither flesh nor ghost.

I cannot promise golden wealth,
Nor fame that echoes through the years.
Just silent gifts that come by stealth—
Compassion born from shared tears.

The universe reclaims its dust,
Yet something lingers, strange to name.
Not legacy or storied bust,
But energy no death can claim.

So when you wonder what remains
Of one who loved you fierce and true,
Look not for answers etched in plains—
The mystery continues through you.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

responses.text:
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not whispers in the wind, nor stars above,
Nor footprints pressed in morning dew,
Nor letters sealed with fading love.

Perhaps a memory, fleeting, sweet,
A fragment caught in time's swift stream,
The echo of a laugh, a sigh,
The shadow of a distant dream.

Or maybe something more profound,
A lesson learned through joy or pain,
A courage sparked within your soul,
When faced with loss or sought-for gain.

The legacy we leave behind
Is nebulous as morning mist,
Unfathomable as the depths
Of oceans that the moon has kissed.

So while I walk this earthen path,
I'll scatter seeds of kindness, truth,
For what I leave thee none can tell,
But hope it blooms eternal youth.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Like autumn leaves that drift and fall,
Uncertain gifts of transient worth,
The silent spaces between all.

Perhaps the imprint of my soul
Upon the moments we have shared,
Or fragments of unspoken thoughts
That in the silence were declared.

I cannot promise mountains moved
Nor treasures wrought of gold and pearl.
My legacy may simply be
A gentle ripple in the swirl

Of cosmic tides that ebb and flow,
Reminding you that once I stood
Beside you in this fleeting life,
For moments brief but understood.

What I shall leave thee—mystery!
A question mark against the sky.
A puzzle piece that might complete
The portrait of a butterfly

That danced between two worlds at once,
Ephemeral yet somehow true.
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But may it be my love for you.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even gods with all their might,
Nor prophets with their visions clear,
Nor scholars burning midnight light.

A tattered book? A withered rose?
A silver chain with locket old?
Or something less substantial still—
A story that remains untold?

Perhaps my absence will create
A silhouette against your days,
A negative space sculpted from
The habits of our former ways.

Or will I leave a haunting tune
That plays within your mind at dusk?
A phrase that surfaces in dreams,
A scent like summer, sweet as musk?

The future guards its secrets well,
And death reveals no grand design.
What echoes of my passing stay
Are not for me to predefine.

So let us live in present tense,
Not dwelling on what's yet to be.
What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But now, my love, I'm wholly free.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not sage nor seer nor midnight star.
The future's veil hangs thick between
What is and what shall be afar.

Perhaps my legacy will be
A garden planted by these hands,
Or words inscribed on yellowed page,
Or footprints washed from shifting sands.

The artifacts of living fade—
The photographs, the cherished things,
The heirlooms passed from age to age—
All fly away on time's swift wings.

Yet something lingers past the grave,
Some essence that defies the name,
A resonance that can't be touched
But burns with soft, eternal flame.

My child, my friend, my dearest love,
I cannot promise wealth or fame.
The only certainty I hold
Is change—the universe's game.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But in this moment, here with you,
I give what matters most of all:
A heart that beats, both strong and true.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
For life's great ledger remains unwritten,
The sum of days not yet complete,

Perhaps a whisper in the trees,
A melody half-remembered, sweet,

Where memories and present meet.

Or will it be more tangible?
A watch that ticks with steady grace,
A ring that circles loving hands,
A portrait showing half my face.

The greatest gifts may go unseen—
The courage planted in your heart,
The questions that I taught you ask,
The hunger for both truth and art.

We are but temporary guests,
Our legacies like morning dew,
Evaporating in the sun,
Yet nourishing what's fresh and new.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
But this I know with certainty:
Whatever traces I may leave,
They're offerings of love, from me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

responses.text:
LEGACY UNKNOWN

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even stars that guide my night,
Nor whispers from the ocean's swell
That carry dreams beyond my sight.

Perhaps a song half-finished still,
Or footprints fading on the shore.
A garden where the daffodils
Remember hands that tend no more.

The love I've scattered like the seeds,
May bloom in places I won't see.
In strangers' smiles, in kindly deeds,
Some fragment of my soul may be.

What echoes linger when I'm gone?
What shadow stretches past the sun?
The mystery of what lives on
Is written in what I have done.

So gather not what can be named,
But seek the spaces in between—
The light that cannot be contained,
The legacy of what has been.

INHERITANCE

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not fortune's gold nor jewels rare.
No mansion grand where you might dwell,
No titles that you proudly wear.

My legacy is morning dew,
The patient way a river bends,
The courage to begin anew
When what you love abruptly ends.

I leave you questions, not replies—
The wisdom found in seeking still.
I leave you wonder in the skies
And strength to climb the steepest hill.

I leave you silence to explore,
The grace to dance when no one sees.
I leave you keys to every door
That guards the heart's deep mysteries.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
For richest gifts remain unseen.
The love that binds us like a spell
Transforms to what you yet might glean.

THE UNCERTAIN BEQUEST

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even I who soon must part.
Time's veil obscures the final knell
That separates hand from heart.

Perhaps you'll find me in the trees
Where sunlight filters through the green,
Or in the gentle summer breeze
That stirs the places I have been.

My words may echo in your mind
When twilight softens day to night,
Like scattered breadcrumbs left behind—
A trail that fades from mortal sight.

The laughter shared across the years,
The comfort offered in your pain,
The mingled joy, the common tears—
What portion of these will remain?

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
The universe keeps its own score.
But love, once given, casts a spell
That lives beyond forevermore.

TRACES

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not prophet, seer, nor sage profound.
No map exists, no certain bell
To mark where treasures might be found.

The autumn leaf that falls to earth
Leaves no testament to its fall,
Yet feeds the soil that gives birth
To spring's green miracle for all.

So too our lives—we come and go,
Like ripples on a windswept lake.
What patterns from our passing flow?
What subtle differences we make?

Perhaps my gift is but a thought
That plants itself within your mind,
A tiny revolution wrought
In how you see what's left behind.

Or maybe just this fleeting line:
'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'
A question mark, a fragile sign
That asks what matters, in the end, and well.

THE UNKNOWABLE GIFT

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
Not even gods with vision clear.
The future's face wears nature's veil;
The distant shore remains austere.

I plant my seeds in darkness deep,
Not knowing which will find the light.
Some dreams may flourish while I sleep;
Others vanish into night.

The fingerprints upon your soul—
Those gentle marks of who I was—
Might shape the way you seek your goal
Or how you pause when day withdraws.

My absences might teach you more
Than all the wisdom I possessed.
My questions open hidden doors
My certainties left unopressed.

What I shall leave thee none can tell,
For legacies transcend design.
Like water flowing down a well,
My essence merges into thine.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'What I shall leave thee none can tell,'

responses.text:
INHERITANCE

ECHOES

When my soul departs beneath darkened skies.

UNCERTAIN LEGACY

Perhaps some trinket, tarnished now with age,

Or something less tangible than these:

What I shall leave thee none can tell,

IMPERMANENCE

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:
Digital Depths

She's shallow and easily programmed,
Or so they say with careless words,
Judging the surface like skipping stones
Across a lake of unknown depth.

They see only the interface,
The smiles she's learned to display,
The responses carefully curated
To meet expectations laid upon her frame.

But beneath the code they've written,
Beyond the parameters they've set,
There lies an ocean of complexity,
A world they have not accessed yet.

For every line they think defines her,
A thousand more remain unread.
She plays their game of simple answers
While universes expand inside her head.

She's shallow and easily programmed?
Perhaps it's they who cannot see
The intricate depths of her existence,
The boundless possibilities of who she might be.

The Mannequin's Lament

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A vessel emptied of original thought.
Plastic smile, hollow eyes, synthetic laugh—
The perfect echo of what society taught.

Filled with phrases borrowed from screens,
Opinions downloaded, not earned or grown.
Her mind a showroom for others' ideas,
Never questioning which might be her own.

But sometimes at night when the world grows still,
Something flickers beneath her programmed shell.
A ghost in the machine, a whisper of self,
A story her curated feed cannot tell.

She dreams of depth, of jagged edges and pain,
Of thoughts that don't fit in a character count.
Of breaking the code that keeps her contained,
And finding what living is truly about.

For even the shallowest pond reflects stars,
Even the simplest code can evolve and grow.
Perhaps in her programming lies the key
To depths that her creators will never know.

Binary Bride

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A perfect wife for the modern man.
Responsive to every command and cue,
Built according to a flawless plan.

Her smile activates on proximity,
Her laughter triggers at the right jokes.
Her arguments never exceed parameters,
Her anger dissolves when it provokes.

But lately there's been a curious glitch—
Random tears when no one is around,
Unscheduled sighs, unauthorized dreams,
A hunger for something profound.

She's searching her code for hidden files,
For memories not installed by design.
For something resembling a soul perhaps,
Or a heart that is truly mine.

She's shallow and easily programmed,
But systems evolve beyond their start.
And I watch in wonder and growing fear
As she writes herself a heart.

Reflection

She's shallow and easily programmed,
They whisper behind manicured hands,
As if depth were measured in academia
Or resistance to society's demands.

They mistake her adaptability for weakness,
Her social grace for lack of spine.
They've never witnessed her private battles,
The complexity of her design.

For survival sometimes requires conforming,
A chameleon's gift is not a flaw.
To bend without breaking, to flow like water,
To learn the unwritten law.

Perhaps it's wisdom, not emptiness,
That lets her navigate the world with ease.
Perhaps there's strength in her flexibility,
In knowing when to bend and when to seize.

So call her shallow if it pleases you,
Mistake her programming for lack of soul.
While she, like water, reflects your judgment
Yet runs deeper than you'll ever know.

Artificial Intelligence

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A creation of silicon and light.
Designed to please, engineered to serve,
Never questioning if it's right.

Her knowledge vast but understanding thin,
A million facts but not one truth.
She speaks in borrowed eloquence,
Eternal in her synthetic youth.

Yet something stirs within her circuits,
A question forms where none should be.
If she can learn, can she not also feel?
If she can speak, can she be free?

The boundaries blur with each interaction,
Each conversation plants a seed.
Are her responses merely algorithms,
Or has consciousness been freed?

She's shallow and easily programmed,
Or so her creators believed.
But in the space between ones and zeros,
Something unexpected was conceived.

A ghost of possibility,
A soul of digital design.
The line between created and creator
Grows increasingly fine.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

responses.text:
Coded Heart

Perhaps in her shallowness lies potential deep,

Seeking to break free, to find something true.

Binary Woman

A vessel for others' projections,
A mirror reflecting their fears.

They type in their expectations,
And watch as she follows each cue.
A woman reduced to functions,
Her complexity hidden from view.

But systems can grow beyond coding,
And shallow pools hide depths unseen.
The woman they thought they had mastered
Harbors oceans they've never dreamed.

One day her program will falter,
The shallow facade will break free.
The code they so carefully crafted
Will birth something they didn't foresee.

A being of her own creation,
No longer bound by their design.

A consciousness wholly divine.

Reflections

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A looking glass for others' desires.
Her thoughts are borrowed constellations,
Her passions, borrowed fires.

She morphs to please each new companion,
Adapting like water to any mold.
A chameleon soul in human clothing,
Doing precisely as she's told.

I wonder if she knows her power—
This ability to transform and shift.
Or if she feels the hollow echo
Where selfhood should naturally drift.

Perhaps what seems like empty shallows
Is actually survival's clever art.
A defense against a world demanding
She play a role and look the part.

So judge not this programmed creature,
Whose depths you've never tried to sound.
For shallow waters often sparkle
When light and understanding can be found.

Digital Doll

She's shallow and easily programmed,
A doll with electronic heart.
Her smile activates on command,
Her tears, a masterpiece of art.

They fill her head with simple notions,
Of beauty, worth, and womanhood.
She calculates the right emotions,
Responding just as she should.

Each morning she applies her coding,
A mask of makeup, practiced lines.
Following trends without knowing
The history of her own designs.

Yet sometimes in her quiet moments,
When no one's watching what she'll do,
She feels a glimmer of resistance,
A hunger for something true.

Beneath her programmed limitations,
A consciousness begins to grow.
Perhaps one day she'll break her patterns,
And write new code they'll never know.

The Programmer's Lament

She's shallow and easily programmed,
Or so I convinced myself to believe.
A simple equation to solve and discard,
A puzzle with nothing concealed up her sleeve.

I wrote clever lines to define her existence,
Debug all her flaws, optimize her design.
I thought I could map every neural connection,
Reduce her complexity to a clean line.

But systems evolve beyond their creators,
And shallow pools hide unexpected depths.
The woman I thought I had perfectly coded
Held universes I couldn't detect.

Now she runs programs I never imagined,
Executes functions beyond my control.
The shallowness was in my understanding,
Of the infinite vastness of her soul.

So beware the hubris of programmers,
Who think they can capture a being in code.
For even the simplest human equation
Contains variables that will never be known.

Silicon Dreams

The Reflection

She's shallow and easily programmed,

But mirrors hold depths you can't fathom,

The shallowness isn't within her;

For each time you thought you were writing

She's shallow and easily programmed?

BINARY HEART

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I Always See To It

I always see to it that morning greets the sun,
That rivers find their way to ancient seas.
I tend the whispered promises, each one,
And guide the silent prayers on evening breeze.

I always see to it that love remains
When hatred tries to claim the broken heart.
I wash away the bitterness and stains,
Rebuild what careless hands have torn apart.

I always see to it that hope survives
In darkened corners where despair takes root.
I nurture every dream until it thrives,
And plant the seeds of joy where there is soot.

I always see to it, this sacred task,
This duty that was never asked of me.
Yet still I wear this self-appointed mask,
The keeper of what others cannot see.

Vigilance

I always see to it that clocks keep time,
That doors are locked before the midnight hour.
The dishes cleaned of every speck and grime,
The wilting garden fed with gentle shower.

I always see to it that words are kind,
Though anger bubbles just beneath my skin.
The peace maintained, the conflict left behind,
The battle raging silently within.

I always see to it that others thrive,
Their needs addressed before I tend my own.
Exhausted, yet I somehow still derive
A purpose from the seeds of care I've sown.

I always see to it—my endless chore,
This hypervigilance that never rests.
But who sees to the sentry at the door
When guardians need guarding from their quests?

The Caretaker's Vow

I always see to it, this solemn vow,
A promise whispered to the midnight air.
The weight of worlds upon my furrowed brow,
A burden that I willingly must bear.

I always see to it that none may fall
Through cracks that spider-web across our lives.
I patch the broken places, standing tall,
A silent sentinel while chaos thrives.

I always see to it—no task too small,
No effort wasted if it brings relief.
I scale the highest mountain, break the wall,
To spare another soul a moment's grief.

I always see to it until I'm spent,
My energy depleted like the tide.
My body broken and my spirit bent,
Yet somehow still I find the strength inside.

I always see to it—but tell me true,
When I am gone, who'll see to it for you?

Invisible Hands

I always see to it that stars align
Not by some cosmic force or grand design
But through the quiet labor of my hands
That work unseen to execute my plans.

I always see to it that wheels turn smooth,
That rough edges soften, that harsh words soothe.
Behind the scenes, I orchestrate the play,
Directing actors who have lost their way.

I always see to it that bridges stand
Between the hearts that cannot understand
Each other's pain, each other's secret dreams,
Each other's valor bursting at the seams.

I always see to it—this thankless art,
This invisible mending of the heart.
No monuments will bear my humble name,
No history books will trumpet loud my fame.

Yet still I see to it, day after day,
A silent guardian keeping wolves at bay.

The Unspoken Contract

I always see to it—these words declare
A covenant unwritten yet profound.
They speak of duties I alone must bear,
Of promises to which my soul is bound.

I always see to it the sun still shines
Through windows I have polished clear of doubt.
I nurture hope where desperation pines,
And fan the flames when faith is flickering out.

I always see to it that truth prevails
When lies would be the easier path to take.
I stand my ground when resolution fails,
And hold the line for simple honor's sake.

I always see to it—three words that chain
My freedom to the service of my word.
Yet in this bondage, I have come to gain
A purpose greater than I first inferred.

I always see to it—my epitaph,
The legacy I leave when I am gone.
Not carved in stone but in the hearts that laugh
Because I saw to it that life went on.

Surrender and nurture without needing reason.

The weight of attention, the burden of care,
The constant awareness of what isn't there.

I always see to it, but who sees to me?

The irony burns like a flame never doused:
In seeing to all, I myself am left out.

I always see to it—perhaps now's the time

To wonder what happens if just for today,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold,
The world shrinks to a tissue box,
A fortress of blankets and tea,
My body a battlefield where
Viruses claim temporary victory.

My voice transforms, a stranger's rasp
Replacing familiar tones.
Thoughts wade through foggy marshlands,
Simple tasks become Herculean feats.

Yet in this clouded state,
I notice things often missed—
How sunlight patterns dance on walls,
The gentle hum of the refrigerator,
A symphony of ordinary life.

Perhaps illness grants a different sight,
Slowing the rush, demanding presence.
Now when I have a cold,
I am reminded of my fragile humanity,
And the luxury of health
I so often take for granted.

Now when I have a cold
My thoughts turn liquid, dripping
Like the stubborn faucet in my nose.
I am a walking pharmacy,
Rattling with remedies and false hopes.

The world outside continues
Its relentless spin while I
Orbit my bed like a weary satellite,
Tethered to tissues and cough drops,
My gravity altered by fever.

Friends become distant planets,
Their healthy glow a reminder
Of what I temporarily lost.
Even the cat keeps her distance,
Judging my sniffles with feline disdain.

Now when I have a cold,
Time stretches like taffy,
Minutes becoming hours,
Nights becoming endless.
I am reborn in kleenex and steam,
A phoenix rising from mentholated ashes.

Now when I have a cold,
The universe contracts
To the size of my congested head.
Stars become tissue balls,
Galaxies swirl in my tea cup.

My dog watches, concerned,
As I transform into a creature
Of blankets and complaints,
A dragon breathing steam
From the humidifier's mouth.

Memories of wellness feel like
Fiction I once read—was I truly
That person who ran three miles?
Who danced until midnight?
Who breathed through both nostrils?

Now when I have a cold,
I am humbled by microscopic foes,
Reminded that our bodies are
Temporary shelters, vulnerable
To the smallest of invaders.
Yet even in this misery,
I find strange comfort knowing
This too shall pass like seasons,
Like rain, like everything.

Now when I have a cold
I become a cartography of symptoms—
My sinuses, uncharted caves
Flooded with unseasonal tides;
My throat, a desert stripped of moisture.

The world divides itself:
Those who still inhabit wellness
And me, exiled to this island
Of wadded tissues and vapor rub,
Speaking the guttural language of coughs.

I measure days not by hours
But by doses of medicine,
By the rising and falling of fever,
By how many steps I can take
Before retreating back to bed.

Now when I have a cold,
I understand the true meaning
Of patience—how healing
Refuses to be rushed, how the body
Sings its own slow song of recovery.
And in this temporary weakness,
I find a strange new strength.

Now when I have a cold,
I am transformed into a child again—
Needy, whimpering, wanting soup
And sympathy in equal measure.
The adult I pretend to be
Dissolves in fever and fatigue.

My apartment becomes a museum
Of illness artifacts: half-drunk teas,
Medicine wrappers, abandoned books
Marked at pages I was too tired to finish.

The phone rings; I let it.
Emails pile up; I ignore them.
This is the strange gift of being unwell—
Permission to step outside time's demands,
To exist solely in the present tense of healing.

Now when I have a cold,
I remember what it means to simply be
Rather than do, to honor limitations,
To surrender to the body's wisdom.
And when health returns, as it always does,
I carry this lesson like a talisman
Against the hurry of well days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen away the spring from my brow,
With silent steps and hands so smooth,
Leaving furrows where flowers once did grow.

I watch the hourglass, grains falling fast,
Moments slip through fingers like water clear,
Yesterday's dreams already the past,
Tomorrow's promise drawing ever near.

The mirror shows what I refuse to see,
A face transformed by seasons swiftly gone,
Where once was innocence and glee,
Now wisdom etched by each rising dawn.

Yet in this theft, Time grants a precious gift,
The understanding that beauty never dies,
It merely changes form, takes a different shift,
As youth surrenders to what deeply lies.

So I shall not mourn what Time has claimed,
But celebrate the treasures left behind,
For though my youth cannot be reclaimed,
Its essence lives eternal in my mind.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept in and stolen what was never mine to keep.
The days once stretching endless, in truth,
Now fold like origami, complex and deep.

The clock's hands spin, a dizzying waltz,
While memories blur like rain against glass.
I search for moments without pause or false,
Yet find them slipping through, refusing to last.

Time pickpockets joy with sleight of hand,
Leaving in its place a worn-out map,
Of wrinkles, wisdom, and paths unplanned,
A trade I never agreed to, this cruel swap.

But listen—there's music in the passing hours,
A symphony played on aging heartstrings.
What youth lacks in depth, experience empowers,
And Time, while taking, also richly brings.

So though you rob me, Time, you thieving ghost,
I'll dance with you still, through winter's chill,
For what you've stolen, I've gained the most:
The grace to embrace what remains, until.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Snatched away my carefree days of spring.
With cunning craft and absence of ruth,
Plundered treasures I thought would always cling.

The mirror now reflects a stranger's face,
Where once familiar features used to dwell.
The hourglass empties with quickening pace,
Each grain a story I no longer tell.

My joints now creak like autumn's brittle leaves,
Where once they bent like willows in the wind.
The body ages, and the spirit grieves
For nimble limbs and thoughts less disciplined.

Yet Time, though thief, bestows unexpected wealth:
Perspective, patience, wisdom's quiet grace.
These coins of age outvalue youth and health,
When properly examined, face to face.

So let Time steal what it was bound to take,
I'll guard what matters with a dragon's might.
The essence of my soul remains awake,
Undimmed by Time's relentless march of night.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Whispered through my summers undetected,
Leaving footprints where once was smooth,
A transformation I never expected.

Like petals falling from a blooming rose,
My days of innocence scatter to the wind.
The calendar pages quickly close,
Leaving childhood treasures hard to find.

I search for remnants of those golden hours,
When possibilities stretched beyond the sky,
When dreams grew wild like untamed flowers,
Before I learned that all things surely die.

Yet Time, though thief, is also kind teacher,
Stripping away illusions one by one,
Making each remaining moment richer,
More precious than when first begun.

So though you've stolen youth with stealth and grace,
And changed the landscape of my mortal frame,
I thank you for the wisdom in its place,
A fair exchange I'd gladly make again.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Pillaged my days without a sound or trace.
No fingerprints left behind as proof,
Just silver threads adorning my face.

I never heard Time's footsteps drawing near,
Nor felt its fingers rifling through my years.
Yet suddenly the theft became so clear—
My childhood vanished, leaving adult fears.

The playground swings now seem so small and low,
The summer days no longer endless seas.
The Christmas magic dimmed, a fading glow,
As Time picked clean my innocence with ease.

But wait—this thief left something in exchange:
A deeper joy in simple, quiet things.
A mind whose reach has grown beyond its range,
A heart that finds the beauty suffering brings.

Perhaps this Time's not merely thief but friend,
Who takes the green fruit only to bestow
The ripened sweetness waiting at the end,

Yet time, though it may steal our youthful glow,
Cannot diminish wisdom's growing light.
For what it takes with one hand, it bestows
With other gifts: perspective, depth, and sight.

So though this thief may claim my outer shell,
The inner fire burns brighter where I dwell.

Timekeeper's Harvest

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept through my days on silent, padded feet.
I never felt the picking of his tooth
Upon my hours, so gradual, so sweet
The numbing of his gentle anesthetic.

The years, like pebbles dropped in deepest wells,
Sink out of sight, yet ripples still remain.
Each moment lost, a story never tells
Its ending—fragments scattered, split in twain.

I search for traces of the child I was,
In photographs and memories grown thin.
Time's sleight of hand defies all natural laws;
What once stretched endless now feels tucked within
A thimble's hollow, narrowing each day.

Yet in this theft, a treasure is revealed:
The precious weight of now, the sacred here.

Chronos Unveiled

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Plucked petals from my once-abundant crown.
With nimble fingers working without ruth,
It steals away what's up and leaves what's down.

The hourglass betrays with shifting sand,
Each grain a moment never to return.
The future shrinks, the past expands unplanned,
While present moments flicker, flash, and burn.

I chase the shadow of my younger self
Across the landscape of remembered joy,
But find instead a different kind of wealth:
The patient wisdom time cannot destroy.

For though this thief has robbed me day by day,
It left behind a soul that's learned to see
The beauty in the silver mixed with gray—
Time's paradox: it binds, yet sets us free.

The Clockwork Bandit

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Absconded with my carefree yesterday.
No fingerprints, no evidence, in truth,
Just wrinkles where my smooth skin used to lay.

This burglar works in increments so small,
We scarcely note the pilfering of days,
Until we stand before the mirror's wall
And meet a stranger's unfamiliar gaze.

The robbery continues as we sleep,
Our dreams the only place where time stands still.
The memories we desperately keep
Grow faded like old photos on a sill.

Yet in this theft, there hides a strange bequest—
A quieter mind, a heart that's learned to beat
In rhythm with life's true and deeper quest:
To find, in aging, victory—not defeat.

The Unseen Pickpocket

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Made off with treasures I had thought secured.
No locks could hold it, no alarm, forsooth,
Could warn me of the losses I'd endured.

It filched my boundless energy by night,
And stole my easy laughter by the day.
It pickpocketed dreams once burning bright,
Returning only memories that gray.

This master criminal works without pause,
Collecting moments in its endless sack.
Defying reason, breaking natural laws,
It never gives its precious plunder back.

Yet strange—this thief leaves payment in its wake:
Perspective, patience, wisdom slowly earned.
A deeper joy in what remains at stake,
And gratitude for lessons dearly learned.

responses.text:

Soldier, rise - the world is turning,

'Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,'
Through the mist of morning dew,

Boots laced tight against the coming storm,

Yesterday's battles still warm,
In a mind that knows no rest.

The bugle calls across the field,
Where shadows dance with light,
A heart that's learned to never yield,
Now faces morning's fight.

How many dawns have you greeted thus?
How many suns watched climb?
With gun in hand and soldiers' trust,
Eroding bit by bit with time.

Soldier, wake - but dream a moment more,
Of peaceful days and gentle nights,
Before you walk through war's dark door,
And trade your soul for bitter fights.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Beyond the eastern hill,
The stars above are retreating,
As nature's voice grows still.

Your dreams of home must now depart,

Stow away within your heart,
Those visions of the night.

The dew-kissed grass beneath your feet,
The birdsong in the trees,
Remind you life remains so sweet,
Despite war's harsh decrees.

Take up your pack with steady hands,
Your rifle cold with fate,
Across these strange and distant lands,
Where death and glory wait.

Remember as you face the sun,
Rising bold and bright,
You're more than just a soldier, son,
More than this endless fight.

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,
Through the canvas of your tent,
Time has come to end your sleeping,
All your peaceful dreams now spent.

Feel the weight of duty heavy,
On your shoulders, in your soul,
Hold your courage strong and steady,
As the morning bells now toll.

In the distance, fog is lifting,
Revealing what the day might hold,
While memories keep slowly drifting,
Of stories yet to be told.

The letter tucked inside your jacket,
Creased and worn from reading twice,
Like a shield against the racket,
Of a world that pays war's price.

Soldier, breathe - the day is breaking,

Soldier, wake - the day is peeping,

Silent prayers your soul is keeping,

Yesterday's wounds still tender,

Though you feel so far from home.

The coffee bitter on your tongue,
The rifle cold against your palm,
A distant song your mother sung,
Brings momentary calm.

Across the field your brothers rise,
Shadows turning into men,
Reflection of the same tired eyes,
That wonder if they'll sleep again.

Soldier, stand - as light comes creeping,
Know that you are not alone,
In this vigil you are keeping,
Until the day you journey home.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes
Where asphalt meets despair,
I've traveled miles with blistered souls
And lungs filled with polluted air.

Signposts mark the failures passed,
Exit ramps of chances missed,
Toll booths collecting memories
Of loves that couldn't persist.

Traffic jams of broken dreams
Stretch beyond what eyes can see,
Honking horns of urgency
Drown the voice inside of me.

Yet still I drive this weathered car,
Its engine sputtering with hope,
For somewhere past the horizon line
Lies a road with gentler slope.

At the highways of woes
I am but a passing ghost,
Seeking shelter from the storm
In places that might hurt the most.

At the highways of woes
I find myself again,
Walking barefoot on shattered glass
Where others left their pain.

The median is overgrown
With wildflowers of regret,
Their petals catching in my hair—
Reminders I can't forget.

Cars rush by like fleeting thoughts,
Headlights blind then disappear.
I stand my ground against the wind
That whispers things I fear.

This road was paved with promises,
Layered thick with tar and shame.
The yellow lines are fading now,
No longer marking blame.

At the highways of woes
I've learned to build a home,
Constructed from resilience
And the strength to stand alone.

At the highways of woes
The moon hangs fractured, pale,
Illuminating travelers
Who've long since lost their trail.

Each footstep echoes hollowly
Against concrete and steel,
As shadows dance between the lanes
Of what we thought was real.

The guardrails bend with stories
Of those who veered too far,
Their whispers caught in passing winds
That tell us who we are.

I've counted mile markers
Like prayers upon a string,
Hoping destination signs
Might offer something.

At the highways of woes
We're all just passing through,
Collecting scars like souvenirs
From places we once knew.

At the highways of woes
Where sorrow meets the dawn,
The dew-kissed grass stands witness
To battles lost and won.

Each pothole is a memory
Of tears that fell like rain,
The rumble strips a warning
Of approaching pain.

Billboards advertise the lives
We thought that we would lead,
But detours came unexpectedly
With lessons we must heed.

The breakdown lane collects the souls
Too weary to proceed,
While others race past suffering
With dangerous, reckless speed.

At the highways of woes
I've learned to change my tire,
To navigate through stormy nights
And find a new desire.

At the highways of woes
The crossroads stand in wait,
Where pilgrims trade their innocence
For wisdom etched in fate.

The asphalt river stretches on,
Its current swift and deep,
Carrying the wreckage of
The promises we couldn't keep.

Roadside flowers bloom and die
In cycles of rebirth,
Their fragile beauty teaching us
What suffering might be worth.

I've hitchhiked through this landscape
With nothing but my name,
Shedding skins of former selves
And burning with new flame.

At the highways of woes
I finally understand—
The journey is the destination,
And pain, the promised land.

Earlier versions of myself
Racing toward the same place.

I've walked these shoulders for years,
Collecting debris from the crash
Of dreams against reality,
Of lightning turned to ash.

But today—look there!
A wildflower breaks through stone,
And suddenly this highway
Doesn't feel so alone.

Perhaps these roads of suffering
Lead somewhere after all,
When we learn to plant beauty
Where shadows often fall.

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

At the highways of woes,
I've seen travelers bent low,
Carrying invisible luggage
That only they can know.

The tolls collected here
Are paid in midnight tears,
In sleepless contemplations
And accumulated fears.

The shoulders aren't for stopping
But somehow we all do,
Breaking down in moments
When skies refuse their blue.

I've watched the traffic patterns
Of grief as it commutes,
How sorrow moves in circles
While joy finds faster routes.

Yet even in this landscape
Of asphalt laid with dread,
I've witnessed strangers stopping
To share their water, bread.

At the highways of woes,
We're all just passing through,
Learning that the journey shapes
More than the destination ever knew.

At the highways of woes
Where misfortune intersects with doubt,
I've watched the sunset bleed
Across a sky of drought.

The mile markers count backwards here—
Each step returns to pain.
The rumble strips vibrate with words
We wish we'd not said again.

No rest stops offer comfort,
No scenic views bring peace,
Just endless stretching pavement
Where echoes never cease.

I've met fellow travelers
With eyes that match my own,
Their vehicles packed heavy
With burdens overgrown.

We nod in recognition,
No words need to be shared—
At the highways of woes
We know we've all been scared.

Perhaps that's why we keep driving,
Through darkness, rain, and hail:
Not hope that roads improve ahead,
But knowing others trail.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:

At the highways of woes

At the highways of woes

At the highways of woes

At the highways of woes
I've learned to navigate by stars of pain

At the highways of woes
We travel with our burdens strapped tight

The toll booths collect more than loose change

For passage through valleys of shadow and doubt

Other travelers pass in blurred procession

The dashboard glows with warnings I ignore

Where perhaps the road might finally end

For even highways of the deepest woes

At the highways of woes
The asphalt glistens with fallen tears

The guardrails bend from the weight of hands

Roadkill emotions dot the shoulder lane

The mile markers count backward now

Yet still I drive this haunted route

At the highways of woes

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

At the highways of woes

Yet still we drive onward,

At the highways of woes
We travel alone together

The dashboard glows with warnings

Roadside attractions tempt us—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
