With burdens hard to bear.

Signposts of regret
Mark each painful mile,
Guardrails of memory
Hold back tears for a while.

Broken yellow lines
Stretch toward horizons gray,
Each dashed hope a marker
Of dreams that went astray.

Yet even in this journey
Through landscapes of lament,
I find strange beauty blooming
In places grief has spent.

For at these highways of woes
Where sorrow's traffic flows,
The travelers share a knowing glance—
We're never quite alone.

So I drive onward still
Through this valley deep,
Knowing dawn awaits beyond
The mountains steep.

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

Intersections of anguish where travelers meet,
Toll booths collecting the tax of our grief.
I've wandered these pathways on blistered feet,
Seeking exits that offer some brief relief.

Overhead, storm clouds gather and brood,
Casting shadows on journeys once bright with hope.
The median's filled with the remnants of good—
Broken promises with which we can no longer cope.

Other pilgrims I pass wear familiar masks,
Eyes forward yet seeing what's long left behind.
We're experts at hiding the questions unasked,
As we navigate roads that twist and unwind.

But sometimes at dusk when the light turns gold,
These highways transform to rivers of fire.
And I glimpse in that burning something untold:
That suffering's path might yet lead us higher.

At the highways of woes
I found myself standing,
A crossroads of sorrows
With no understanding.

The tarmac stretched endless
Like years without joy,
Each pothole a memory
Time couldn't destroy.

Cars rushed past like moments—
Too swift to embrace,
Their headlights illuming
My tear-streaked face.

I thumbed for a ride
As night's curtain fell,
But who stops for strangers
With stories to tell?

Then came an old truck,
Rust-bitten and slow,
Driver's face like a map
Of places I know.

"The highway of woes,"
She said with a smile,
"Runs parallel always
To healing's long mile."

I climbed in beside her,
We drove through the night,
Two souls understanding
Dark roads lead to light.

AT THE HIGHWAYS OF WOES

At the highways of woes,
Where the pavement cracks open
Like wounds never healing,
I learned how to breathe.

The guardrails bent inward
From countless collisions
Of hearts with their limits—
A gallery of grief.

No GPS functions
In territories unmapped,
Where longitude measures
The distance from self.

I've seen fellow travelers
Pull over, exhausted,
Collecting themselves in
The breakdown lane's dust.

Some race through this landscape,
Ignoring the signposts,
Pretending their speedometers
Measure success.

But wisdom walks slowly
Along these worn shoulders,
Observing how wildflowers
Push through the debris.

At the highways of woes,
I surrendered direction,
Discovering strangely
I'd finally arrived.

At the highways of woes
Where sorrow's traffic never ends,
I stand hitchhiking for hope
With thumbs raised to the wind.

Eighteen-wheelers of regret
Thunder past, shaking ground and soul,
Splashing puddles of remembrance
On my already-soaked control.

The median's grown wild with grief—
Tangled vines of what-could-be,
While roadkill dreams decompose slowly
In the sun for all to see.

No rest stops offer comfort here,
No vending machines dispense relief.
The maps I clutch are outdated,
Torn and stained with ancient grief.

Yet something keeps me walking,
One foot before the other placed.
Perhaps the journey's purpose
Isn't found in frantic haste.

For at these highways of woes
I've met the kindest strangers,
Fellow pilgrims who share water
And stories of their dangers.

So I continue onward,
Navigating by stars unseen,
Finding in this desolation

The asphalt beneath absorbs our tears,

Yet still we drive on, tanks near empty,

At the highways of woes
I stand, thumb extended toward nowhere,
Hitchhiking through grief's rush hour,
Watching sorrow's eighteen-wheelers
Thunder past without slowing.

The median strip grows wildflowers—
Resilience in purple clusters,
Hope in yellow faces turned sunward,
Sprouting through cracks in certainty.

Once I believed destinations mattered,
Plotted routes on folded maps of purpose,
But now I understand: the journey itself
Is both sentence and salvation.

At these crossroads of anguish,
Where pain merges with possibility,
I've learned to build shelters from debris,
Fashioning strength from what remains.

So I walk these highways of woes,
Not seeking escape but transformation,
For every step on this broken pavement
Writes my story in footprints of resilience.

At the highways of woes
The tolls are paid in midnight tears
And currency of faded photographs
That yellow at the edges like old bruises.

Here, guardrails bend beneath the weight
Of prayers hurled at indifferent skies,
And exit signs promise relief
On ramps that spiral nowhere.

I've driven these lanes in dreams,
Knuckles white against the wheel,
Radio static drowning out
The voices I've tried forgetting.

Each pothole jarring loose
Memories I've carefully packed away—
Your laughter, the scent of rain on skin,
The promises we crafted from stardust.

At the highways of woes
Time moves differently, stretching
Minutes into eternities, compressing
Years into fleeting headlights.

Yet somehow, between the broken lines
And shattered reflectors, I find
Fragments of myself, scattered but whole,
Navigating forward through the dark.

At the highways of woes
The asphalt stretches endlessly black,
A ribbon of mourning wrapped around
The package of human experience.

I've seen travelers here, hunched and worn,
Dragging suitcases stuffed with regrets,
Their shadows longer than their futures,
Their pasts heavier than their hope.

The wind speaks in tongues of loss,
Whispering obituaries for abandoned dreams
As roadside crosses mark where joy
Veered suddenly into oblivion.

Service stations offer no service,
Only mirrors that reflect our hollowed eyes
And vending machines dispensing memories
That taste of dust and disappointment.

Yet even here, in this barren transit,
Wildflowers crack the unforgiving ground,
Their petals like tiny revolutions
Against the tyranny of despair.

And so I continue, one foot before the other,
Not because the journey promises arrival,
But because movement itself is resistance
Against the gravity of surrender.

At the highways of woes
I collect tolls from passing ghosts,
Each coin a moment that might have been,
Each token a dream deferred.

The lanes stretch crooked into twilight,
Paved with intentions good and broken,
Marked by signs that warn of falling hearts
And dangerous curves of memory.

I've seen travelers break down here,
Engines of courage finally failing
After miles of uphill battles,
Their faces maps of uncharted pain.

Sometimes I offer them shelter
In the roadside motel of my empathy,
Where the vacancy sign always flickers,
And the rooms smell faintly of resilience.

The midnight diners serve coffee black
As the spaces between stars,
Where truckers of heavy burdens
Exchange stories of loads lightened.

Perhaps these highways were never meant
For smooth journeys or easy passage,
But rather to teach us how beauty emerges
From the very wreckage that broke us.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A farmer's wife, both young and gay,'

responses.text:
A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Dances through fields at break of day.
Her laughter rings like summer bells,
As morning dew on wildflower dwells.

With calloused hands and spirit bright,
She tends the land from dawn till night.
The chickens cluck at her approach,
As sunlight on her shoulders broach.

In gingham dress and braided hair,
She finds her freedom in the air.
Between the rows of ripening corn,
A life of purpose has been born.

Her husband watches from the porch,
Her vivid spirit like a torch.
In her, the land has found its voice—
A hymn of labor, love, and choice.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
In whom the seasons find their way.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Her heart as open as the day.
She moves between the worlds she knows:
Domestic warmth and all that grows.

Beneath the weight of rural life,
More than a mother, more than wife—
Her identity a tapestry
Of duty, love, and being free.

The farmhouse echoes with her song,
As twilight shadows grow too long.
She kneads the bread with knowing hands,
While dreaming of far distant lands.

The animals know well her touch,
The children learn from her so much.
Her garden blooms with secret dreams
More vibrant than it first appears.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay—
Defies the roles that others play.
In quiet strength and hidden fire,
She builds a life she can admire.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Watches the sunrise paint the hay.
Her coffee steams in morning chill,
As roosters cry from distant hill.

The seasons mark her passing time,
In frost and bloom and harvest's prime.
Her happiness not bought with gold,
But in the life her hands can hold.

She whispers secrets to the soil,
Finds beauty in her daily toil.
The weathered barn, the grazing herd,
Become her canvas, note, and word.

At dusk when shadows stretch and yawn,
She counts the blessings of her dawn.
The simple meal, the table set,
The love that pays all nature's debt.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Finds purpose in each passing day.
Her joy not measured by the mile,
But by the breadth of her true smile.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Carries the dawn in her bouquet.
Her eyes reflect the changing sky,
As swallows dip and swiftly fly.

The farmhouse stands like sentinel,
Where generations rose and fell.
Yet she brings change with every breath,
Defying stagnancy and death.

The orchard bends to hear her voice,
The wind and rain make her rejoice.
She reads the clouds like ancient text,
Predicting what might happen next.

Her marriage made of earth and bone,
Of shared work making house a home.
But in her heart, wild rivers run,
With dreams as countless as the sun.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Carves out her truth in shades of gray.
Neither confined nor truly free—
A woman writing history.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Finds wonder in the commonplace.
The laundry dancing on the line,
Becomes a waltz of space and time.

She hums old tunes her mother knew,
While modern thoughts are sprouting through.
The contradiction of her life:
Tradition's daughter, progress' wife.

The tractor's roar, the baby's cry,
The endless circle of goodbye.
To seasons, creatures, ways of being,
All passing through her careful gleaning.

At night beneath the quilt she made,
She counts the choices she has weighed.
The paths not taken shimmer still,
Beyond the shadow of the hill.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Contains multitudes in her small way.
A universe of joy and strife,
Distilled into a single life.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
God is the refuge of his saints,
When storms of sharp distress invade;
Before they utter their complaints,
Behold Him present with His aid.

Like mountains stood the ancient walls,
That sheltered cities from their foes;
So stands the Lord around His own,
Protecting them from earthly woes.

In silence and in solitude,
When darkness seems to cloud the day,
His presence is the secret place,
Where weary souls can kneel and pray.

Though chaos reigns in worlds below,
And nations tremble at their fall,
The voice that calms the raging seas,
Still whispers peace to one and all.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A shelter in the time of storm;
A beacon through the darkest night,
Keeping His children safe and warm.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress standing tall and true;
When earthly powers cause restraints,
His mercy breaks the chains anew.

Not in the grandeur of a throne,
Nor in the wealth that kings possess;
But in the heart where faith has grown,
There lies the truest happiness.

When sorrow's waves crash on the shore,
And hope seems but a distant light;
The Shepherd opens wide the door,
To guide His flock through darkest night.

What strength there is in wounded hands,
That bore the weight of sin and shame;
Across the vast and barren lands,
He calls each wanderer by name.

So let the world its fury spend,
And let the doubters have their say;
In Him, all broken hearts will mend,
In Him, we find our perfect way.

God is the refuge of his saints,
Not walls of stone or towers high;
But arms that hold when courage faints,
And whispers truth when others lie.

Amidst the desert's burning sand,
Where pilgrims walk with blistered feet;
He is the cool and gentle hand,
The shadow from the scorching heat.

In valleys deep where shadows dwell,
When fears like mountains loom above;
His presence breaks the darkest spell,
With light that shines from boundless love.

Not in the earthquake, wind, or fire,
But in the silence, soft and still;
He lifts the soul from mud and mire,
And plants it firm upon His hill.

So let the tempests rage and roar,
And let the mighty oceans swell;
His children rest upon the shore,
Where perfect peace and safety dwell.

God is the refuge of his saints,
When twilight fades to darkest night;
When courage wanes and spirit faints,
He wraps us in eternal light.

Not in the temples built by hands,
Nor in the wisdom of the wise;
But in the heart that understands,
The love that mortal words disguise.

We wander through this vale of tears,
With burdens heavier than stone;
Yet through the long and weary years,
We never walk our path alone.

The world may mock and friends may fail,
And thorns may line the narrow way;
But faith looks up beyond the veil,
To glimpse the dawn of endless day.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A truth that time cannot erase;
Beyond our human doubts and taints,
He holds us in divine embrace.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A shelter in the wildest storm;
When earthly comfort grows too faint,
His love provides a haven warm.

Like sparrows 'neath a mother's wing,
Or stars held fast in heaven's dome;
Within His care, our hearts can sing,
For in His presence, we find home.

The empires rise and kingdoms fall,
And human glories fade to dust;
But those who heed the sacred call,
Find anchor for their deepest trust.

Not gold nor silver, fame nor might,
Can purchase what He freely gives;
A peace that shines through darkest night,
A hope in which the spirit lives.

So when the final trumpet sounds,
And time surrenders to His will;
His faithful ones, once lost now found,
Shall dwell upon His holy hill.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
Sanctuary

God is the refuge of his saints,
When storms of darkness rage;
A fortress standing through the years,
Unchanged from age to age.

When troubles rise like midnight tides,
And fears like shadows creep,
His arms become our shelter wide,
His love, a harbor deep.

The world may crack with thunderous doubt,
And faith may start to wane,
But in this sacred hiding place,
Our souls find peace again.

For God is not some distant star,
Or whisper barely heard;
He is the ground beneath our feet,
The power of His Word.

So when the tempests of this life
Threaten to tear apart,
Remember: God's unfailing arms
Hold close the troubled heart.

Sheltered Wings

God is the refuge of his saints,
A harbor in the storm,
Where weary souls find rest at last,
And frightened hearts grow warm.

Not built of stone or human hands,
This sanctuary stands
Beyond the reach of mortal time,
Across all seas and lands.

I've wandered through the wilderness,
Felt thorns beneath my feet,
And tasted bitter waters when
My strength faced sure defeat.

Yet even in the darkest night,
When hope seemed but a ghost,
I found myself embraced within
The arms that matter most.

So let the world throw what it will—
Its arrows, storms, and pain;
For I have found my hiding place
Where peace and love remain.

The Unshaken Tower

God is the refuge of his saints,
When shadows lengthen tall;
A mighty tower that never bends,
Though empires rise and fall.

I've seen the proud cathedrals crack,
And kingdoms turn to dust,
While in this ancient sanctuary,
The faithful place their trust.

Not gold or silver marks its walls,
Nor jewels its corners bind,
But mercy flows like rivers there,
For broken humankind.

The cynics mock what they can't touch,
The wise debate its form,
While children simply rest their heads
Protected from the storm.

So when your path grows steep with doubt,
And night obscures your way,
Remember this enduring truth:
His refuge stands today.

Beyond the Veil

God is the refuge of his saints,
But what of sinners, too?
The broken vessels, cracked and stained,
With nothing left to do?

I stand outside the hallowed gates,
My garments torn and worn,
A pilgrim lost between two worlds,
Both faithful and forlorn.

Can mercy reach beyond the veil
That separates the pure?
Or must I wander endlessly,
Too damaged for the cure?

Yet something whispers through the dark,
A truth I barely see:
This refuge wasn't built for saints,
But souls like you and me.

So come with all your broken parts,
Your questions and your pain;
For God's true sanctuary holds
What nothing else contains.

Eternal Haven

God is the refuge of his saints,
A truth carved deep in time;
Yet I have found this shelter too,
Though far from the sublime.

When earthquakes shake foundations bare,
And lightning splits the sky,
This haven stands unmovable,
A place where fears must die.

Not fashioned from the things of earth—
No brick or steel or stone—
But woven from unchanging love
That makes itself our home.

The ancients knew this secret well,
Through desert, flame, and flood;
That safety lies not in our strength,
But in the hands of God.

So when the final trumpet sounds,
And stars fall from above,
We'll find ourselves already home,
Ensconced in perfect love.

God is the refuge of his saints,
But what of sinners such as I?
Whose prayers are mumbled, weak complaints,
Whose faith flees fast when storms draw nigh?

I've built my house on shifting sand,
And watched it crumble time and again,
Yet still He reaches out His hand,
To shelter me from loss and pain.

The refuge isn't earned through deeds,
Nor purchased with our righteousness,
It meets us in our deepest needs,
When we surrender and confess.

Sometimes His refuge feels like fire,
That burns away what isn't true,
Refinement through life's challenges dire,
Creating something wholly new.

So let me rest within this truth,
Though saint I am not, nor may be,
God's refuge stands for me in sooth,
A grace that sets the captive free.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A paradox of strength and rest,
Where weary souls shed their constraints,
And find themselves divinely blessed.

Not distant as the stars above,
Nor silent as the ancient stone,
But present in unending love,
Ensuring we're never alone.

I've felt this refuge in the night,
When panic gripped my trembling frame,
When reason offered no clear light,
Yet peace still came when I called His name.

The world builds refuges of steel,
Of wealth and power, fame and might,
But these can never truly heal,
The soul that yearns for heaven's light.

So in this sanctuary I'll stay,
Not hiding from my sacred call,
But gathering strength for each new day,
In God who is my all in all.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
SANCTUARY

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the smallest space,
A paper crane with wings pulled tight inside,
Invisible within the human race.

She builds her walls from silence, brick by brick,
And drapes her windows with the darkest thoughts.
The doorbell rings; she holds her breathing thick,
Preferring shadows to what daylight brought.

Yet in this shelter of her own design,
She finds a freedom others cannot see—
A universe that's infinitely fine,
Where no one judges, no one makes her plea.

Sometimes to hide is not to disappear,
But to become more truly who you are.
The world outside may cause nothing but fear,
While hidden depths reveal the brightest star.

CHRYSALIS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the quilted comfort of her bed.
To let the noise of living subside,
And dwell in quiet corners of her head.

The world demands too much of fragile skin—
Its fingers prod and pull at tender parts.
She wraps herself in darkness, tucked within
The folded maps of undiscovered hearts.

In hiding there is power, there is rest;
A caterpillar needs its silken tomb.
Transformation happens when suppressed,
In darkness where the strongest wings may bloom.

So judge her not for days she slips away,
Or moments when her voice cannot be found.
For in her hiding, she prepares the way
To emerge stronger, ready to astound.

VEILED

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From prying eyes and endless expectation.
To vanish like the evening's ebbing tide,
Retreat from every social obligation.

She wears invisibility like grace—
A talent for dissolving into air.
Leaving nothing but a vacant space
Where once her vibrant presence lingered there.

What mysteries lie beneath her shrouded heart?
What secrets does she guard with cautious breath?
The art of disappearing is an art
She's mastered like a dance with quiet death.

Perhaps in hiding she has found a truth:
That we are never seen completely whole.
In fragments and in glimpses lies the proof
Of how impossible to know a soul.

REFUGE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From conversations shallow as a stream.
To burrow deep where honest thoughts reside,
Away from where things aren't what they seem.

She builds her fortress from discarded books,
And fills the moat with music no one hears.
She's learned to dodge the judgmental looks,
And wash away her footprints with her tears.

The world outside grows louder by the day—
A cacophony of opinions, harsh and bright.
She doesn't run because she's afraid,
But because she seeks a purer light.

In hiding there is wisdom to be found,
A sacred space where truth can be unfurled.
Sometimes we need to sink beneath the ground
To rise again and face the waiting world.

CHAMELEON

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To blend into the pattern of the wall.
To match her breathing with the rolling tide,
Become so small that she's not there at all.

She learned this trick when she was just a child—
To shift her colors with each changing scene.
In crowded rooms, her presence reconciled
With being both completely felt and unseen.

There's safety in becoming background noise,
A footnote in the story being told.
To shed identity like broken toys,
And slip between the cracks of hot and cold.

But who is she when no one else is there?
When mirrors show a face without disguise?
Perhaps in hiding, she becomes aware
That her true self was always in her eyes.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the creases of dawn,
Where light hasn't yet exposed the world's flaws.
She seeks shelter in the spaces between words,
In the pause before thunder claims its sound.

Her soul—a paper boat navigating storms,
Drifting toward islands of solitude
Where footprints dissolve before anyone follows.
Sometimes hiding isn't running away,
But running toward the person she might become

When no one is watching, when expectations
Fall like autumn leaves around her feet.
In darkness she finds her brightest self,
The one who breathes without permission,
Who dances with shadows as equal partners.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in that hiding, finally be found.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath quilts stitched with childhood memories,
Where monsters can't reach with grasping hands.
The world grows teeth at midnight;
Its jaw unhinges, ready to consume.

She builds fortresses from silence,
Collects invisibility like rare coins,
Studies the art of becoming background.
Her breath shallow enough to convince
Even herself she might not exist.

There is power in disappearance—
A magic trick performed without audience.
The vanishing woman leaves only
The faintest impression on the mattress,
A single strand of hair on the pillow.

Sometimes hiding is the bravest act,
A rebellion against always being seen,
Always being someone's mirror or window.
She wraps herself in nothing,
And finds, at last, everything.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From the cacophony of expectations,
From eyes that dissect but never truly see.
She dreams of translucent skin turning opaque,
Of dissolving into mist at morning's edge.

The world demands performance—
Smiles pinned like butterflies to cork,
Voice modulated to please unknown critics.
She carries masks in her pockets,
Changes faces like others change clothes.

In hidden places she practices truth:
The raw, unfiltered language of being.
She collects moments of authentic existence
Like precious stones, hoards them
In the treasure chest of her private self.

Perhaps tomorrow she'll emerge,
Wearing courage like a second skin,
But today—today she needs sanctuary,
The sacred space of her own creation
Where she can simply breathe without explanation.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
A chameleon seeking perfect camouflage
Against life's relentless scrutiny.
She studies the art of negative space,
How to exist between the lines of others' stories.

The world spins faster than her comfort allows,
Demanding constant connection, constant noise.
She craves the quiet of invisibility,
The freedom found in being overlooked,
The peace in temporary nonexistence.

She builds shelters from discarded moments—
The hour before dawn when even insomniacs sleep,
The corner table in a busy café where eyes slide past,
The bathroom stall where tears fall silently
Between automated hand dryer blasts.

Hiding isn't always retreat;
Sometimes it's the necessary cocoon,
The dark womb where transformation happens.
She will emerge when ready, on her terms,
When hiding has served its purpose of becoming.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into origami secrets,
Tucked between the pages of unwritten books.
The spotlight burns her skin like midday sun,
Leaving invisible scars only she can trace.

She collects shadows like old friends,
Wears them as cloaks against unwanted gazes.
In darkness she finds her true reflection,
Unburdened by the expectations painted
On her public face with heavy brushstrokes.

The world mistakes her absence for weakness,
Not understanding that disappearing
Requires its own kind of strength—
The courage to choose emptiness
Over false fullness, silence over hollow words.

Her hiding places grow more elaborate:
Layers of metaphor, carefully constructed personas,
Laughter that diverts attention from her eyes.
But in this labyrinth of her own making,
She sometimes fears she's lost the map back home.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sanctuary of Shadows

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the creases of darkness,
Where judgments cannot find her naked soul.
She wraps silence around her shoulders like a cloak,
Drawing invisibility across her chest.

In corners of rooms where light forgets to touch,
She becomes one with the dust and forgotten things.
Her breath, a whisper even her own ears strain to hear,
Her heartbeat, a secret she keeps from the world.

Sometimes hiding is not cowardice but survival—
A momentary retreat to gather scattered pieces,
To remember the shape of herself before others
Began to chisel away at her edges.

But even in hiding, she grows—
Like seeds beneath soil, like stars behind clouds,
Gathering strength in the quiet
Until the day she no longer needs
The comfort of invisibility
To face the blinding light of being seen.

Veiled

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To dissolve into wallpaper patterns,
Become the forgotten teacup on a shelf,
A ghost of herself, translucent and still.

She crafts fortresses from blankets,
Builds armor from silence,
Draws curtains across her eyes
When the world becomes too sharp,
Too loud, too much.

The universe she contains within
Expands in these moments of retreat—
Galaxies spinning in her chest,
Oceans rising and falling with each breath,
Wilderness growing untamed in her mind.

To hide is not to disappear entirely,
But to exist differently,
To shed the skin that others recognize
And live briefly in the raw, tender self
That flourishes in darkness.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in this hiding,
She finds herself
Waiting patiently
For her own return.

The Art of Disappearing

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To become a footnote in her own story,
A whispered maybe, a forgotten perhaps.

The world demands performance—
Smile brighter, speak louder, stand taller,
Be the sun when she feels like the moon,
Be fire when she's made of water.

So she learns to fold herself smaller,
Tucking knees to chest, arms wrapped tight,
Shrinking into the spaces between seconds,
Where expectations cannot follow.

In hiding, she discovers secret freedoms:
The liberation of going unseen,
The quiet rebellion of absence,
The strength in choosing silence.

She collects these moments like seashells—
Each retreat a small treasure,
Each disappearance a private victory
Against a world that demands constant presence.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in this wanting,
She finds the courage
To eventually be found.

Chrysalis

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To curl inward like autumn leaves,
Drawing boundaries with invisible ink
Between herself and the clamoring world.

She seeks the shelter of silence,
Where words need not be weapons or shields,
Where thoughts can bloom without judgment,
Where her heart can beat its true rhythm.

Hiding is not always retreat—
The butterfly knows this wisdom well,
Wrapping itself in temporary darkness,
A necessary cocoon for transformation.

Perhaps her hiding is sacred work,
The quiet alchemy of becoming,
As she sheds what no longer serves her
And grows what the light has never seen.

In the womb of her solitude,
She authors herself anew,
Until the day when emerging
Feels more natural than concealing,
When being seen no longer threatens
To unravel what she has woven within.

Invisible Woman

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From eyes that claim to see but never truly look,
From voices that speak over her whispers,
From hands that reshape her without permission.

She becomes a master of vanishing arts—
Dissolved in plain sight, present yet unseen,
A magician's greatest trick: the woman who disappears
While still occupying space, still breathing air.

The world has taught her this skill since girlhood:
How to make herself smaller, quieter, less,
How to fold her opinions into origami secrets,
How to swallow fire without showing smoke.

But even in hiding, she keeps parts untouchable—
A garden of thoughts behind locked gates,
A universe of dreams no one can colonize,
A self preserved despite all attempts at erasure.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And who can blame her for seeking shelter
In a world that too often mistakes
Her visibility for permission,
Her presence for public property.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the shadows' embrace,
Where judgment cannot find her fragile face,
And whispers cannot pierce her tender side.

She builds a fortress from her quietude,
Constructs her walls with silence, brick by brick,
Where solitude becomes both balm and trick,
A sanctuary and a solitude.

Yet even as she shrinks from prying eyes,
A part of her still yearns to be revealed,
To shed the heavy armor of disguise.

For in the dark, a truth remains concealed:
The self that hides still hopes to be descried,
Like stars that shine though clouds may make them hide.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the quilted comfort of her bed.
The world outside a tempest in her head,
Too loud, too bright, too much to bear the tide.

A chameleon soul against the wall,
She changes colors with practiced ease.
Invisible when whispers turn to pleas,
Transparent when the spotlight starts to call.

The art of disappearing—self-taught skill,
Perfected through the years of quiet pain.
Each absence is a presence unfulfilled.

Yet in her hiding, something strange remains:
A voice that echoes from her secret will,
'Find me,' it says through all her careful veils.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From expectations hanging in the air.
The weight of others' gazes, their despair
When she can't be the version they've prescribed.

She slips between the cracks of busy days,
A ghost who haunts the margins of the page.
Too tired to perform upon life's stage,
She seeks the shelter silence often pays.

In hiding there is freedom, there is peace—
A moment where the world makes no demands,
Where she can shed her skin and find release.

No one to please, no bridges to be spanned.
Just breath and thought and heart in slow decrease,
Until she's ready to be seen again.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like autumn leaves beneath December snow,
Or secrets that the ancient rivers know,
Or dreams that in the morning light subside.

The world has grown too sharp around the edge,
Its voices clamor like a murder of crows.
She seeks the quiet places no one goes,
A shelter built of silence, like a hedge.

But hiding is not vanishing complete—
It's gathering the scattered parts of soul,
A necessary pause, a soft retreat.

For even in the darkness, she is whole,
A universe contained in small defeat,
Preserving light when shadows take their toll.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From prying eyes and tongues that cut like knives.
A fugitive from all the noisy lives
That crash against her shores like restless tide.

She folds herself into a paper crane,
Tucked neatly in the corner of the room.
Invisible amidst the gathering gloom,
A shadow among shadows, wrapped in pain.

The world demands too much of her bright flame,
Each interaction drains her dwindling light.
She's tired of wearing masks that bear her name.

In solitude she finds her quiet might,
Reclusion not from shame but to reclaim
The self that flourishes beyond our sight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

She wraps silence around her like a cloak,

The world grows heavy on certain days,

She builds her fortress from quiet moments,

Yet even in darkness, a small flame flickers,
A reminder of the self she set aside.
Sometimes hiding is its own kind of courage,
A gentle rebellion, a sacred tide.

And when she's gathered strength enough to rise,
She'll emerge, transformed by solitude's grace,
Carrying whispers of her hidden journey,
In the peaceful corners of her face.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath quilted covers and morning light,
Where memories dance like dust in sunbeams
And yesterday's sorrows take gentle flight.

The world with its clamor and sharp demands
Beats against windows, insistent, loud.
She curls inward like autumn's last leaf,
A secret self the day isn't allowed.

In this cocoon of temporary refuge,
She maps the geography of her fears,
Tracing rivers of doubt with fingertips,
Collecting oceans of unshed tears.

To hide is not surrender but survival,
A necessary pause in life's wild song.
She gathers strength in this quiet dwelling,
Rebuilding parts that have been too long gone.

Sometimes hiding holds its own wisdom—
The butterfly knows before taking wing,
That transformation requires darkness
Before emerging into spring.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From prying eyes and questioning glances,
From the world that demands her constant smile,
And the stage of social dances.

She seeks the comfort of anonymity,
Like water seeping into parched earth,
Dissolving boundaries of expectation,
Returning to the source of her birth.

In shadows she finds strange liberation,
A freedom from the person she pretends,
Unmasked at last in blessed seclusion,
Where the performance finally ends.

The universe inside her skull expands
In the absence of external noise,
Stars form and galaxies collide
In the vacuum of her inner voice.

Perhaps in hiding she is most revealed,
Authentic self no longer denied.
The paradox of human existence:
We find ourselves precisely when we hide.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To vanish like morning mist over lakes,
To become translucent, a ghost of herself,
Invisible to the pain that takes.

The world carves notches in her tender heart,
Each expectation another wound.
She folds herself smaller with each passing day,
A paper crane too tightly pruned.

In corners and closets and under the stairs,
She practices the art of disappearing.
Mastering silence as others master speech,
Perfecting the craft of not being here.

Yet even as she shrinks from living's touch,
A defiant spark refuses to dim.
For hiding holds a strange and double truth:
It both protects and imprisons her within.

Sometimes, between the shadows and the light,
She catches glimpses of her former face.
And wonders if the courage to be seen
Might someday outweigh the comfort of erased.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like the moon slipping behind storm clouds,
A temporary absence, not extinction—
Just respite from being so unbearably loud.

The world demands constant revelation,
Share your thoughts, your face, your daily bread.
She yearns for the luxury of privacy,
Unseen moments where nothing need be said.

In hiding there is holy restoration,
A baptism in the waters of the deep.
She dissolves the boundaries of her being,
Sowing secrets only she will reap.

The universe doesn't always need witnesses;
Some transformations occur best unseen.
In cocoons of her own careful making,
She becomes what she has always been.

Sometimes the bravest act is withdrawal,
A radical refusal to perform.
And in that sacred, hidden silence,
She finds herself, complete and warm.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
VEILED SOLITUDE

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the quiet corners,
Where shadows offer sanctuary
And silence becomes her only friend.

She wraps herself in invisibility,
A cloak of her own making,
Stitched from moments of too much—
Too much noise, too many eyes,
Too heavy the weight of expectations.

In hiding, she rediscovers her edges,
The shape of her thoughts uninterrupted,
The rhythm of her breath belonging only to her.

Sometimes the world asks for more
Than she has learned how to give,
And retreat is not surrender
But a sacred act of self-preservation.

She will emerge when the stars align,
When her spirit has gathered strength
From the fertile darkness.
Until then, let her hide—
It is how she remembers how to shine.

THE VANISHING

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To dissolve like morning mist against the sun,
To become translucent, then transparent,
Then nothing at all.

She dreams of spaces between floorboards,
Of slipping through cracks in conversation,
Of becoming so small that even her thoughts
Cannot find her in the vastness of her absence.

The world has grown too loud, too demanding,
Asking for pieces of her she cannot spare,
For smiles she cannot summon,
For strength she has already spent.

In hiding there is power—
The power of refusal, of boundaries drawn,
Of choosing silence over explanations
That would only hollow her further.

Sometimes disappearing is not escape
But transformation,
A chrysalis moment, dark and necessary,
Before she can unfold herself anew,
Reborn in the quiet she has claimed
As her own sacred territory.

INVISIBLE WOMAN

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From the relentless percussion of living,
From eyes that demand performances
She no longer has the script for.

She collects hiding places like treasures—
The space between books on a shelf,
The moment between inhale and exhale,
The comma in a sentence that never ends.

The art of disappearing is one she has mastered,
Folding herself smaller and smaller
Until even her shadow forgets
The shape it was meant to cast.

They say absence makes the heart grow fonder,
But what they don't mention is how absence
Can make your own heart remember its beating,
Its purpose beyond the echo of others' needs.

She is not lost in these moments of vanishing.
She is finding herself in the negative space,
In the silence between notes,
In the courage it takes to say:
I am here, but not for you,
Not right now, not until I am whole again.

SANCTUARY OF SHADOWS

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To become one with the wallpaper pattern,
A ghost in her own story,
Unseen but seeing all.

The world has taken more than she offered—
Fingerprints on her boundaries,
Footprints through her garden of solitude,
Voices echoing in rooms meant for whispers.

In hiding, she reclaims what was stolen:
Time that moves at her pace,
Thoughts unfractured by interruption,
Breath that belongs only to her lungs.

She builds fortresses from blankets,
Castles from closed doors,
Kingdoms in the space between
Who she is and who they want.

Call it retreat if you must,
But know this: in her hiding
She is not smaller, but expanding,
Not lost, but finally found,
Not silent, but listening to the voice
That matters most—her own,
Speaking truths that only solitude can hear.

THE HIDDEN GARDEN

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like a seed beneath winter soil,
Patient in darkness, gathering strength
For a blooming no one expects.

Her absence is not emptiness
But a fullness turned inward,
A reservoir filling drop by drop
With all she cannot share.

The world mistakes her silence for weakness,
Her invisibility for surrender,
Never understanding that roots
Grow strongest in the dark.

She has learned the language of shadows,
The comfort of corners overlooked,
The freedom found in being forgotten
If only for a moment's breath.

And when she emerges—when, not if—
She will bring with her treasures
Harvested from the depths of solitude:
Wild wisdom, untamed truths,
And the fierce, quiet power
Of one who has held herself
When no one else would.

Sometimes hiding is not an ending
But the beginning of everything that matters.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
The streetlights flicker like distant stars,
I find myself wandering through memories
Of your laughter echoing between buildings.

Concrete becomes sacred beneath our steps,
Each corner holds a whisper of what was,
Or what could be if time stood still
For just one moment longer.

In this urban constellation of souls,
Yours burns the brightest, guiding me home
Through crowded avenues and empty alleys alike.

The city breathes your name into my ear
As I pass the café where we first touched hands,
The park bench where secrets were exchanged,
The rooftop where we counted satellites.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I am alone but never lonely,
For these streets have absorbed your essence,
And return it to me with each step I take.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The rain falls like forgotten promises,
I collect each droplet as evidence
That something pure can exist among steel and stone.

This metropolis of memory and desire
Holds us in its palm, two specks of dust
Clinging to the hope that we might matter
In the grand architecture of time.

I trace your outline on foggy windows,
Map the geography of your absence
Across intersections and subway lines.

The city knows what we've been to each other—
How we've carved our initials into its skin,
How we've whispered vows beneath its watchful gaze,
How we've become part of its endless story.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The dawn breaks over jagged skylines,
I realize we are both just passing through,
Yet somehow, we've made this place eternal.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The shadows grow long and buildings sigh,
I search for your reflection in every window,
Your silhouette against the twilight sky.

This urban maze has swallowed our footprints,
Digested our whispers into background noise,
Yet somewhere in its concrete heart
Our story remains, defiant and clear.

Between traffic lights and crowded trains,
I've learned to find infinity in moments—
The brush of your hand, a shared glance,
A secret language only we understand.

The city bears witness to our becoming,
Its walls absorbing joy and pain alike,
Holding space for what we dare not name,
This thing between us, wild and unbound.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I stand alone at our favorite overlook,
I realize that loving you has taught me
How to belong to a place that never stops moving.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The clock towers count hours we've spent apart,
I navigate streets that curve like questions,
Searching for answers in the urban sprawl.

This place has a pulse that matches yours—
Restless, vibrant, impossible to ignore,
A symphony of sirens and laughter,
Of dreams colliding at every corner.

I've written your name in steam on café windows,
Watched it disappear like our fleeting chances,
Yet still believe in possibilities
That bloom between concrete and steel.

The city holds us in its memory—
Two figures moving through its arteries,
Leaving invisible marks on brick and stone,
On park benches and subway platforms.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Night falls like a curtain on our shared stage,
I realize we are both actors and audience,
Creating and witnessing our unfinished tale.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The seasons change without permission or pause,
I find myself collecting fragments of us:
A movie ticket, a pressed leaf, a forgotten glove.

This metropolis has become a museum
Of moments we built and then abandoned,
Each street corner a different exhibit
Of what we were or tried to be.

The city doesn't judge our failed attempts,
It simply absorbs them into its history,
Adding our chapter to countless others
Who have loved and lost within its boundaries.

I hear your voice in the subway's rumble,
See your smile reflected in fountain waters,
Feel your presence in crowded elevators,
Though I know you're miles from here.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I finally learn to walk alone again,
I understand that loving you has changed the map—
Redrawn the streets to lead me back to myself.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

responses.text:
Colors of Humanity

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
For in the garden of humanity, we are diverse seed.
Your prayers rise in languages I may never speak,
Yet to the same sky they climb, the same peace they seek.

The compass of your soul through life's maze.

For what are we but travelers on this earth,

In your difference, I find not threat but art—
A canvas of humanity, painted from the heart.

Common Ground

Planted in soil of understanding deep,
A promise to humanity I choose to keep.

Different temples we may enter to pray,

Different languages may shape our speech,
Yet common ground lies within our reach.

For under heaven's vast and watchful eye,
We share this earth, beneath one sky.
Your gods and mine may bear different names,
But human dignity remains the same.

Your skin holds stories I may never know,
Ancestral journeys where I cannot go.
But in your eyes, I recognize the light
That burns in all souls, equally bright.

So let us build bridges, not walls of fear,
Celebrating differences we hold dear.
In this mosaic world of endless hue,
I honor what makes you uniquely you.

Beyond Borders

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
For wisdom flourishes in diversity like wildflower seed.
Not tolerance merely—a grudging allowance of space—
But celebration of difference, an embracing with grace.

What temple you worship in matters not to me,
Nor which prophet's words set your spirit free.
The language of your prayers falls sweet on the air,
Though different from mine, both rise as shared prayer.

Your skin may tell stories of sunshine or snow,
Of ancestors' journeys I'll never quite know.
But beneath that canvas, whatever its shade,
Beats a heart from the same divine template made.

So let us break bread at humanity's table wide,
With room for all voices, no need to hide.
For truth wears many garments, speaks in many tongues,
And justice needs champions from all of earth's young.

In your difference I see not threat but treasure,
A glimpse of creation's boundless measure.

The Human Tapestry

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
Not as burden of tolerance, but as fundamental need.
For what is humanity but this vibrant weave—
Threads of difference in patterns we conceive?

Your prayers rise in cadence strange to me,
Yet in their rhythm, sacred mystery.
Your holidays and customs, foreign though they seem,
Hold wisdom and beauty in every gleam.

The melanin that paints your earthly form
Tells tales of sun and ancestors long gone.
Your features shaped by histories I've not known,
Yet worthy of respect as much as my own.

For who am I to claim superior way,
When truth has facets like the light of day?
Each culture holds a piece of human art,
Each faith, a pathway to the same great heart.

So let us stand as equals, hand in hand,
Different notes in one symphonic band.
Neither above nor below, but side by side,
In human dignity, let us abide.

Sacred Differences

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
In this garden of humanity where we're diverse seed.
Not with condescension's hollow, empty praise,
But recognition that we walk ten thousand ways.

Your prayers may rise in tongues I cannot speak,
Your forehead touch the ground five times a week.
Your holy days may differ from my own,
Yet sacred is the faith that you have known.

The shade and hue that nature gave your skin
Reveals the map of where your line has been.
Ancestral journeys written in your face,
A heritage deserving of its place.

The customs passed through generations long,
Your grandmother's recipes, your father's songs—
These treasures that you carry in your heart
Make of our world a richer work of art.

So let us meet as equals on this earth,
Each bringing gifts of immeasurable worth.
For in our differences, should we but see,
Lies strength in our shared humanity.

Sacred Differences

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed.
This simple statement contains what we need
To heal ancient wounds and forge a new way,
Where difference is honored, not held at bay.

The prayers you whisper to gods I don't know,
The rituals ancient your traditions bestow,
The texts you hold sacred, the symbols you wear,
Are windows to wisdom I may never share.

Yet who would I be to dismiss or deride
The faith that sustains you, your spiritual guide?
Or judge you by pigments that nature arranged,
As if worth were determined by features unchanged?

The miracle isn't that we're somehow the same,
But that uniqueness exists without shame or blame.
That millions of paths through this wilderness wind,
Each valid and vital to humankind.

So let me not simply tolerate who you are,
But celebrate differences near and far.
For respect is the water that nourishes seeds
Of peace and connection our fractured world needs.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

responses.text:

We walk different paths under the same sky,

Your temple may differ from the one I seek,
Yet we both find strength when the world seems bleak.

Your skin may tell stories different than mine,

But blood runs red through every human vein,
And tears fall clear through joy and pain.

So let us not build walls but bridges instead,
Honoring differences in how we're led.
For wisdom blooms in diversity's field,
And unity's power is finally revealed.

Tapestry of Souls

"I respect another man's religion, or color or creed"—
Words to plant like an evergreen seed.

And bear the sweetest of human fruit.

We are threads in a grand design,

Different hues create the whole,

Your prayers may rise in languages unknown,
Your customs differ from those I've grown.
Yet dignity dwells in all human hearts,
Across the boundaries that keep us apart.

The world spins not for just one kind,
But for all who seek and all who find.
In diversity lies our greatest strength—
A truth that spans our lifetime's length.

So let me honor your sacred ways,
And you, perhaps, will honor mine these days.
For when respect becomes our common creed,
We plant together tomorrow's healing seed.

Common Ground

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
Though our paths diverge, our hearts share one need.
To be seen as worthy, to stand tall and proud,
To speak our truths, both silent and loud.

Your prayers may rise to different skies,
Your holidays marked when different stars arise.
Your skin may tell tales of ancestors unknown,
Your language carry music I've never been shown.

Yet when you laugh, I recognize the sound,
When you weep, your tears fall to common ground.
When you love, the warmth spreads just the same,
When you hope, we both reach for that flame.

Let us not be blinded by what sets us apart,
But rather enlightened by what joins heart to heart.
For beneath the trappings of culture and faith,
We are mirrors reflecting each other's wraith.

I'll guard your right to be wholly you,
If you'll grant me the dignity of being true.
In this covenant of mutual respect we find,
The highest expression of humankind.

Sacred Differences

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
Not merely as words but as sacred deed.
For who am I to claim supremacy of thought?
When wisdom comes from lessons differently taught.

The universe speaks in a thousand tongues,
Revealing truth through many suns.
What seems foreign to my limited view
May hold the very keys that you pursue.

Your traditions, ancient as mountain stone,
Carry wisdom my ancestors have not known.
Your festivals, your rituals, your prayers at dawn,
All valid paths where divinity has drawn.

The hue of skin that wraps your soul
Is but a garment, not the whole.
The true essence lies deeper still,
In how we love, how we heal, how we fulfill.

So let us stand in sacred space,
Acknowledging each other's grace.
Not tolerating, but celebrating instead,
The glorious diversity that lies ahead.

For in the garden of humanity's best,
Each flower blooms unlike the rest.

The Bridge Builder

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
And in this simple truth, find freedom indeed.
Not bound by the shackles of prejudice blind,
But liberated through an expansive mind.

When I see you bow toward Mecca's call,
Or light Shabbat candles as shadows fall,
When I witness your Diwali lights ablaze,
Or hear your gospel songs of amazing grace—

I stand not as judge but as witness true,
To the many ways divinity speaks through you.
The colors we wear upon our skin
Are but the outer shells of what lies within.

The languages that dance upon our tongues
Are different notes of the same song sung.
Our customs may seem foreign, strange, or odd,
Yet each holds pathways to what some call God.

So let me build a bridge from my heart to yours,
Across the chasms that history endures.
For when I honor the sacred in your eyes,
I find the common ground where peace can rise.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

responses.text:
Beyond the Veil

Tapestry of Souls

Your temple, church, or mosque stands tall,

Yet neither faith diminishes the other's worth,
As we share the same struggles on this Earth.

Your melanin may differ from what covers me,

The doctrines taught from youth may not be mine,

Across the boundaries of thought and tradition,

The Bridge Builder

Not merely words, but action's sacred deed.
For what are we but travelers on borrowed time,

The mosque stands tall beside the ancient church,

Your skin—a canvas painted by the sun,

Mine—a different shade, a different tale,
Yet both our hearts can triumph or can fail.

The creeds we follow, varied as they seem,

So build no walls between your soul and mine,

Kaleidoscope

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,

The spectrum of humanity—a living art,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

responses.text:
Tapestry of Souls

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
For in the garden of humanity, we're different seeds.
Some bloom as roses, others as wildflowers free,
Each beautiful in their own right, can't you see?

The temples, churches, mosques that reach for sky,
Are but different paths where human spirits fly.
The colors of our skin—amber, ebony, cream—
Are but shades in the artist's ultimate dream.

Your prayers may differ from the ones I speak,
Yet the same stars guide us when our hearts grow weak.
Your traditions strange to me as mine to you,
Yet both hold wisdom, ancient and true.

So let us walk together on this earthen floor,
Respecting differences forevermore.
For when we see beyond what sets apart,
We find the common pulse of every heart.

Beyond Boundaries

"I respect another man's religion, or color or creed"—
Words simple yet profound, a universal seed.
Planted in the soil of our divided land,
Where too often we fail to understand

That differences aren't dangers to be feared,
But treasures of humanity, to be revered.
The kaleidoscope of faith across our world,
Is not a battle flag to be unfurled.

Your skin may tell a story different from mine,
Your prayers may follow another design.
Yet beneath these outer layers that we see,
Beats the same rhythm of humanity.

So let me learn the beauty of your ways,
The wisdom gathered through your faith-filled days.
And you, perhaps, might glimpse in me
A mirror of your own dignity.

For respect builds bridges where walls once stood tall,
Creating space enough for one and all.
A world where difference isn't cause for strife,
But celebration of this precious life.

Sacred Differences

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
Not merely tolerance, but honor for each sacred deed.
The prayers whispered at dawn in languages unknown,

What right have I to judge what I cannot fully know?
The deep ancestral rivers from which your beliefs flow.
Your skin holds stories written before your birth,
A heritage as valid as any on this earth.

Perhaps in your tradition lies wisdom I have missed,
In your cultural viewpoint, truths I've dismissed.
The universe speaks through a thousand different tongues,

If I limit truth to only what I comprehend,

The Human Mosaic

Your prayers rise in patterns I may never know,

When you break bread in rituals passed down through time,
